GJY1pW2qUHc1a6cSTrHWhw.text: it's alright. decent price, no wait. and service is fast.   i only had a spam musubi for $2. it helped ease my growling stomach. I had a few bites of the kalua pork -- it was okay.. i wish the cabbage and the pork were more shredded. And it was too watery. I like it a bit more dry. The rice that came with was not hot and was not soft either. It tasted like day old rice. -- no bueno.  on another note this place definitely satisfies your hungry stomach.

NQxsDLafuObpYoCkSgOwkA.text: Ever since my old buddies and I began going to Vegas in highschool with our fake IDs and all (Jesus, that was over a decade ago now......), Aloha Specialties has become an obligatory stop on each trip. It's in the California Casino, which is in North/Downtown Las Vegas. If you've never seen this part of Vegas, you might want to check it out just for kicks. It's usually our desperation stop when we lose all our money elsewhere and need some lower-limit tables to make a comeback.   But back to Aloha Specialties...  If you've ever eaten at an L&Ls or other Hawaiian BBQ joint, you'll feel right at home here. Loco mocos, hamburger steaks, chicken teriyaki, macaroni salad, spam musubis, they're all here. Stick with the plates, and if you want a soup, only pick the saimin. It's all pretty good, and portions are extremely generous. It's definitely no substitute for "the real thing" from Hawaii, but it's not as terrible as L&Ls...   Aloha Specialties is a very low-key place where you show up really hungover and collapse all over tables. Trust me, you'll look like an idiot if you show up at all dressed up expecting the usual glitz and glam of "Vegas". Everybody is very relaxed, you won't be hooking up with random strangers here (unless you're old to really old locals who don't talk much), and service is friendly without being the slightest bit overbearing.   The ordering system is a little weird, as you order your food in a line, then sit down at any table you'd like, and then they bring you food and continue to bring you things you request afterwards. You'll have to specifically ask for certain things that you'd normally consider "essentials". I guarantee you that even if everybody only orders just what they want, you will end up with too much food, which is a good thing. Cash only, folks.

FkiFXhz2_mkxg-YqtgnRqA.text: During our Annual trip to Vegas, aside from the pricey restaurants on the strip we always want to find the hidden gems. And this is definitely one of them. It's located on the second floor of downtown's California Hotel. Pretty big seating area. Keep in mind it's not a fancy restaurant.   I order the Saimin with wonton. Pretty much it's noodles with kimchi and wonton. Pretty good but not too special. Boyfriend order the Korean chicken and beef and he loved it. We also tried the Spam Masubi, which is like sushi with spam. Pretty good as a appetizer. They also have Hawaiian soda.   Overall a good experience. I would definitely come back to try other dishes.

nvGQX7bG0_F4LJ3N97BaTA.text: This is located on the 2nd floor of THE CAL! Above Market Street Cafe.  My family & I come here to eat Large Saimen :) Saimen is bomb[d0t]com.! *(Yeah, I say that a lot in my reviews). I mean, it's just noodles & soup, but so good.! I haven't eaten any other of the food items since I was small, just the saimen. All I can say it's GOOOOD.!

bsxHj_0Z72a_JlJBDUUFAw.text: What happened to the portions?  Yesterday, I ordered two teri beef sandwiches and a large saimin.  They reduced the portion about a third.  Oh well, good food and great prices.  Good value.

OS0TMRQJu54cwMljts9oHQ.text: Super good Hawaiian food! Quality was good and it was filling. Side of Mac Salad for $1.95 is worth every penny! Only flaw is the line takes forever. Its simple order and pay but the line moves very very slow... I got the teriyaki combo and it was perfect.

UDeyID_OI4yULEF6MvwgLg.text: Loco moco = best Vegas hangover breakfast. The 9th Island is a really fun place. Stop here to eat every time I'm in town.

m3DVaRLi2ZCbK9LYvQgg_g.text: Saimen I feel like , used to be better. I keep ordering that hoping it was as good as I remember it, but it hasn't been. Would stick to ordering the large rice plates. It is in a casino, up stairs. Coconut jello dessert-pretty good.

uzroR5gqvJM3JOKifpVZMQ.text: Ohhh man this place is dope! Hawaiian food late night is always great! I know this place closes early like around 10pm, but you still can get some of the menu items at the restaurant downstairs. Same company, just using that place for late night Hawaiian munchies I guess...   I usually get their spam and eggs. Not much I can say about this meal, except that spam is always 2 thumbs up! I know they got kalua pig upstairs. The kalua pig is flavorful and juicy. Downstairs they got the Ox Tail soup is pretty darn tasty. They pack that bowl with at least 5 big ox tails!! The broth is similar to a filipino dish called Nilaga... so I can't argue about that! It also comes with a bowl of rice.  Definitely will be coming here for my late night Hawaiian grindz...  Aloha bitches!!

QAAmtyQrLxisVdBKnwLEUg.text: Wow, this place has really good local style food. It would do well in Hilo due to the amount of food and cheap prices.  Kim chee saimin and a flash(chix/beef) bowl with 2 drinks only $15 total!

ElXilTmZeOb4WN9dXJ6QVA.text: Mmm mm. A place to go for some good home cooked style food. I always have a hard time ordering because everything on the menu sounds so good. A mix of hawaiian and filipino items.   My last visit, I ordered the classic Loco Moco. A simple yet filling dish consisting of hamburger patty, with two eggs, topped with tasty gravy all covering a base of white rice.   The place can get really busy around lunch time, so get there between 10-11am and you'll be good. After that, wait time can be almost 30-45mins to order. After the lunch rush, wait time isn't an issue.  Oh!... and bring cash. no card accepted.

nFWuLxj5H7w8ICI-Iuz6Jg.text: YUMMM!!! I loved this place.  The teriyaki burger was sooo good.  And definitely worth $4.99!  It was huge!  Good flavors there.  I also had their kimchi saimin.  Taste like kimchi water.  Nothing too special about it but not bad with the beef bits.  The spam misubis, cant mess up there.

tamHXI7GiTHJOnaCzMLTWA.text: Been eating here since my teen years. Flavor is always great, people are always nice. Best spam musubi in town along with a side of Teri chicken.

dGEmOozUCxgCi1uc9px7FQ.text: As a regular here, I felt it was time to write a review. This restaurant is by far my favorite place to grab Hawaiian food in town. The prices are great and the portions huge! Not to mention that the quality of food is spectacular! Everything from crispy teriyaki chicken bowl, korean chicken, loco moco, saimin, and spam musubi, they are all so good! Tons of flavor and definitely cooked like they do on islands. This little place gets crowded around lunch time and early dinner time, so if you're in a rush I'd make arrangements before going here. Great place for locals and tourists alike!

BBPXFmsIU_7iT1UG5SB3_w.text: I've been coming here for as long as I can remember. Almost every time i'm in Vegas, I would drive down to the California hotel just to eat at this place. There is nothing more satisfying than a large bowl of saimin and a nice little side of hot mustard for dipping, especially after a night of drinking.  The workers are always super friendly and the prices are extremely cheap especially for the amount of food you get. if you're ever looking for a place to try real Hawaiian food in Las Vegas thats not too far off the main strip, this is definitely the spot to go to.

afZOxYBGNsevjaj9bMyZog.text: 3/5/11  Love this place and just the casual atmosphere! This time we tried the fried saimin and the Korean style chicken...both good, but the fried saimin wasn't all that fried..it was pretty saucy...next time i'm gonna try the Loco Moco! this place is becoming our regular places to stop by...I mean it's not the greatest food..and some of the dishes can be pretty fatty...but mebbe it's the Asian majority here that makes one just feel at home...LOL

A8bxvzU9Kq4evClRx1GJhA.text: There's one place I ALWAYS go to when in Vegas and that is the Aloha Specialties Restaurant at the California Hotel. This place reminds me of being in Hawaii- very ono. The combo plates are HUGE as is the saimins so feel free to share (and add wontons to the saimin)- also the fruit punch reminds me of my childhood in Hawaii so go for that too. Portuguese Sausage YUM Spam Musubi OISHI If you eat at the off times then the line's usually short but during peak hours it's really busy and not only is the line big but the wait for a table can be long too. It is a Cash Only restaurant so don't bring your cards here and water is self serve.

xxaYN3fYgbPekigLsSODMg.text: This cash-only restaurant is nestled in the California Hotel, down the block from Vegas' famous tourist attraction, Fremont Street. Parking is a breeze - just use the hotel's self-park. :)   I ordered the Garlic Chicken Combo (comes with macaroni salad and rice), a Coke and a side spam Musubi. Five minutes after our party sat down, we were served! (Probably the shortest time I've had to wait for food in Vegas). The food was BOMB. This beats your typical Hawaiian Chain restaurant any day! And unlike typical Vegas fare from the strip, the cost did not hurt my wallet.  Full and happy? Check. Hidden Vegas gem? Check.  ** Note: This place is not for people who want to go on a diet. They keep the skin on the chicken (both sides) and they smother your dish with gravy (if it comes with gravy).... all I can say is, HELL YES BABY. Just be aware of what you're getting yourself into when it comes to Hawaiian food but other than that indulge yourself in the gravy goodness.   I'm hooked. I want one of these in Los Angeles immediately.  And as my friend Stephen H. would say, "THAT'S THE SITUATION!"

bOJQnxZpf14M_SW18Ji9fw.text: This place is awesome!  There are a few deals to be had in Vegas. This is one of them.  Fine Diners Beware: this is hole in the wall Hawaiian old school. To borrow a phrase from a favorite Oahu joint, this is "eat till you sleep" type food.  Recommended: everything. And get an extra Spam Musubi to go , it's the best $1.75 you will spend in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Thank god for Saimen. Thank god.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aloha Bento plate

fJfktqgtTAzcP_e4Cmm-LQ.text: White meat chicken eaters..stay away! Lol...I'm a dark meat lover...so this spot is definitely for me since all their chicken dishes are made with chicken thighs.  My all time favorite dish here is the Korean chicken..which is similar to bbq chicken but it has a spicy kick.  The prices are very cheap, around $7 for a very large plate of food.  The only dish that seemed to be a little lackluster was the loco moco.  It looked good, but the flavor didn't quite match the look of the dish.  I don't know if I'd venture all the way to Fremont just to eat here, but this place is 2nd on my list of favorite Hawaiian restaurants after Island Flavor.

OtfNfj-J25DC-1qwP1XkzQ.text: damn this place is in a hotel? this spot needs their own location on the strip somewhere and they'll def get good business esp at those prices!   the loco moco i had was really good and it was sooooo much food for $6. i was tempted to get the tuna too but damn that was so much food. def a clean and nice place to grab lunch on a hot day in vegas. keep it up!

2cqpLeOJZeD0WaZ-RJONlA.text: This is a must do. We stopped in for a bite and were completely blown away with the food. Large portions at reasonable prices and totally delicious! Just do it!

_RVn3eCCZ449iLkCktJXZQ.text: I have heard so much about this place that when I finally had the chance to try it out they already had a high expectation to live up to in my book. I would say it was O.K. - I've definitely had better...  I was taliking to someone that told me that when they first moved to Vegas in the mid 1990's this was the only place that you could find Hawaiian Food so that's why this place it still so special to many people and for that reason I can understand the love for this place!! THE FOOD:     Korean Chicken- I hate when places only offer chicken thighs!!! (Chicken Breast is just so much healthier for you) It was O.K. but once you peeled off the skin the rest of the chicken had no taste.      Fried Saimin: This was good!!!      Poke: I was very disappointed with this dish, it was just sooo soaked in soy sauce- Not good at all....    The other dishes had at the table that I did not try was Chop Steak, Mix Plate and Loco Moco- Everyone else seemed to be content with their food. My 6yr old nephew really loved his Loco Moco.  I didn't care for the cash only policy either- very inconvenient if you ask me!!! Anyhow, I do not see myself craving to go back...

3l0cJhSM2_CQIKtRLw-Feg.text: The four stars is for the hamburger steak!  They make a homemade patty, and it rivals the best stuff you would find in Hawaii.  The rest of the menu can be hit or miss, but if you like Hamburger steak, like I do this is the spot!  Don't forget to order a side of kim chee, and one Large fruit punch!  Chee Hooooo!

8rIgkbwHOkLYaryrJ1EIVQ.text: On of my favorite places to eat Hawaiian food!! It on 2nd floor of California Hotel! Korean Chicken is good! Also Aloha Bento, Aloha Breakfast, & a bunch of other ones!! Love eating here when I'm hungry for some grinds!! Opens @ 9am! I'm not to sure about the time it closes but you can call!! ONO GRINDS!! great service!!

oJOtw2SR6TY_JFjvqgGu4g.text: I've only been here once, but if I'm ever back in Vegas, I'm definitely coming back! I actually found this place based on current yelp reviews (thanks guys!) and I wasn't disappointed. The menu is pretty short, but do yourself a favor and order something you haven't heard of. Chances are you won't be disappointed. You're bound to get something tasty in huge portions! Granted it's a "trek" to the Fremont Street district, but this place makes it worth your time.

NznmGNC7wCPLpSfBcSsIEw.text: Tired of the over priced buffets?  Go to Aloha Specialties for Good Hawaiian food at old school vegas prices.  I will always hit this spot more then a few times while in Vegas.

IcdHw1_zGaP5jATYeSnZFw.text: Can't get enough of the good "local" food here. Open early and just late enough to get saimin or whatever plate lunch you crave. Always has great service and terrific prices too.

_R4CWd4VzktnCK2UTK80-A.text: A (decent size) of teriyaki chicken rice bowl for 3 bucks, where else you can get something like that? The price at Aloha definitely falls into the affordable category, and their food is not bad either. I especially love the Kalbi combo, which unfortunately is not available everyday. The saimin noodle soup is not bad. My only complaint is that they put too little charsiu pork/fish cake etc... Even if i order extra charsiu, it's still too little.

r9X7CuHDubHxbgfcVXWvJg.text: I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!  Located on the 2nd floor of the California Hotel and Casino in downtown Vegas, lies this little restaurant.  My fiance and I come to Vegas several times a year, and stopping here at least once during each trip is a MUST!  We come here mainly for the Saimin with the wontons .  So amazing!!!!  They have the best Saimin ever!  Don't even try comparing Aloha Specialties Saimin with L&L as there is no comparison.  We also like ordering the teriyaki plate which has teriyaki chicken, beef and pork with a side of white rice and macaroni salad.  Their macaroni salad is to die for.  Mix their macaroni salad with a little bit of their thick, oh so yummy teriyaki sauce and it's like you have died and gone to heaven.   In addition, they believe in giving you generous portions and have reasonable prices. They have a good sized menu too, with a little something for everyone. Service is always friendly.  The only downside is they take cash only and at times their lines can be long!   And when I say "long" lines, I mean lines that go way out, past the entrance to the restaurant.   To ensure you aren't waiting in line I give this piece of advice.  Go before noon or after 2 pm to avoid the crowds.  Yes, folks, this place is that popular!  When you do decide to make a trip, make sure to wear your stretchy pants.  LOL!  :D

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. long line

XPspyfknURLxczv4O2ZUvg.text: With much hesitation, my friend and I found ourselves at the Aloha Specialties Restaurant at the California Hotel and Casino.  He had tried earnestly to suggest another restaurant, but it appears that everyone else wanted their version of Hawaiian food from this place.  We ordered their special - the Hawaiian special lunch plate of pork lau lau, mac salad, tuna poki, and beef (or tripe) stew.  We also added an order of spam musubi and two drinks.  Total - over $15!  WTF?  Whenever I eat Hawaiian food outside of Hawai'i, I always go for the pork lau lau, so I've had my share of this specialty.  With a little shoyu, I took my first bite of the pork lau lau and looked at my friend.  He took a bite himself and knew exactly what I was thinking.  "This is bad."  It was dry, flavorless, and ultimately, I think it was old.  In all fairness, I dug in deeper, aiming for the center and was equally disappointed.  Moving onto the mac salad, this was a shame too.  Again, tasteless.  There was no flavor whatsoever in this mac salad.  Moving onto the tuna poki.  There was chunks of low grade tuna sitting in a sauce.  It was okay, edible and had more flavor because of the marination.  But nothing to rave about.  Thank goodness for the beef stew and sauce.  The chunks of beef had flavor and we poured all of that over our rice.  The spam musubi could use some serious improvement too.  I think they are using the cheap version of seaweed, or maybe it was old.  I just know that when I get a spam musubi or make it myself, the seaweed is a lot tastier and fresher.    The only good thing this time was the free refill on the drinks!  I still gave this place a two star because everyone else was happy with their order.  Then again, they had a chicken teriyaki bowl and it's really hard to mess that one up.  If you feel the need to be immersed in the Hawaiian theme and surround yourself with Hawaiians and Hawaiian stuff, take a walk on over there.  You'll pass by Lambert's Ice Cream, Ethel M Chocolates, and lots of people in Hawaiian garb.  And you'll probably find a bunch of transplanted Hawaiians hanging out there or visiting.

rK1DP0VmezrKZ-vj69rHgg.text: terrible service.  all five of us genuinely felt that we were being racially discriminated against.  and the food wasn't good either.  dry salmon, flavorless ramen, small portions.  no water refills at all.  check, please?

caFwOYwom6w5M_MEJHd0ig.text: THE BEST HAWAIIAN FOOD I've had on the mainland in comparison to the home-cooking in the rainbow state.  Close enough to the cooking at Rainbow's in Oahu i guess.  Good grubb!!!  My favorite is the shoyu chicken with 2 fried eggs and gravy & the ahi poke by far!  Everything on the menu is delicious and affordable.  Everybody has to know about this place..It's a secret hideout where all the locals hang out.  Good, good food at a very low, low price....JUST LIKE HOME!!  Thanks for the load of food!!!  If you want to get the bang for your buck, this is where you should get your grub on!  Come on an empty stomach though...

SLjL6hblj67c_BmLnSUj3g.text: My trip to Vegas was complete after a $20 cab ride to the Cal. Our mission was to eat some good 'ol comfort food. We ordered a variety of plates: loco moco, fried saimin, teriyaki burger, teriyaki chicken, teriyaki beef, and saimin. I am happy that they make their own patties, not the pre-fabricated frozen patties you get from costco. The loco moco brown gravy has a real gravy taste, nothing a package can get you. The teriyaki sauce is sweet and a good compliment to the salty meats it is poured over. The mac salad is creamy and plentiful, but there's always room for more! Only thing is that I was surprised to see the saimin order did not come with fish cake, one of my husband's favorites in saimin.

Qa7r1RRDjD83SQt07PyjtA.text: good cheap food. not saying much as this is vegas. the land of cheap food and buffets. i mean you can get a prime rib dinner under $10!!!  but if you want some solid local food, just visit this place. nothing fancy or great about, but the food is decent. for some reason everytime i go to vegas, i must come here at least once.   that and the many niketown outlets. which deserves 9 stars.

mrblkvbc1I4NZCIvOxGw_Q.text: First understand that if you're from Hawaii, you probably visit Vegas often and always stay downtown (never on the strip).  This sets the stage for what has become known as the "Ninth Island": the California Hotel (AKA the "Cal") and adjoining Main Street Station (both Boyd hotel/casinos that cater to the Hawaii crowd).  If you've never been to Hawaii before, this is a pretty good cross section of the local community all lovingly united by a constant flow of Bud Light and the chirp of Blazing 7s slot machines.  I'm a Hawaii transplant now living in the Bay Area, so I especially look forward to Vegas trips for the food.   On the mezzanine of the Cal is a small restaurant called Aloha Specialties which IMO has the best local food menu on the mainland.  In CA we're limited to Hawaiian BBQ joints like L&L which pretty much offer the same spectrum of choices.  Aloha Specialties has some of  my favorite dishes:  TRIPE STEW: Pretty good, could use more and bigger chunks of veggies.  Tabasco makes it even better. (4/5) SAIMIN: Not as good as what you get in Hawaii, but far better than the crap they have at places like L&L.  And it's cheap. (4/5) BEEF STEW: Tastes the way I expect it to and don't understand why other places can't make it (see my L&L review). (4/5) POKE: Too sweet.  I also prefer the onion/sesame oil style (2/5)  Like I said, I eat here because I don't get good plate lunches and other local food on the mainland.  One of life's biggest mysteries is why visitors from Hawaii -- fresh off of their red eye flights from the land of Kim Chee II, Rainbow's and Helena's -- will wait in a long line for food they could get back home.  That's Hawaii locals for you.  Gotta love them... I sure do.

uE5ZDWUGg-jjGDAX_IJydw.text: Fun place for a real ethnic experience.  When I walked in, I felt like I had walked off a plane in Honolulu.  It was so warm and inviting with all the Pacific Rim folks.   Great food and cheap cheap cheap.  Such a nice break from the same old boring mostly white casino folks.  Hey, I'm a Haole .... just sayin!  You can get a spam musabi for $1.75!   The raspberry iced tea is wonderful.   Most dishes come with a side of macaroni salad that is delicious! I was there for my Valentine's Lunch and it was definitely memorable in a good way.

KcT85qpZRNtM7f6Hp5O8cw.text: Whenever I go to Vegas I always make sure to stop at the Cal to get me some good Hawaiian food here at this restaurant.   The food is always consistently good, the service is fast, and the prices are cheap.   For the long drive home I make sure to pack a spam musubi to go. If you are a fan of Hawaiian food make sure to stop by and grab a bite to eat

7huUV133Ql6OIpJKT3uTUQ.text: wen stay downtown las vegas, "locals" gotta fo go git grinds at da kine aloha specialties. eva body git guud aloha. da  grinds is ono. no matter wat git: korean chicken, teri plates, bento, and da saimin stay da best from hawaii. ohana style service too. check um out wen yu stay at da cal o vegas club. wat eva's!

zclSRugHvJyhlC5bNjboOQ.text: Great traditional Hawaiian fare. Fantastic low prices! Seriously,  what a deal! Located inside the Californian hotel in downtown.  The staff was very friendly, customers were 95% Hawaiian, it must be a good place.  I will certainly return. Bonus, the casino was actually clean and nice.......in downtown!  Free parking in the garage.

nKSIa-danQi24A6hxFISPA.text: Haven't been her since the new remodel.  The place is much better looking but the lines just don't move as fast as I think it could.  The sofa machine is nice to have if you drink sofa.  Prices are up but the spicy Korean chicken was better today than the last few times I went.  They don't have fried saimen any more.. why?   The wonton saimen was not my favorite the ramen was just too over done for me. The local plate looked yummy yum.  The place is good but not our first stop any more.

cbwfRVuc6Ca3SNTWtk5Ukg.text: Mmmm I LOVED the saimin! I think I ate it 3 times here. It reminded me of Hawaii. :) I added the veggies to it too. The dashi had a lot of flavor and the portion size was huge.   The ochazuke looked delicious too, but very large. Maybe next time...

ldUvT09iM74o18ydfbyM6Q.text: If you're craving a taste of the islands, you cannot go wrong with this place.  It's a casual order at the counter kind of place, so don't expect anything fancy.  It's just big portions of gut busting Hawaiian standards.  I ordered one of the bento combinations and my wife ordered the kalua pig and cabbage plate.  Each were excellent and very budget friendly.

oUhoN_IcqmD6Oy5sDznElQ.text: Great home cooked food from scratch. Super nice people. Great value/pricing compared to all the crap elsewhere. Good variety too. Had the spicy Korean chicken and it was bangin. Will come back for ahi tuna appetizer (seasonal so not always available) and garlic chicken.

j7Iveeji3J8OKNk3JGhZ1g.text: I got the Spicy Korean chicken, but the Local plate and garlic chicken sounded good too. Price to portion ratio is very good, especially for Las Vegas. $10.25 for a large plate and I was full afterwards.  The line is slow because there's only one cash register. Seating is decent, ample self seating.   The chicken was good flavor wise but kind of soggy and oily. The macaroni salad was pretty sweet for some reason. The rice was rice.

eCT90qW5OGiRvbU1jhjeRQ.text: Great service even when they are super busy. AFFORDBLE price and no service fee. Do Accpet credit card. Perfect for people who lose a lot of money at casinos. Big plate for the price. Highly recommended by CL4.   (CL4: casino loser 4)

iFlnBszrQhCco3iJUvZH1Q.text: Good consistent food thru the years! Good portions tasty food. The masubi  needs the spam to be 1/8  inch thicker, than it would be primo! Can't get it here, close by, so please fix it! The price is right! Love eating here, among all the locals from the Islands! Staff , excellent , friendly and professional!

dzZLQsZ74xyXqYy-rIe-yw.text: Went here on our first night. Ordered the Mix Plate and it was a pretty good serving size. Only warning would be not all plates come with rice. Def would come back here on my next trip.

xGgf-wKkIbFS9eCRxp_nbA.text: Kalua pork and cabbage was indeed great.  The chicken and veggie bowls are nice value though too heavy and sweet for me.  An abundance of rice for all entrees. Counter service friendly and restaurant full of Pacific Islanders for guests.  Spam and related items on the menu but I didn't try them. On the SECOND floor of the California Casino.  Very smokey casino which is unfortunate so I probably will not be back.

H-ddV0zzKQhBHd3r6G-sPg.text: Ordered saimin with vegetables.   They charge extra $1.75 for veggies.  Veggies consist of a bit of cabbage and a few sprouts.   Horrible.  Save the money and don't get veggies.   Saimin tasteless.  Tastes like noodles in dirty water.   Only reason they got 3 stars is I've eaten other dishes like Korean chicken that is much better.

cJoZP5b5HRn3rlzFFKoYEg.text: Been going here for 29 years, and their food is still the best Hawaiian food in Las Vegas. Can't say enough good things about their food. Always large portions and great staff.

X4yojDL3FqY_Tnd2W2-DSw.text: Stayed at the California Hotel and found this cute and convenient place! I love Hawaiian food and it's hard to find good Hawaiian food outside Hawaii. They stayed True to Hawaiian flavors and I would definitely go back. They gave us so much food and I could barely finish. Would recommend if in the area and crave well priced and yummy food!

VUcBnVwH85AH-NJrB18kYQ.text: The slowest line I've ever waited in to order. 45 minutes if you're by the door.  After we ordered I sat down and looked at the time as well as the last guy in line....after eating he was only half-way through after thirty minutes.  It's completely unexpected too because the line wasn't long, it was just insanely slow moving.  Stop having the cashier do anything but take the order and money...they shouldn't be grabbing forks, plates, whatever else, just taking orders and money.  This would solve the problem overnight.  It is so frustrating to get in a line with 10-15 people in front of you (some in groups even) and then move so slowly through it.  Of course once you're committed you aren't leaving because then you'd have to leave the hotel and find somewhere else to go, by then you will be almost through the line!  That being said, the food is actually really good and the price is great.  Portions are huge and delicious.  I went with the Aloha Bento Box for around $13.  This came with spicy korean chicken, some mahi mahi, some sort of sausage and some steak.  All meats were delicious.  The rice was really good and the sauce on it was excellent.  If you can manage standing in a slow line it is very much worth it.  This is 4-5 star food, but the line is just too slow to recommend strongly.

nqFYbsiHik6t91XQR7uRug.text: This is a must on my list whenever I'm in Vegas. Where else can you grab an amazing (and huge) bento plate, play some slots, listen to folks talk in Pidgin, and sit next to a WWII veteran from the 100th Infantry Battalion?   The Korean chicken plate, bento plate, and saimin are my favorites here.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bento plate and small bowl of saimin.

AAkxqf_Ym3sdQR1oYwID1Q.text: Yummy! Love this place. Our first stop off the airplane. Teriyaki combo is very fresh, tasteful and tender. Must try

QPqDrL5jC3lsXxqhqQfX-g.text: Kool Hawaiin restaurant in the hotel California.   Place doesn"t appear anything fancy, but food was really good & everyone who worked there was super friendly.  Went for the Loco Moco dish and it was excellent.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

h90lN0wyN5SR00TlozhrRw.text: Went here a couple times while I was in town for a music festival.   Portions are kind of huge but huge because it's chocked full of fillers like rice and carbs.   Coming from a major metro city with tons of Hawaiian, Asian, and fusion flavors of all types and qualities, tiny flavor rating for this spot isn't all that great, but not bad either. Get the job done  If you are eating to get full as fast as possible, which I sometimes am, come here.   If you are looking for flavortown or ambience, which I often am, go elsewhere.

XWRt397GzNMRBFM0mjY7wQ.text: Overall pretty solid, I would recommend a thicker piece of spam in the musubi, I ordered 6 to go and it was 95% rice so that was a bummer. The employees were pleasant and wait time was short. I'll try again next year when I'm in town.  Mahalo nui loa

ND4Hbjauc1W_RulAU_b26g.text: Great place to grab a quick meal! They are always friendly and serve great Hawaiian food. There Mac salad is very good as well as many other things on the menu like the combo plates and noodle dishes. The spam musubi can be passed because there's no egg and nothing special, but all other food I have had has been great. Even if you are just looking for a snack go get a $2 side of Mac salad, it's perfect.

yewRm34JtzhYwg2vCIXSTA.text: The 1 star is only for the service! They have the worst system ever! The cashier rings up and puts together the utensils? She counts the drawer and goes on break with a line to the door?! Not a care in the world! Each person(order) takes like 5min! Just ridiculous

r8lLIM6VU4v-vUB4Wq1Q8A.text: This place, not unlike the California itself, is Hawaiian mecca.  Our neighbor who lived there goes there for her Korean chicken fix.  My brother comes here at least once on every visit for saimin and spam musubi.  The stuff we were raised on, the stuff of legends.  Not to mention the food of champions.  We can outwatch TV and switch channels faster than anybody.    I don't think I've had anything other than the saimin since a good bowl outside the Islands is so hard to find.  Great al dente noodles, tasty bits of egg, green onion, kamaboko and char shiu.  Broth not as good as Shiro's but what broth is?  Get it with veggies and, if you're hungry, with won ton.  The large size will feed two people!    And don't forget about the tasty shortbread cookies they sell at the counter.  Cookies baked in Hawaii taste like no other.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A &#34;small&#34; saimin with veggies
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Teri Burger

PzAXaMXRmB6TZ6WVTQ5vUg.text: OMG, tasty Hawaiian  local food with portions fit for a family! Tasty chicken teriyaki, sis had the large won ton saimin (fed our entire party of 7), bro had the Local plate lunch of two types of Teri, rice, mac salad, pickles, other sis has the Kalua pig/ came mixed in cabbage (ok), other sis has the spam musubi, she liked!  We rolled outta there and hit the black jack tables to burn off them calories.....oh, and there's a Lappart's Hawaiian ice cream shop next door for awesome ice cream ----dang it, off to the gym to burn off those 1000 lushious calories!

Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin noodles
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hawaiian special

-Lz2vTVOG_2bDCBk5CdKsg.text: Been coming here since 1985 and still has the best tasting teriyaki bowl in town. Big portion for 4$ dont forget to get Lapperts ice cream across the hall... best coconut pineapple ice cream in town!

bCg0BznRX476pDvfYIwEJA.text: a place for local food from hawaii. plenty of locals here from hawaii and they still come and pack the place.  having the local moco for the first time here in vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wY8kwITz9-IFlO9C5wmKdA.text: Highly recommended by friends, it was an easy choice for lunch. With our arrival just after 11:30, we anticipated a long line. Much to our surprise, there was practically no wait at all. Even more surprising was the fact they only accept cash. What? This is Vegas. I got the Korean Chicken complete with rice and macaroni salad. I was in culinary heaven until my buddy, who ordered the same thing, found a very lengthy hair in his mac. The staff was apologetic and handled it well. Kind of put a damper on an otherwise pleasant experience though. Heads up if you use the parking garage. You must pay first and then validate at the casino cage. Make sure you have a receipt. No exceptions. The food was good enough to warrant a return (hopefully hairless) trip.

SeEzkAiZeqIR74YddP25RA.text: Haven't been here in years ever since we''ve been staying on the main part of the strip for all that glitz, glam, tourists and crowds. But occasionally we like the quiet local joints in this part of the city. Nice change of pace!   No nonsense Hawaiian joint. Good food, great service with great prices. Stop by after you check out the Fremont Experience can't go wrong. But bring cash as they do not take cards.

AUZQwFyL8LRZeeKxtfyXpg.text: Simply the best in Vegas for local food. Saimin and Teri beef is my favorite. I also enjoy the Mahi plate. The staff is also always friendly! Take note that they only take cash.  *update* they now take credit cards, and the place has been renovated.

ovg9qK0IBkesxSLWbXckqQ.text: We were very disappointed after our lunch today. We come to this restaurant everytime we visit Las Vegas, which is almost every month. The reason for our disappointment is that they changed the saimin noodles. They have a weird texture. We will not be returning to this restaurant again unless the saimin noodles are changed back. *The one star rating is for the saimin noodles only. Service is great*  *UPDATE* They have since changed the noodles back to the original :) Very ono!

7qEIXGkjT53YrbwcNocCbA.text: I'm usually not a fan of teriyaki sauce but this one was really good. Cheap price with large portions. I recommend it if you're on a budget

UCwjEFFebZuqTEv5TWzgMw.text: This is the first place I ever tried Hawaiian food. It was summer 1997. I worked at Circus Circus. My friends kept talking about this restaurant until I finally got to try it for myself. There was always a long line. And for good reason.  Fast forward to 2011. Hawaiian food can be had pretty much everywhere in the valley. But I'll always have a special place in my stomach for Aloha Specialties. I'm not sure if it's the absolute best in town, but they get the nostalgia star bump.  Rest assured. I'm not reviewing based on memory from a decade ago. I went back to Aloha Specialties about a week ago. I scanned the menu board and quickly decided on the tripe stew. I do love me some tripe stew, or pretty much tripe anything.  I was supremely happy when it came out and lived up to expectations. It confirmed that Aloha Specialties still ranks up there with the best in town. The stew was solidly on par with my other favorite place, Ross J's Aloha Grill. It makes sense because people keep telling me there's some sort of connection there.  One thing that strangely impressed me was the mac salad. I've gotten to a point where I don't eat the mac salad at most Hawaiian places or I'll substitute it for more rice (something that Ohana Hawaiian BBQ offers). The mac salad at Aloha Specialties was actually quite good--just the right balance of mayo and other ingredients.  Great. Now I'm hungry.

dVFt8P4Hdk7-GmuT-CSRnQ.text: It was the Friday night during LVI and we had just come back to the Cal and the Main Street Station when we were looking for some late dinner grub. One look at the Main Street buffet line was enough to convince us to go up the escalator to the Cal and look for some Hawaiian comfort food at Aloha Specialties... The best thing about this place is that you get some pretty authentic island comfort food, a large portion, for a very reasonable price... You get in line, order, pay, and then they bring everything out to you. Although they don't have traditional sit down waiter/waitress service, our waitress who brought out our order was kind enough to bring out another can of Hawaiian Sun and another Spam Musubi, calculate the charges and collect directly from us at the table... They were pretty busy and had already run out of the large Saimin so wifey ordered a small. yelp.com/biz_photos/wpnL... My son had the Kalua Pig and Cabbage yelp.com/biz_photos/wpnL..., and I had my usual comfort food specialty, the Loco Moco. yelp.com/biz_photos/wpnL... Thinking that that wasn't enough, we wound up ordering two rounds of Spam Musubi... yelp.com/biz_photos/wpnL... Mom and pop comfort food at a reasonable price; one of our go to places for Hawaiian food in LV...

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 090911:  Kalua Pig and Cabbage...
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 090911:  Small Saimin...
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. 090911:  Spam Musubi...

J44mknI8xk2u7N4Jy3F3GA.text: A hidden gem inside the California Hotel. I've been coming here for years, even before I became a Vegas local. And being a local, I prefer DTLV to the strip. Don't expect white linens or pretentious food. This place is all about that good stick-to-your-ribs kinda food. Definitely comfort food to the max (probably good for hangovers) Good prices and large portions, what more could you ask for? The plates they use to serve the food are the biggest plates I've ever seen, haha! I wasn't able to finish my meal so I boxed up the left overs. I went during a weekday afternoon. No line whatsoever, so that was a plus. We ordered the SAIMIN, KOREAN CHICKEN and BEEF STEW. I wasn't a fan of the SAIMIN. A bit too fishy for my taste. The KOREAN CHICKEN was very tasty, a bit on the sweet side. The BEEF STEW was awesome! I highly recommend that. I got a side of green onions too which really made the dish. In hindsight I should've asked for a fried egg on top. Perhaps next visit. Side note if you have time or room for dessert, Lappert's is right next door. You'll find all the flavors you'd expect from an IceCream shop based in Hawaii. So Ono!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean chicken over rice &amp; macaroni salad.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef stew over rice, delish!!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin. Not my favorite

IhvhqrCMLzT7_GWnX-wArQ.text: Always a tradition to go here when in Vegas with the fam.  Likes: -Cheap food.  -Pretty good Hawaiian food. I've had their saiman, Portuguese sausage with eggs and rice, and spam musubis. -Big portions. -Service is fast. -Casual, take-out place.  Dislikes:  -Cash only. -They bring you the food, but everything else is self-serve, such as getting cups f water and utensils.  Recommend: Yes! Good place to stop by before leaving Vegas...pick up some spam musubis for the road!

9OBD__BamX5-b3__OlGJqg.text: The funniest thing...we left Hawaii to go to Vegas, but still found a way to eat local grinds. The food was simply delicious here! Better than a lot of places in Hawaii...hands down!   *Korean Beef and Korean Chicken Combo ~ Bombtastic! Ask for side korean sauce. A little sweet, a little spicy, but a perfect complement to your meal. Kim chee and mac salad was onolicious!  *Ahi Poke ~ fresh, cold, tasty! Even comes with ogo, too! Loved it!  *Loco Moco ~ onos!  On our last day in Vegas, we hit up Aloha Specialties again. The line was crazy long (20 deep). I decided to google their phone number and made a take out order while standing in line. Our take out was done within 15 minutes. We got to enjoy our food while people were still waiting in line.   *TIP* Order take out if the line is too long :)

TWMxAMxd2jdtB2yBdj3oGQ.text: "I would like one of EVERYHTHING on the menu..." Picked up some boiled peanuts and spam musubi for the drive back to LA. Wish I could take the place with me! A definite comfort-food type of place that always hits the spot. Can get crowed at peak hours but don't let that deter you. Check out the daily specials/combos....and the ochazuke set!

9bgEUOqx5tM123oh-6REig.text: Oh man, I'd come here again in a heart beat! This is the cheapest and best Hawaiian food in Vegas! Aloha is located on the 2nd floor of the California Hotel down near Fremont Street. We got here just before noon and didn't have to wait in too long of a line to order. This place is CASH ONLY and no coupons are accepted.  The menu has plenty to choose from...combo plates, saimen, spamusubi, loco moco, breakfast, etc. We ordered a large saimen and the teriyaki combo plate with mac/rice. The saimen was good....lots of noodles and tasty broth. The combo plate was yummy also, a variety of chicken/pork/beef with tons of rice and some good mac salad on the side. Portions are large and hey, even if you're still hungry it'll roughly cost you maybe $5 more to order some more!  This is an order at the counter then seat yourself place- the staff here was nice though and food came out fast. Would definitely recommend and return again!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Teriyaki combo plate and large saimen

Ax25ZLrevWWoHab5diN2Dw.text: I always make sure a trip to Vegas includes going downtown so I could walk down memory lane and eat some Hawaiian comfort food.  Aloha Specialties is no fine dining, but I always come back.  I've had the occasional loco moco and poki, but I always order the won ton saimin with veggies.  Having a little container of hot yellow mustard reminds me of childhood eating.  Note to self-get a small.  I ordered a large and had way too many noodles. Oh-traveling tip for you.  Go to Aloha Specialties right before you head to the airport to go home.  Get yourself a few Spam musabi to snack on while you wait at the airport.

Po9iW4zqhoPMGaTs79jiQw.text: When I need to get my Hawaiian fix Aloha specialties is where I go. I love love love their saimen bowl with vegetables and wontons. But, I must admit I have a secret crush on their spam musubi. It is served warm and just brings delight and joy to my heart with every bite.

_SsaaJnKJRzP9Yf9JN7Bsw.text: They forgot my fucking food... And they weren't even busy, how the hell you forget to make someone's order when it's empty....

eZlC1qaIDRRcgVB8s3nbSQ.text: Hidden gem, in what could be considered a very sketchy area for good food - felt like I was eating in Maui with the locals.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

eNLhS_brLddBHy129EfYdg.text: Basic, simple, delicious.  I'm so happy that they updated everything in here.  Now there's more seating available and their layout is much better.  If you don't expect some sort of gourmet meal, this place is the best home style Hawaiian food that you can get.  On par with or even beyond on the island.  They don't over complicate things by adding non traditional seasonings to try to change flavors.  What you order is what you get and that's what I love the most about this place.  Nothing is unique, but executed perfectly.  There's nothing much that I can say about the food because you get exactly what you pay for.   You want spam, eggs, and rice?  You're going to get exactly that.   Moco loco?  Exactly how you would expect it.  Will it blow your socks off?  No.  It's basic food, but made correctly.  That's why people eat here.    They don't serve you so that you can say something like, "the acid from the pickle cuts through the heaviness of the...." blah blah blah.  They serve you food from home, made with love.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The spread.  Ocha Zuke, Moco Loco, Spam &amp; Egg Sandwich, Spam Musubi

cm19bp8a554yqH4_nAkuhQ.text: I must admit I was a bit skeptical going to an "authentic Hawaiian place" in a casino, but now I take it back. We had a large Family reunion group meet for dinner at Aloha Specialties (all 28 of us) and though the place was small, the staff were very accommodating and the food was really good. Portions were good and flavors were spot on. Prices were fair and service was very good to us. The California Hotel really knows how to cater to us Islanders who miss Hawaii, Aloha

MbnfuUb_1PBdXjOYhDNRuw.text: This place is hawaii away from Hawaii.  So ONOlicious!!! Spam musubi is dakine.  Saimin is on point.  And if your lucky enough, the tuna poke is da best!

imvEhHc-sir7JmD5noB8UA.text: Cute little place. Very busy when we went. In the California Casino. Decent prices. Fairly big portions. The macaroni salad was so-so. The Chicken dish was nicely flavored. Overall, okay.

CM4DdzTtWFWBjkEal8wzSw.text: Had the breakfast plate, rice, spam and egg.  Exactly what I expected but don't think I'll return.

Zh3YpigKFjAvojp75J6xgw.text: Came here for the first time 16 years ago for Sadie's and MY LIFE HAS NEVER BEEN THE SAME. Never had Hawaiian good before. Ive tried much of the menu but I still default to the Chicken bowl with Mac salad (absolute best anywhere I've still not found better) and extra teriyaki sauce. Very good Korean chicken too.  Only complaint is they do not accept cards. Unless that has changed recently.

a-KFgP_3XUq7knCJXRM7Sw.text: Seriously regret not coming here sooner. After several recommendations from friends, and customers of my company, I made the trek. I'm lucky that I had an hour lunch, as it is about a 10-15 minute walk from my job. Situated on the 2nd floor of the California Hotel, the restaurant is across fron Lappert's Ice Cream shop. The restaurant is small but can accomodate some larger groups and has a small patio-like eating area outside its doors. The menu ranges from classic teriyaki bowls and mixed plates to some Hawaiian-inspired items like the burgers. On this occassion I ordered the Teriyaki Chicken bowl and I side of mac salad. I ordered my food to-go and walked back to work.   The food does speak for itself, the chicken had a fried chicken-like crust on it which gave it a texture and held more of the teriyaki sauce to it. The portion for a bowl was larger than I expected. I got through half and felt my tummy hit it's limit and passed my remaining food to a co-worker. The mac salad was good, I tend to mix all Hawaiian Mac Salads with the teriyaki sauce though, so I can't say more than that.   The staff is friendly and has smiles on their faces, it made the place seem lighter. I will definitely cone back as I would like to try tjeir Garlic Chicken and Spam Masubi next.

SmTM-Achz0nrpKZDDHlqMQ.text: This restaurant is located inside the California hotel in downtown Las Vegas.  The whole hotel has a very Hawaiian feel to it.  This restaurant is very casual dining.  You order at the register and the food is delivered to your table.  The portions are huge!    I had the Loco Moco and it was delicious!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Bento
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

QQWwgpon5knRoFoqvDScHg.text: I visited in April 2017. I was a little hungover (it's Vegas) and needed something to bring me back to life. We came in for lunch. I was with my sisters and Dad. My youngest sister didn't order.  I ordered the Saimin and a Spam Musubi.  My sister, the Loco Moco.  My dad, the Burger and fries.  It was super inexpensive and the portions sizes are large.  The soup is piping hot, so be careful. It's a light broth that settled my tummy in no time. Unfortunately, I was unable to finish my soup, even with my sisters help. My sister couldn't finish her Loco Moco either, the ice cream shop across the hallway was a big part of that too.

LLYoDZYoovaZUAeoQWYq9g.text: Stopped in for the kalua pig and cabbage. Everything about the meal was PERFECT. Great traditional Hawaiian menu. You will not be disappointed

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

wnBzr0Dou68jVqNz7hUvEw.text: After reading the glowing reviews, I was excited to try out Aloha Specialties. However, I found the food to be just okay.   Came during peak lunch hours on a Saturday and was expecting to wait awhile to order. I was pleasantly surprised to only find a short line, which moved rather quickly. After placing our order, we were given a number and easily found a table.  My teriyaki combo came with steak, chicken, pork loin, and side orders of macaroni salad and rice. Out of the three meats, I enjoyed the steak the most. However, even the steak was just okay. All meats didn't have a lot of flavor to them. They were each drenched in teriyaki sauce, which I wasn't exactly a fan of. However, the sauce definitely gave all three meats some much needed flavor. If you are a fan of rice, this combo had a lot of it. I found the macaroni salad to be just okay as well. I did like how the mayo wasn't overpowering.  I also had the chance to try the kalua pig and cabbage dish, as well as the spam musubi. The kalua pig was definitely much better than my teriyaki combo. It had a nice smoky flavor to it and was tender and juicy. The amount of pig that came with the dish was rather generous as well. The spam musubi was good, but nothing memorable.  Overall I found Aloha Specialties to be just okay. This restaurant might curb your Hawaiian cravings, but for me, it just didn't do the trick.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Teriyaki plate
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spam masubi
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mix plate

cJK1tIZxU3Oaetq7pVK2Fw.text: I'm so happy this place is still open!!!! I remember coming here as a kid back in the early 90's. They recently upgraded the restaurant and it looks wayyyyyyyyyyyyyyy better. This is one of my top places in Las Vegas for Hawaiian food. They never disappoint me! The menu is full of yummy food and the staff is always welcoming/friendly.   Be patient, sometimes the lines are long but you know what they say "long lines mean it's worth waiting for" Just start off a conversation with anyone cause everyone is really friendly since majority of the people there are visiting from Hawaii or use to live in Hawaii.   My favorite thing to order is the tripe stew! OMG!!!!!!!!!!!!! It is to die for! It soooooooooooo freakin yummy! To top it off, it comes with mac salad and I always have to get a side order of kimchee.   Price is reasonable!   Enjoy and be sure to thank me later :)

qRMa8M7xwCtwLq_XxKXKig.text: Honestly, this was the first Hawaiian food place I've been to outside of Hawaii and I was not impressed. We ordered a saimin, a kim chee saimin, an aloha bento, a loco moco and a spam musubi. The kim chee saimin was better than the regular saimin, but neither were great in their taste. The regular saimin was super fishy. The loco moco and spam musubi were average. The aloha bento had really good steak and chicken sauce. However, the fish was terrible and the hot dog straight up looked scary. It looked so artificial that I lost my appetite just looking at it. Overall, the servers are nice but the food really isn't great.

tnSNAuB-mhjL8sscHBTi5w.text: I came here because I wanted to try their bento. I don't mind waiting but I waited for almost 30 minutes for my food to come out. The waiter said it was "coming" but waited another 10 minutes for it. Honestly, I should've just ordered a spam musubi.

sEARqyaJxaTc9o9lkKIN4Q.text: Very good for a Hawaii-style restaurant in Vegas! The chicken bowl was HUGE and the chicken had this yummy grilled flavor. The beef stew was delicious, had soft meat and was so on point!! I felt transported back to Honolulu!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mac salad
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef Stew
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Bowl

sC5B5VmV0pL0Aj5NcvjdqQ.text: After the remodel the place looks great!  Unfortunately a bit of a downgrade for me.  The other changes just happen to take it down a notch.    With the new layout the lines seem to take forever now when waiting to order your food.  Never used to take use more than 20 minutes or so to get to the front of the line.  This time around it took 30 minutes!  Perhaps it was because the place just recently reopened.  Finally after ordering we got a nice booth/table combo with new furniture.  It was busy so it took another 20 minutes for food to arrive to our table.  Is it just me or did the food get changed up a bit??  My usual order of a teri chicken bowl with mixed veggies and extra teri sauce on the side was NOT the same.  HUGE mound of rice, barely any chicken!!  Like literally a thigh and a half worth of meat.  Used to be at least 2 good size thighs.  Thankfully the teri sauce didn't change, still tasty.  And what, no more LARGE saimin?  It's all one size bowl now?  Luckily it was their large bowls.  But guess what?  The portion is now cut!  We ALWAYS order a large saimin to share at the table for the 3 of us and we always have some leftover to take home.  But no longer!  We finished the saimin easily.  It for some reason didn't taste the same either, broth was light on flavor.  Overall the saimin was light on garnishes as well.  The teri burger and the macaroni salad were still the same however.  I like the teriyaki flavor with the flat top grilled patty.    Other pet peeve with this new upgrade?  The prices!  I know they creeped up over the years but now it is obvious that just about everything on the menu shot up in price.  One entree is nearly equivalent to going over to Main Street Station's buffet for dinner.  Not sure if it's worth it because those entrees that were coming out of the kitchen were chock FULL of rice.  I love rice, but I need something to eat with it!  Expect to spend more now on your next visit to Aloha Specialties.  Biggest problem with me?  This was a bit back around a couple weeks after their re-grand opening but...did no one notice the big 'C' grade from the food inspector posted on the wall??  I mean, it is not is shut down territory but definitely there are some sanitary issues.  I couldn't stop thinking about it.  And after the wifey & kid didn't like the food this time because it's changed, we haven't been back since.  For the money we often end up somewhere else.    Sorry Aloha Specialties, but where has the classic magic gone??  Please bring it back!!  #toomuchrice

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

_flln7unm83aAPSpTe0IPw.text: WOW! Big portions!!! I easily shared a plate with my mother. They give you so much rice! We had rice leftover for every dish. You order your food and pay before hand and the waiter will bring your order to your table.   Mix plate - their chicken was crispy, teriyaki beef was sweet, fish was a bit bland, and the Mac and cheese cold slaw was alright. I like this one; you get to try a bit of everything. Loco moco - lots of rice with omelet and a patty drenched in gravy. My brother was a fan!  3 eggs breakfast - one large egg with rice. For some reason I pictured three mini eggs but they mixed it into one large one. It was nice and fluffy.   Overall I wish I wasn't just visiting, I'd like to try more items on the menu. I never tried Hawaiian food before and this place made a great first impression.   Side note- You can park at the hotel for free if you dine in and spend a minimum of $10.

SZIs8NkoGOF1qWvvUIdyAQ.text: 2016 Yelp 100 Review Challenge -     54/100  I've been a fan of this place for 20+ years. Before I moved here from Hawai'i, every time we visited Vegas, we always made our way to The Cal and ate at Aloha Specialties. In the past few months, we have been eating here every week and it doesn't disappoint. Food is still the same as it was years ago. The renovations are modern and nice. It feels more spacious.   Lately, they seem to have more on staff to keep the line moving. There's still a line and maybe a 10 minute wait at most since this is the most popular Hawai'ian spot in Downtown. But the line moves fast. Now, there's 1-2 cashiers and 2 waitresses, for Saturday afternoons.   They're the sister restaurant of Ross J's in Henderson. One star off for this location. They have the same food but the only thing that doesn't make sense is I can't order the Korean Chicken as a side. I don't eat white rice or mac salad anymore because of my diabetes so it would be pointless to get the plate. Ross J's offers it as a side. If the owners read this I hope they'll consider adding it as a side order. We come here more often anyways because there's more activities to do in the area.   I've tried almost everything on the menu, all are onoliscious (delicious.) What I usually get is Korean chicken, Kim Chee, steamed broccoli and haupia. All are onoliscious. Haupia is made fresh, one time it had a good amount of sweetness, the next week it wasn't as sweet.   Other great options: The Bentos, Sweet & Sour Spare Ribs, huge bowls of Saimin, breakfast plates, Spam musubi, Loco Moco, Kalua Pig and sandwiches. Everything is tasty.   When at The Cal I prefer this place over the cafe on the first floor. Will be back again and again!  TIP: They also sell shortbread and cookies at the cash register. Depending on the wait time, it's worth getting a package to hold you over ;-)  Aloha! :-)

Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Teriyaki Steak plate

VbP_o_hSkM6lVtC7b2Akhw.text: Under cooked chicken, food poisoning. Do not recommend.  Danger. I will not be eating here again. Thank you

jbge-lu6qmVN4Koq9gkucg.text: Always ono! Sometimes the wait can be long. But the wait just builds the anticipation. Never a disappointment and always reminds me of being back on the islands. The only trouble I ever experience is, What should I order now? Too many favorites to select from. From Saimin to Loco Moco and my go to Mahi Mahi sandwich, always hits the spot! Give them a try!!!

ClcEnu-2ia8W5xI8Bl1WVA.text: The restaurant is conveniently located in the California Hotel and Casino in the second floor. Although it's located in a casino, it looks and feels like a local hole in the wall. I ordered the bento plate, tofu and coconut pudding. The portions were huge and it's served on a mountain of rice. The food is thoroughly satisfying. I recommend this restaurant if you're near Fremont Street and want some real, home cooked food.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aloha Bento

6IOahWvljoiB6IXizddLEg.text: It's a Universal truth that the first first thing to do after checking into your downtown Hotel is to head straight to Aloha Specialties.  Nothing kicks off Vegas like a Loco Moco. It sets the tone for the whole trip. You never want to get into Vegas and start drinking on an empty stomach. This is the perfect place to eat to put some rice and some delicious meats in you.

YqeNM8Fu_aRXZXtvWRWOEg.text: Good, considerable food at incredible prices - especially for Vegas. The wait is worth it, asnd it's not totally fancy, but it gets the job done.

-BC0hXYLsCRn-URMq4xrsA.text: My family and I have been eating at Aloha Specialties over 30 years, and it's because they have the best Aloha dishes outside of Hawaii. Like the new upgraded ambience and still affordable consistent prices.

7ZobjtvIbbzsIbXzPh4o2w.text: It saddens me that I have to write this negative review, as I have been a fan for many years. Not sure if it has anything to do with the recent remodel, but the agonizingly slow service is something never experienced at this restaurant prior to the upgrade. Service here makes the DMV seem fast. Staff is unapologetic about the appalling wait and service time. People actually clapped when they received their food. After standing in the line for an hour to place the order, it took another hour to receive the meal. The food is fine and is cheap, but if you see a line, be prepared for an unnecessary two hour experience.

OLi6Ah-lwEq5VeHY_gpYyA.text: After a 10 hour drive from SF to Vegas, we were anxious to fill our growling tummies. After hearing about the best Hawaiian food at the California Hotel and seeing the pictures of delicious poke on Yelp, we were sold. We didn't have to return our rental car for a few hours, so we quickly drove 20 minutes off the strip to Aloha Specialties Restaurant.   What a disappointment! First of all, we were told that they haven't served poke in about a year. Talk about False advertisement! If you're looking to order poke, look elsewhere. They don't have it here.   Fine, everything else on the menu looked appetizing enough that we could probably still be satisfied sans poke right? Wrong! When we got our meals, no one left satisfied. I wouldn't suggest wasting gas, cab money or calories here at all.

vRzqy2UQ-5MpPD_qB5499g.text: Soon as you get near the restaurant, you'll see a gathering of people visiting from Hawaii. If you too are from the 808, you'll recognize a variety of menu items that are common in the islands. If you're not from the 808, some of the items may seem unfamiliar. It's comfort food from Hawaii.  The prices are reasonable. Mostly under $10, comparable to the prices in Hawaii, sometimes even less.  Ono grinds. Good Hi food. saimin, beef stew, musubi, teri beef, chicken, all the usual. If you've never been to Hawaii, this is a good introduction/representation.  Serio, it's not a slice of pineapple on a burger to make it Hawaiian, that's not how it works.  Food is consistent in taste, quality, and presentation.

O0wuejRC5JpQ_7q7YfUe3w.text: Definitely no Aloha on the service.  The cashier was very rude and told her mom to help "her" (using the third person referring to me) all because I missed the sign "wait to be called".  I ordered a musubi and it was less than mediocre.  Not worth the wait of "made to order" and certainly not worth going back to very rude and bad service

pyT3E2OsxBILs5WC-dphFg.text: Disappointed in this place. The menu looked delicious, but when the food came out it was average at best. We ordered a variety of items, the aloha bento, teriyaki chicken bowl, spam musubi, saimin, and kimchee. Don't waste your money on the musubi. It was awful. Everything else was just average. The kimchee was extremely sour and tasted horrible. I was really looking forward to getting some good local food, but came out disappointed.

5YN54M_tlL0S94bW7AXuzA.text: First time at the restaurant, and it was great. The portion size for the noodles in their bowls compared to the prices was amazing. The Selection of foods had a nice variety. The customer service was good & very kind. I will be sure to recommend & come back to try the other foods.

QQR_KLOuExcJ7F8pNOIyUw.text: I love the Aloha Bento! Giant portions and it has everything Mahi Mahi, Redondos Hot Dog, Teri Beef, Korean Chicken and Furikake Rice. Better than most Hawaiian places in LA and very nostalgic for me, I've been staying at the Cal since I was a kid. I always eat here when I'm in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. the bugga ono! haha

U_cmHtadaxwcmW8mhBg2hA.text: This isn't near the Strip, but it is extremely worth the trek (it's near Old Vegas (Fremont) so you can explore there as well). Delicious authentic Hawaiian food and, surprise surprise, the portions are quite large. Definitely try it out and make a day of it in Old Vegas and the Mob Museum!

HjD6IE16oPxREgLczgIwuA.text: Great Prices, Huge portions and just a great atmosphere it is very "Homey"

uQpznBvqouBcMX7E0n1IkA.text: The longest wait ever!!!  My husband stood in line for over 30 minutes, which is normal for dinner.  Unfortunately, we also waited over 30 minutes for a Teri Beef Sandwich, Sweet Sour Spareribs and a Chicken Bowl.  Adding to the long wait was a constant loud pounding from the kitchen that went on forever.  I could barely think much less enjoy my meal.  This was one of my favorite places but I'm not sure if I would return after tonight's experience.

khzmv6r9YKij2pzIg2Q9Mw.text: No wonder then Hawaiians are always smiling, because they always eating good!! A perfect home cooked meal inside a casino!

BEZggLpWCQy0qttH9cIR8g.text: I love this place! I've been coming here since they started the first restaurant in Henderson! The staff is always so pleasant & the food is so good! Prices are reasonable & I'm glad they opened a location downtown to cater to the Island Tourist!

beCNOG26uwVpkGCaqDOBoQ.text: The newly remodeled with more seating and modern design same great menu. Order the teriyaki beef bowl with mushrooms and onions. Very good.
