I wasn't that hungry when I left the hotel, but after sitting through bumper to bumper traffic on the 15, just to get to downtown LV, I was ready to eat. Ugh, I hate traffic no matter where it is.  Walking through the California Hotel and finally by the entrance for the restaurant, it immediately looked familiar. I had walked by before, just never tried their food. Everything on their menu board just looked so good, we wished we could try it all. But the wife and I finally settled on the Aloha Saimin.  The food arrived quickly, and my eyes widened at how large the bowls were. The Aloha Saimin came with just about everything but the kitchen sink, it had cha siu, spam, wontons, and some other stuff Honestly, I had never heard of the term "saimin" before this, but after looking it up, I thought it was cool that it originated from Chinese words. Hawaii really is just one big melting pot of Asian cultures.  There was something about the texture of the noodles, which resemble ramen noodles. I liked the chewiness, bite, and flavor, not overcooked or soggy at all. Either way, I just couldn't stop eating. I only wish they had a bottle of Siracha or any real good hot sauce, instead of that weak mustard sauce. Inexpensive, friendly service, and tasty comfort food. All perfect components for repeat visits.

kQGMEIo-9cdzjEkgZ3iN1g.text: I'm a particularly strange gal.  For me, no trip to Vegas is complete without a meal stop at the California Hotel.  Specifically, no trip to Vegas is complete without my Hawaiian food fix.  This trip was no different.  Sure, I could have had the Loco Moco downstairs at Market Street, but... I was in the mood for full-on Hawaiian.  Large saimin with veggies and wontons?  Check. Loco Moco plate?  Check. Spam musubis?  Check.  Ahhh.  Talk about an awesome lunch.  I don't understand why people would shell out tons of dough on whatevers food at the Strip when Aloha Specialties is just a five minute drive away.  Save yourself a bundle and check out this joint.  It's ghetto, but definitely hits the spot.  Then you can go to Lappert's for ice cream afterwards!  Yippee!!

-9mGC5YmATGlSolsssBm-w.text: Walk into the California Casino and you can't help but notice that they brought over a little bit of Hawaii over to the mainland.  Aloha Specialties is a must go if you come here while in Vegas.  Great local comfort food for less than 10 bucks!  I've been here on my last two trips to Vegas and I have every intention of always going back for future road trips.    Siamin - Great flavor and the noodles are the perfect texture.  Perfect for anytime of the day and in any state, sober, buzzed, drunk, hungover...you get the point  Kaluha Pork - Juicy, tendered, and perfectly seasoned.  This is one of my all time favorite dishes and it is legit here.  Korean Spicy Chicken - Super tasty and delicious!  Not exactly your typical local Hawaiian dish but totally worth a buy  Spam Musubi - Get these not matter how much food you order or even if you think you are too full because they make the best late night eat or quick bite between casino hopping.  If you don't know what this is, it is a yummy fried piece of Spam with a sweet glaze wrapped in rice and Nori (seaweed).    If you venture to this part of Vegas eat here!

fNt4OYhkl-zdNyJy9uApzQ.text: My family ALWAYS comes to this restaurant... There's a reason why it's crowded!! The line was out the door and the wait about an hour long. I got the 2 eggs with rice and Portuguese sausage (so good, my mom was surprised with the amount of food I ate... And they aren't stingy with their food!!). The spam was extremely salty (this is from a girl who LOVES her salt) but my mom seemed to like it :) the rest of my family got Siamin noodles (sp?) keep in mind that the large is HUGE. I have no idea how my brother ate that... The macaroni salad is a must in Hawaiian cuisine and the kimchi tasted like kimchi (which was to be expected). My only issue is with the seating. It would be so much more organized if they had someone seating people! However I can't really complain as we were able to find a seat pretty easily (which was EXTREMELY surprising given the amount of people there!)

VOHaiDOPZzTZsJKue0Mmog.text: This a great food and excellent comfort food for anyone from Hawaii.  Now I understand that the non-Hawaii people might not give this a 5 star rating but then again how many non-Hawaii people are hanging at the Cal?  I was hungry when I stopped by with the fam for dinner after hitting the floor at the Cal an working up an appetite.  The fried saimen is so good.  Noodle are tender but with enough tooth to them to be respectable.  No pasty or gummy fare here.  Toppings are fresh and flavorful with bright green onions with just a little tang to them.  Bean sprouts are crisp and milky white with a fresh taste.  I also had a cheeseburger in the same sitting (I was hungry and from Hawaii).  The patty was moderate in size, not thin and not gluttonously large.  It was hand made and contained fresh juicy beef that had that homemade flavor that no process patty can compete with.  Lettuce, onion, and tomato were firm, fresh, and juicy.  FYI you can get a side of kim cheese and toss it in the burger for a wonderful kim chee cheeseburger, not for the faint of heart or heart burn prone.  Overall the food is well made, portions are good, and the service is fast and friendly.  Beyond the food the friendly staff reminds me of home and that makes a meal at Aloha Specialities all the more special.

TvcbqWh8aa9OUZjU-EKndg.text: The only thing I have ordered here is the burger. BUT, my friend did have the bento and I tried it.   The burger here is one of the best I've had. My cousins told me to try it out and I was not disappointed.  The patty is hand-formed, thick, and juicy. They place the lettuce and tomato on the side in case you don't want it or if your buddy wants to double up on his/her veggies. They'll ask you if you want mayo or not (they also place it on the side for you).  I realize not everyone goes to a hawaiian restaurant will order this here, but from what I tried from my friend's bento box, the quality and flavor is better than any hawaiian restaurant that I've been to. Only thing that's better, in my opinion, are family potlucks/get-togethers.  Anyway, the pricing is fair given the amount of food you get. Quick tip though: they don't accept credit/debit cards - cash only.

CcAfuVts4huQzuQnB7U3Ow.text: This place gives either huge or a lot of food. So worth the bucks and the wait in line. What most people say, "where the cops are, you know its good food". Well, surely this place is where they go. My bf introduced me to this place and said it's the only place he knows of NOW that serves  teriyaki chicken with the skin on it. The fat on the skin is what makes teriyaki chicken sooo good. I'm not usually a musubi fan, so we ordered one  to share. Turned out I ended up eating 3/4ths of it and my bf wasn't too happy that I ate all of his masubi.   Can't wait to come back to Vegas for more teriyaki chicken and musubi's!!

OI33jLZXvJRXGOAeaN8v3g.text: I've been eating at Aloha specialties for more than 15 years.  Always try to stop by when I'm in town.   They do have excellent food but the service has definitely fallen off.  I dropped in on a  recent Thursday for lunch.  6/28/12 to be exact.  I expected the usual good food and fast service.  I was really disappointed.  I ordered a plate lunch to go.  I took my receipt and sat down to wait.  I never left my seat right in front of the counter.  The cashier(younger lady) that took my order began eating her lunch right after I ordered from her.  No biggie.  I waited and waited and waited.  I started to notice that several people that ordered 15-20 minutes after me were receiving their food in the dining room.  No biggie.  I continued to wait and after 35 minutes I walked up to the front and asked hey where's my plate lunch.  A different(older lady) cashier looked at me like I was crazy.  I noticed that there was a partially boxed up meal to go right on the counter.  I asked is that mine?  She looked at me again like I was crazy.  The original cashier that was now finished with her lunch said "oh yeah, that's his order"  WTF, WTF!!  I've been waiting for my to go plate for like 40 minutes!!  In disappointment I took my meal and walked out of the casino.  When I opened it in my vehicle the entire meal was COLD, gravy was clumping up.  I know that Aloha specialties does well but you need to step up the service or fire some of your lazy employees.  The entire time I was waiting the staff kept going on about what they were going to do later that day and so on and so on.    I realize that this review will not affect their business at all but if ownership is reading this just remember nothing lasts forever.  You do have good food but your service is in the dumps.  Hire some people that actually want to be there.  Every one looked like they hated their jobs.  There are a lot of people looking for jobs right now.  I'm sure you can do better than the lunch staff you currently have.  Best of luck going forward.

lThGGjmGNxvqwt6dN2vjWA.text: This is one of the best hawaiian food place in vegas. Granted its a hole in the wall (of a casino).  I ordered the "local plate" 2 spam masubi, teri chix/beef and a side of mac. I enjoyed my plater very much. While my other friends ordered the "bento box" and the teriyaki bowls. For the price they had for the bowls, I shouldved ordered one! it was much more than my "local plate". Well I was craving spam masubi, so I my stomach was telling me to buy it vs the other specialties. A buck fifty for a tall drink, sold! vs one of the specialty canned drinks (also for the same price). Some of my friends dogged me for eating spam masubi (they dont like spam or seaweed). So I tell them "life is short, enjoy and eat it up" besides, they're missing out on some good food! decent prices, I'm coming baack for some more grub! :)

S_fE9qejh1CkaKpodWXJNA.text: Always make it a point to stop here when we are in Vegas. I don't think I have ever had anything on the menu other than the large saimin with wontons and spam musubi. And I usually end up realizing that I could've gotten by with just a small. The bowl comes with lots of noodles, tasty wonton, char siu, egg, fishcake, and green onions. All of the other dishes look good, but why take a chance when you know what you want. They only take cash, so make sure you save some of your winnings from the slots or blackjack tables. There are always plenty of Hawaiians at the restaurant, another sign of the authenticity of the restaurant.

AqcpXiyaBBS9NMDH_S7OTg.text: After craving for some Hawaii type food, this place did It's justice. Order the local plate and the hamburger steak which both was pretty good. Very friendly service.

mSHZNywRXxCSJ62cmk327Q.text: The BEST Hawaiian food in town! I have coming here since i was a kid!!! Always great service, friendly owners and delicious food!!!! I have tried many other Hawaiian restaurants in town and nothing compares to this place!!!! Prices are so reasonable and portions are great!!!! I LOVE love love this place!!!!

7RsEeK-Vo71swkXjbzMqdA.text: Yes to Portuguese sausage, eggs, and rice, with a side of Aloha Shoyu.  Yes to real plates and silverware instead of plasticware and styrofoam trays you'd get at a drive-in like L&L.  And yes to all the Hawaiian decor that makes you really feel like you're back on Oahu.  No to their breakfast prices.  We paid $5.75 for a breakfast plate, which is the same amount for the breakfast buffet downstairs, which also serves portuguese sausage, eggs, and rice.  However, if you don't want to wait in line for that buffet AND you're not that big of an eater, Aloha Specialties upstairs of the California is a fine option.

ls7btsYLoJ92LoVftvN_3Q.text: I had high expectations after reading some reviews, but this place didn't live up to the hype. I had the chicken dinner. It was a lot of food, but the quality was horrible. My chicken was 50% skin and fat. If you are looking for a moderately healthy or don't-want-to-give-yourself-an-immediate-heart-attack-dinner go elsewhere. I think the deep fried oreo down the street is better for you.

PsVhmZu4ICfhC9CPbvo6cw.text: i am from honolulu hawaii and i must say i love love love this place.. me and my fiance come here and grind all da time.. ill never not love this place.. aloha specialties no ka oi

viQ-moOdSU7yqIlR1MmqoQ.text: If you are looking for Hawaiian food.. this is da place. We had the saimin, Korean Chicken and Combo plate.  Feels like Hawaii or Gardena  lol!

IzLlWi4PsdBmS7oKC7nF2A.text: I stay at The Cal twice a year and eat here at least twice during our stay. Great food and pretty reasonable. Long lines but worth the wait. Make sure you have cash on you. This restaurant is cash only!!  Shouldn't be a problem unless you lost your butt in the casino lol. I always run into people here, most of them happen to be staying at another hotel, but come here just to eat. Must be that good, right?

vOUHSXtogPyKhB7qRhQNnQ.text: There is always a line here and cheap food by Vegas standards.    Pros: -Good place if you miss Hawaii or Asian food -huge portions -pretty cheap -a lot of variety  Con: Slow service and really long wait (order your own food and they bring it to your table)  My Fav Food: - Siamin -Masubi -Local Plate -Aloha Plate -poke

DBPNN_ZMAQ-RQUgq_iewtA.text: In DTLV this the place to be for Hawaiian food. Love this place and the people. Everyone here is so nice and the food is yummy and the price is great. Its on the second floor across from the ice cream shop and the jerky store.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MOjcZ5Hn4jKZP2wULVeIjg.text: My friend recommended this place however I am not a fan of this restaurant. This is an Asian  fusion restaurant but predominantly Hawaiian food. I got the Teriyaki plate which included steak, pork loin and chicken over rice with a side of macaroni salad. The proteins were thin, almost paper thin! The rice was hard and undercooked. It was drenched in Teriyaki sauce and it still was not edible. The only thing I liked was the macaroni salad.   I do not recommend this place and will not be coming back.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

VJcRoaXM-5EqNvQGTl80Xg.text: Aloha Specialties is my go to Hawaiian restaurant Downtown. It's easy to get in and out, which isn't the case for most restaurants inside a Downtown casino. With a purchase over $10, you can bring your receipt to the casino cage and get your parking validated.  The prices are fair and the portions are ample, though there are better values for Hawaiian food in Vegas (just not Downtown). This is a fast casual restaurant and the food comes out quickly. Everything I've had here has been delicious.  Aloha Specialties will continue to be in my lunch rotation.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Menu as of 1/5/18

uh1p3QQox1zq_pvkcIggHw.text: Las Vegas is called the 9th island because so may people from the 8 Hawaiian Islands now live there/ travel there for vacation, and Aloha Specialties Restaurant is quite simply a taste of home. Authentic island cuisine with staff that recognize their regulars that have been coming there for years. The new renovations make this place more inviting than ever and although I don't care for the long lines these days, I am happy for their success. Their menu has some thing for everyone and I have never been disappointed with a dish from this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

2sKn2pvZO_4eLVxADDtrZw.text: When staying on the strip or in downtown LV, this is our go to place, always, if we need a meal from our home town. It's tucked away on the second floor mezzanine connection the Cal and Main Street Station.  It's all Hawaiian style plates here, with scoops of heaping white rice and mac salad. I always get some kinda bento, so I can have a little of a the different Hawaiian food groups - teri beef, chicken, and fish. I could be mistaken because of the lack of good Hawaiian back in SF, but this place is real good. Tasty.  The wife was amazed how fast I put down the food here on our last visit. But hey I was hungry.  Oh and bonus for all you fatties - there's a Lappert's ice cream right across.  Ask me if I went.

dByfzsHPmfY0t-_RL9bIhA.text: Excellent grindage, Plate lunch. Broke da mouf! Nice people, excellent service, picnic seating. Really good combo plate, Mac salad so tasty!

qv_I-wXogy_VvwjjdGONEw.text: if you're from hawaii, this is legit local style food. I was pleasantly surprised by the authenticity of the beef stew which tasted exactly like my great grandmas/moms which was unreal. Usually when I come to the mainland the 'local/hawaiian' food has a mainland styled flair, which isn't necessarily bad it just shouldn't be called hawaiian. (There was even aloha shoyu on the table!) I also got the korean chicken which resembled zippy's korean fried chicken. The plates come with generous portions of rice haha see the scaled picture, which may seem like a lot but we did do some damage to that mound. They had a spicy ahi poke special that I had wished I tried, but the portions here are huge! The amount of money you pay for the food you get is the reason this is 5 stars. The prices average under $15. The food comes super fast too, I wanna say under 10 minutes. You order at the counter and take your number to the table of your choice and the servers bring your food to you. You should definitely come here if you're looking for some hawaiian style food away from home. The restaurant is clean, casual, and quiet. Didn't seem like it gets suuuper busy so there's no need to worry about reservations or long waits or anything. overall satisfied with this place!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef stew! ($9.99)
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Huge plates! Spicy Korean chicken (not so spicy! $10.75)

XCOUXrZcUuv-WyRvV2v5jw.text: I'm so glad that we found out about this place. We stayed at the Golden Nugget and, unfortunately, discovered how expensive the food are inside the casinos. During our three night stay at Golden Nugget, we ate here 2x.  The first was breakfast-to-go where we got the Teriyaki Combo and Bento. I immediately took it back to Golden Nugget where we ate it right outside of The Shark Tank. Food & Drinks must be purchased inside Golden Nugget in order to bring it inside their pool but there is nothing affordable inside Golden Nugget's facilities. My boys love the food so much that they wanted dinner there that night. We were so full from breakfast from here that we skipped lunch and hung out at the pool all day. We had dinner that night there. It's a short walk from the Golden Nugget. This time, we ordered Mix Plate and the Local Plate. All three of us shared both plates. The Local Plate came without rice but the Mix Plate had enough rice for all three of us.  Again, the portions are huge and the food is very good. My son never had a Spam Musubi before and was so glad that I got him two. Local Plate comes with two Spam Musubis.  This place did not disappoint. We didn't see any lines both times we went and the food came really fast. The sodas are right outside so you get free refills. Water is free as well. We just brought our re-usable cups and filled it with water and ice.  If your looking for filling, delicious, and economical I suggest trying out this place. I'm not familiar with Hawaiian Food but ate at Ono in California. I mainly stayed with anything with Teriyaki. I wanted to try the huge bowl of soups that I saw other patrons ordering but, hopefully, next time we're back in town.

WW1XKTJ7_t06f3LqHHD_dg.text: Great Hawaii style plate lunch place. Food is good and plentiful. I had the teriyaki beef plate. The beef slices were a good portion and the teriyaki sauce was perfect, not too strong, salty or sweet. It was just right. It was laid over white rice. The macaroni salad was good too. The price was proportional to the location and availability to hotel guests. I enjoyed it.

lJVF2CCZsDP45wHG65Cf0Q.text: The saimin is close to Hawaii's quality, the loco moco is a hit or miss! last time I had it the burger was drier than the Nevada desert.  The mac salad is always on point and the atmosphere is always welcoming because of all the Hawaii people who is around the area.  There is a cute server there which makes it all the better when the food quality is not up to par. LOL!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin, Kimchi saimin, loco moco

vJITxfaS9978LH6Mu__Lfw.text: I've been coming to Aloha Specialties for decades Pre-Yelp career.  It's time to give props to one of my favorite casual Hawaiian restaurants in Vegas.  Service:  This place is popular for many reasons and the staff knows it.  The cashiers get you processed quickly and they are fast with clearing and cleaning tables to get the next party dining asap.  Waters and drinks are self-serve which I have no issue with as the dispenser is an ideal location.  Grindage:  My two faves here.  1) Loco Moco = white rice + hamburger patty + gravy + egg (sunny side up for me)  you mix it all up and I'll throw in some hot sauce to get pure bliss. This was were I had my first Loco Moco many years ago and since then I've had many more! 2) Local Plate = Teriyaki beef +Teri chicken (no rice) + 2 spam musubis + mac salad.  This is such a great combination of food put together.  All the dishes with chicken and beef is a win for me and I also enjoy their Saimin noodle soup.  Ambiance:  Walls, seats, tables and decorations makes for a very clean casual setting for Hawaiian food.  Timing is everything as lines can pop out of nowhere because people seem to travel here in groups.    Aloha Specialties remains one of my favorite Hawaiian restaurants after all these years.  I'd visit more frequently if it wasn't so far from me but there's always a couple of planned Aloha Specialties visits because the food is great.   Give them a try if you haven't already, aloha!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Loco moco!!! =)
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Local Plate...=)
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Loco Moco..!

qOE7fD8GWhXbY3ALHEVEIg.text: very good Hawaiian place in Vegas . Tried it twice and both times were great . Huge portions and the food tastes just great

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken bowl &amp; ochazuke

I7f_ZtPY0OqOxfQyBD4stQ.text: This is a nifty place to eat located in the main street casino walkway. It's a very unassuming location. Hence the three stars. However the food is pretty decent especially if you like to try spam sushi :-) if you like Hawaiian food and they do a pretty good job replicating the culture and recipes. The staff are very friendly and respectful.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

mrVLjI2Hy-_kOLykpXXP8Q.text: Aloha Specialties is a Hawaiian restaurant located on the second floor of the California Hotel and Casino.   Today's Special was a Hawaiian Plate consisting of Lua Lua and your choice of Stew (Beef or Tripe) and served with Ahi Poke, Huapia, Steamed White Rice, and Macaroni Salad.  Our party ordered Spam Musubi, Aloha's Special: Ochoa Zuke, Chicken Teriyaki Bowl with Mixed Vegetables, and Beef Stew.   The Spam Musubi consisted of Spam, Teriyaki Sauce, and a block of steamed white rice wrapped with roasted seaweed. It could be seen as a snack or a full meal depending on how hungry you are.   The Ochoa Zuke consisted a grilled Saba (topped with tartar sauce and served with lemon), Spam (half dipped with teriyaki sauce), sliced Teriyaki Chicken, raw broccoli (served with ranch dressing), fishcakes, pickled ginger, radishes, and assorted Japanese pickles, and fresh tofu (garnished with scallions). This was served with a big bowl of rice and Japanese rice seasoning and a pot of Japanese Green Tea. It was a nice variety of their offerings.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ochoa Zuke - Saba, Teriyaki Chicken, Spam, Tofu, Fishcakes, Assorted Japanese Pickles with Rice and Green Tea
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

14GEs0Jw1GzdHyEEKBiQSw.text: Aloha Specialties is our go to spot where we know we can get good Hawaiian food in downtown. I completely agree with the other Yelp reviews on here that this place reminds me a lot of the local restaurants back in Hawaii. We've been coming here for several years now and I definitely have to say that this place has amazing island dishes along with excellent customer service.   My boyfriend and I came in for breakfast today and we were immediately greeted by two nice ladies at the front who were ready to take our order. They initially apologized that they were having technical issues with their system but we didn't mind one bit. I ordered the loco moco with over easy eggs and my boyfriend ordered the aloha breakfast that came with spam, Portuguese sausage, luncheon meat, eggs, and rice. The food came out quick with no wait at all. Both of our dishes were extremely delicious and flavorful.  I definitely recommend this place. The portions are huge and the price is affordable. I had to get a to-go box for mine actually. We always come here whenever we're in the area and will continue to keep coming back. By the way, if you park at the California garage, keep the receipt to validate your ticket to get free parking.

qHA2Yvep2yy41eoAVYBioA.text: Fried Ahi plate- 4 pieces boneless Fried Ahi, 2 scoops rice, Mac salad, lemon wedges. Hits the spot!!!

sCm5KiZnyGs7v8QDHQQaxA.text: If you are a tourist comin to Vegas, take some time to visit the historical Vegas downtown and come to the Aloha specialties. It is one of the authentic, Hawaiian family restaurant and it is affordable and delicious. Glad i brought my family for the Aloha breakfast...well worth the trip and money!  We will be back!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Our breakfast is disappearing...!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

mG5sDQ3-VM4j6KPpmwGgCQ.text: Hidden Hawaiian restaurant inside the California hotel! The line does get a bit long.. we ended up waiting for about 40 minutes. It could be because we were here during a music festival..  Everything is really delicious and great portion sizes. Kind of weird though that a white lady said she's amazed that we could use chopsticks...

X4G6z9_vBVygmUQOH7EyCw.text: Best Hawaiian in Vegas! Great food and great portions. Prices reasonable for Vegas comparison

NHFytMPCo-48mAMUzUX90A.text: My go to place when in Las Vegas. Never lets me down and always leave happy!  Everything on the menu is Ono.  Their haupia is a must have.

LzwkB1XS2qXnM6WAq4KBqg.text: Big portions but very long wait times.  Noodles good not the bowls teriyaki sauce is average . Chicken is also average

nYT-Jy8Uozv7tp82pYr6NQ.text: Literally EVERY time my family is near Las Vegas we make every effort possible to stop by Aloha Specialties Restaurant.  My grandpa introduced my dad to Aloha Specialties when it was still located on the other side of the Cal Hotel. Some may think Aloha Specialties is a small location now, well from what I have heard their current location is a huge upgrade.  Aloha Specialties is located on the second floor of the Cal Hotel, right across from a snack shop and a chocolate shop. They have a small location with a decent amount of seats. However, their prices and food seem to draw a crowd so big that seating can get scarce. For the most part their lines literally go out the door. Worry not, the line tends to go quick and the food doesn't come that much later. You order upfront, pay and take your number to your table.  I have tried numerous things at Aloha Specialties and have a few recommendations. I would definitely recommend the Combination Plate with pork, chicken and beef. It's only a dollar or so more than the bowl and its big enough to share with others. The plate comes with rice and a side of macaroni salad. All meats on this plate are flatten out and covered in teriyaki sauce. I enjoy every meat on this plate because they are all juicy and tender.  I also recommend a bowl of Saimin, don't ask what's in it, just try it!  Lastly, I recommend there Aloha Breakfast which comes with portuguese sausage, spam, eggs, rice and Hawaiian bread. Their portuguese sausage was pretty good, the spam wasn't bad but honestly you can't really go wrong with it, eggs are eggs, rice is rice, and the Hawaiian bread was yummy.   Cheesy Aloha Specialties is probably up there when it comes to a typical themed hawaiian restaurants. They have cheesy decor and random table cloths.  Overall This restaurant isn't literally a 4 star restaurant. However, it's a 4 star overall. You get good ethnic food for a more than reasonable price.  Tip Cash only . . . ATM located in the lobby

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Combo Plate

oDnUry7uWVc5gnrO23Prgw.text: Food was delicous! Great prices. Definately a place to Come back to. One the 2nd floor. Cafeteria type seating, comfy and looks to be a place that is always busy because of their ridicously good food!! $20 got me a large plate of food and a side I was too full to eat. Definately a must try!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Omg so delicous!! Food coma.. very busy because it s soo good. Definately want to come back!!

YBW0ldag5LRWaJyZ3qGiQw.text: Always our favorite place to eat downtown Las Vegas. Large portions and made fresh. Can't get enough of this place

JUMfE63s9Yqi_fchlMgB_w.text: Come here once every time I'm in Vegas.  Over the many years, the saimin noodles lost their taste and chew (way overcooked...noodles have to be cooked with precision for it to be tasty and wherever they are purchasing this brand, it's got to be on the very low end).  OK for those who rarely eat saimin, but horrible for those of us who eat every week.  Broth is still killer !!

cKAdahcGBN_c4udEzI7ODQ.text: I have been going to this place since I was a kid, and no Vegas trip is complete without stopping here for a meal.  Chicken and Steak bowls are under 4 dollars and are the best rice bowls I've ever had! The teriyaki sauce that they use is incomparable! Don't forget to ask for a side of the hot mustard to add a little more kick to the bowl!  Macaroni Salad, Kim Chee, Ahi Poke, and Misubi are great choices also!  I just feed a party of 6 for under $32, that's pretty amazing!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Yum!

D3UxNP3XxDTn53OqjjYynQ.text: I was staying in Las Vegas Downtown for EDC and needed a quick bite. It's a bit confusing to find, but if you wander around enough in the California Hotel and keep going up stairs, you'll find it!  Got the Teriyaki Hamburger Steak. Portions are huge!!  Pretty decent and cheap and fast service. Nothing captivating though. There is so much rice and food though.. almost impossible to finish it all.

TlixoTjJPE1zqUkc12TNQQ.text: One of the spots my wife and i like to visit whenever we are in Vegas. On our most recent trip, we spent the day at the outlets, then drove a couple miles to the Aloha Specialties which is located on the second floor of the California Hotel & Casino.  My wife ordered the Sweet and Spicy Pork Ribs and I ordered the Local Plate which came with Beef, Chicken, 2 Spam Masubi, and the Macaroni Salad. As usual, everything was really good.

5j2BpNnm7_ArfDg-0dfE0A.text: This place has great food and the prices are cheap with large portions! If you love Hawaiian food then this is the place to go. I've brought plenty of visitors here and they all love it just as much as me. I usually get a teriyaki bowl, saimin, spam musubi when I come here  The only downsides are that it's CASH ONLY and there aren't too many tables which makes it tough to sit when it gets packed and it does get pretty crowded in there, especially during the lunch hours

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Haupia
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Teriyaki Bowl

kALCFrE6wveaWkCrNlYStg.text: If you're in downtown vegas and visitIng Hawaii, chances are you're gonna eat here at least once. For those of you that aren't, this place is pretty much equivalent to local food found in Hawaii. I got the aloha plate and everything about it was ono.

RUEuAbucP7ngjUkclW22zg.text: a hidden gem, and by hidden i mean from the tourist.   found this beaut on a  whim when leaving the Mob Museum. (which is amazing but we'll save that for another review). We wanted something not super expensive BUT super delicious. *heads to Yelp* Thanks to y'all Aloha Specialties fit the job. It was a short walk from the museum, located on the mezzanine level of the California hotel/casino.   The menu is pretty simple, and the meals are about $10 each, they can easily be shared or saved for a second meal later in the day! They come with rice and macaroni salad. I'd say, if you're in the downtown area and enjoy Hawaiian food, this is your place!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic chicken and gravy!

PMa9zkPtgqSrUX42BQGNgg.text: Location is in the California hotel. Came here during lunch. It's a small place. You order, pay, sit, and they'll bring your food. They take credit card now so don't be scared. Got the kimchi Saimin. It's a big bowl, but there was little meat and lots of Kimchi. Flavor of kimchi was too much with the soup. Really wanted to like this place but I'm not sure if I just didn't like the dish. Will have to give it another try and see if my review will change. TIP: If you park in the garage thr cashier will validate your ticket as long as its over $10.00.

cDCPMR36KWlDlbbe18PinQ.text: For all you foodies in the mood for Hawaiian food. Dis place is da hook up. The food won't let you down. The look is new, but the food is onolicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

JFj6tBn-boSIruq2oFRjJQ.text: Kind of like Ross J's out in Hendo but different.  I would imagine there would be some Aloha lost if I had to deal with tourists in the Downtown on a daily basis.  I ordered up the Korean Spicy Chicken.  I asked for chopped and extra crispy as I have done so many times at the Ross J location. No love on the chopped but found the meal to be consistent overall.  There was however a slight issue with the order, it was handled without a smile.  Perhaps I am spoiled by the other location.    Located in the California Hotel, parking sucks.  As we made our back to the parking garage we forgot to validate.  Don't forget to do it at the restaurant, the cage can not help you.

iTlPIYciHid_IPwf5O6oew.text: I've been coming here for years just never thought to write a review until today. Our office ordered lunch from here today and it was delicious. Love that it is only 5 minutes away from our office.   We ordered friend saimin, spicy Korean chicken, (2) chicken teriyaki, (2) spam musubi and a side of kimchi. It was great! We ate it all lol. Large portions for a decent price.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. spicy korean chicken and fried saimin

ZHehX1IvHlDmXlrJK-iqhA.text: First off, this is my first review, so don't bash me please. Lol.  Been going to Aloha Specialties since me and my family moved here from California some odd 10+years ago. And I gotta tell ya...ITS ONO!!!  Loco moco or Beef bowl is my go to meal. But when I'm really hungry, I go for the Aloha Bento. Service is great. Has a real "Home style"feel to the place. You can tell by the cooking of the food. Nothing beats" home cooked"style meals that'll fill you up and not hurt your wallet(being an establishment in a Casino). Rajah Dat

JPyyPwECkMVmfKVOFkP4Kg.text: A Hawaiian friend who frequents Las Vegas recommended Aloha Specialties to me as the best place to get Hawaiian food.  So, I dutifully wandered in for dinner one night on my last Vegas vacation.  My wife ordered the Loco Moco, while I got one of the mixed plates.  When our dishes was served, I couldn't believe how much food was on the plate and for the prices we paid!  We stuffed ourselves full, but couldn't finish off everything.  The Loco Moco was very tasty, according to my wife.  And my plate, with the beef teriyaki, spam musubi and grilled fish, was wonderful.  My favorite was the fish, though the spam and beef were good, too.    For Vegas, the prices were very reasonable, especially since there was so much food.  If you come here, bring cash (no credit cards accepted) and a healthy appetite!

tp5cZmfv2iRrCjV3SYMn2Q.text: I guess we got lucky as there was no line only 3 others infront so got our order within 10 mins. Da Cal Hotel & Casino is like the capital of the 9th Hawaiian island.  If you're from Hawaii, you know this to be the truth! Dis is da place where most the locals go.   You get a lot of food for your money. The portions are fairly large so we ordered Aloha Breakfast with 3 eggs, spam, luncheon meat and rice and the Loco Moco with hamburger meat which was flavorful, egg over easy (runny) with gravy.   I had the saimin and teriyaki beef in the past. Great place to get your quick local fix.

_E1dXeBZuXKxFfWJJfIQbA.text: I'd just left the place 15 minutes ago.  I ordered my food to take home at around 12noon today.  The lady at the counter definitely does not represent the meaning of Aloha. She seemed to have permanent frown, doesn't smile  and so rude.  They gave me my number but did not explain whether they will call out my number and I have to pick it up at the counter or they will bring it to my table, which was only 2 feet away from my table where my number 100 was fully visible.  So I patiently waited. 20  minutes later there is still no food and I didn't hear anyone calling out my number. After 35 minutes my patience has run out.  The old man who cleans out the tables saw my number and he saw my to go order has been sitting on the counter and he told me to come over.  He said they normally call out the number and I told him I didn't hear anyone calling out my number.  He handed me my order and I was about to leave when I realized I'm missing another order of spam musubis. So I came back for my order, the rude woman did not even apologize and instead looked at me as if annoyed.  The food was great but the service was horrible - I will never ever come back again.  This is NOT the only place that serves Hawaiian food.

-wfOBx8-oOVHceZE5YOtJg.text: Food was good and pricing reasonable. Clean tables and floors. Bathroom was clean and karaoke room is separate from dining area. Great place for family, friends and karaoke. Service was good and prepared fast. The decor has a industrial rustic with Hawaiian Music to set the mood.

OeNaTI6PPcLeUtaVgH-LbQ.text: This place is so yummy the food is always great. I love the pancakes with coconut syrup. I love teriyaki beef and fried noodles. I love the friendly faces you see when you enter the place. And they way they make you feel is like your at home in hawaii. They have a strong Aloha spirt.

38U_bp3oP3q8I6Qqw6nlig.text: My fave place to go to in Vegas. Have to stop here for my loco moco fix.

lFbqzbCH5mOI5MPuAbsFVA.text: This place has to be an anomaly.  Big portions, cheap prices, casino location and NOT rancid???!? Whuuu??  I am a fan of ASR.  I love Hawaiian food and this place serves a lot of it.  During my last visit, I ordered the Aloha Bento that came with mahi mahi, korean chicken, teriyaki beef, like, 4 cups of rice, and fish cake.  I promptly had a heart attack due to the massive heaps of fried goodness.*  But, it was worth it.    I also checked out some boiled peanuts, but, they were a little crunchy.  I like 'em soft, southern style.  I would give them four stars but I find the atmosphere a little lacking.  I like the relaxed, casual vibe but the usual crumbs on my table, and the pile of child seats on the floor, detracts from the experience.  Also, this place is CASH ONLY which makes me a little sad.  * Note:  Total lie.  Figurative heart attack.

nyrxHUWK0NgEon4fPWs1TA.text: Really really really wanted to eat here for a while and stood in line for a while but got to check out the menu while doing so. When we finally ordered, I handed over my debit card but was refused because guess what? Cash Only. There was not a single sign or anything in the entire place. So we just left. Really? Cash only in a casino? Fail.

dZt7vQhnfb0teJlBN9H_JQ.text: When you're craving some local food Aloha Specialties has got it. It'll satisfy your cravings.   Quick warning, they close 9p on weekdays and 10p on weekends. But they closed early on Christmas eve and didnt put a sign up. Sadface.

yAFobvBRbHZoydPD7gbEQQ.text: Oh damn. Talk about legit ono local kine grindz! My aunty insisted we go here when we met up in Vegas and boy, am I happy she did!  The selection here is winnaz and the food itself is good enough to compete with my favorite plate lunch places back home. Expect a line when you arrive though! Especially if the cashier is talking story with co-worker or a customer.  The smaller wonton min portion is HUGE and the mac salad is delicious. You will definitely eat well and leave with a nice food baby.   Definitely coming here again next time I'm in vegas.

if6-TUx5NrMLIoR84pF-Bg.text: This is the place to eat and grinds when you're here at the California hotel. Friendly staff and awesome ono food. Always order the beef stew and korean chicken. They serve breakfast from open to close..

lm9q-TCww2kG8C-rM4FSYA.text: Food was ok. Had won ton min and hubby had the rib eye plate which he said he wouldn't order again. It was more similar to a Teri beef plate. Overall I would eat here again. Would appreciate it if they took charge cards though.

E74E8wcx-tkQdJ9Vrnus5w.text: Koren Chicken is amazing! If super hungry...Order the fruit punch with an extra piece on chicken and mac salad.

Zu5fcZLMDtdfCOixGqGPnw.text: This place is the main reason why my friends and I initially frequented California hotel & casino.  They have some great Hawaiian food at an affordable price.  This place tends to get packed but it's worth waiting.  Luckily, this time around, we made our way here a little after the lunch crowd had already left.  Got their Aloha plate ($10.99) which includes chicken teriyaki, beef teriyaki, 2 spam musubis and macaroni salad.  I forgot that this doesn't include rice because it comes with 2 spam musubis so I went back to order some rice ($1.25).  This proved to be pointless because I only took 4 bites of rice and also had 1 spam musubi left over.  The beef teriyaki can be a hit or miss sometimes.  Unfortunately, the beef was somewhat tough this time around.  The chicken teriyaki was great though.  I also like their mac salad because it doesn't seem too heavy.  Once you order your food, they give you a number to put on your table.  They bring over your order and you're on your own after that.  There is a table near the entrance with cups and water dispensers with ice, as well as to-go boxes.  Oh and make sure you've got cash because this place is CASH ONLY.  This is the only reason why this place isn't 5 stars for me.

8ZLci-xfA-UtxQU85G7HBg.text: I've always wanted to try this place, but we always got to the Cal too late. This time we came early enough and saw the reasonably priced menu and we decided to eat there.  I did want the mahi mahi, but unfortunately it was sold out. They did have poke which I love and for $5 how can you go wrong? I knew that wouldn't be enough food, so I got a teri burger for only $3.50! It was pretty good sized and tasty for that amount. The poke wasn't the best I've had, but for the price it was good. My wife ordered the small saimen w/ wontons and she thought it was great. It was a good portion for the price and I tasted the broth which was good.   This is a place I would definitely visit again. For the prices and the selection, it's probably better than the cafe downstairs. Sure, you can't get a $4 steak dinner after 11 PM, but overall the food is better.

O0DJvbUo3jle7a5uTFSfdw.text: Holy deliciousness!    I don't even know the name of what I ordered, but it was stellar.  And cheap!  It had a piece of steak, a piece of chicken, a fish cake, and a hot dog. Yes, a hot dog, but the way it was cooked reminded me of the Asian way to cook pork.  It had that very red tinge to it.  It was salty and tasty!  The bed of rice it was all served on was sticky and satisfying.  Ask for the special korean sauce.  It is spicy and sweet.  Went well with everything on my plate.  While eating, I couldn't help but look around at everyone else's plates in the restaurant and want to try it all.    Will definitely be back the next time I'm in Vegas.

deQ88fRbvS5-ixYdSNIJGA.text: A little tough to find as its located on the second floor of the casino, but well worth the search. It was kinda fun to tell you the truth.  Bring cash, and the best part is, you don't even need that much of it. The food menu is simple and to the point. Portions are just right and taste great. If you want a good snack to start with, get the Kim Chi. The rest is up to you. We had a group of 8 so we each had a good taste of each other's dishes and there was no bad here. Very ethnic, so be ready for that, but well prepared and enjoyable.

7WRSk4WHkvaom0ab94KsaA.text: Went there for breakfast and I had the Aloha Breakfast Special! Was really satisfied with the combination of luncheon meat, portuguese sausage, and spam! The rice portions were generous all around and the meal was satisfying. Got to taste the loco moco and mac salad, both of which were decent but not the best. Mac salad was a little sour not in the spoiled way but just in taste and the loco moco gravy wasn't that rich deep gravy that you'd expect out of a loco moco. Overall great place to have a nice quick bite of Hawaiian food, espcially breakfast! Sweet bread toast A++!

O05RhJr66ne8e_zG3BER8w.text: My husband and I have enjoyed Aloha Specialities since 1993! This is a must place to eat if you enjoy Hawaiian food! Musabi's , chicken teriyaki, simian  is the best in the city! The noodles are fresh and flown in from Hawaii! From fresh poki to the mixed plate combos you can't go wrong!! Yum! Yum! Just ask the local and visiting Hawaiians dining!

NRo_kPIDXG8kpI9J5ObC7A.text: They took a little longer than expected due to something being fixed in the kitchen. Got the beef stew over rice and saimin noodles. Got a full refund due to the wait!  Great food and excellent service!

RNbCinAmYy3NNEHYuWTWSg.text: I LOVE this place. great food & awesome people. great portions for the price--haven't found a single Hawaiian restaurant that I like better in Las Vegas OR San Diego.

O1wr-_Ph9sf6ss6pFI_UVw.text: Concerned about a possible long line, we ordered take-out while staying at The Golden Nugget.  I got the wonton saimin. It really was delicious and the spam musubi was fine, but I let it get cold before I ate it and I wanted soy sauce for it.  The chicken and rice and steak teriyaki was all great. Plus It was all totally affordable. I would definitely go here again if I'm in the area.

XBUxDWEVcKM4ywe5QCow4Q.text: Food was very good, like home style. Very good comfort food. Price was fair for good, wholesome Hawaiian food. You could tell pride was taken in preparation of their teriyaki beef & chicken, macaroni salad, spam musubi, and other items.  Only downside is the wait, but I guess it due to their popularity.

y7WUcHfwcpzge30ARE9TOw.text: I'm a huge fan of Hawaiian / Japanese-American food and this place has the perfect combination of down-home cookin' and quality ingredients.  A necessity when I'm in Vegas. Plus it's near old Vegas, which is always a nice distraction from all the hoopla of the strip.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spam musubi, kim chee and teriyaki chicken

yJaNctQ7j25XbV2LOVjUHg.text: For me, an 808 bred and raised local boy, the best plate lunch you can find in Vegas. Local food made by local brahddas and sistahs. Whenever I'm out here visiting friends and/or relatives, I eat here at least once. Had lunch here yesterday. 2 korean chicken plates. 1 garlic chicken plate. 1 roast pork plate. 1 ahi belly plate.  1 saba plate.   1 side order kim chi. 3 large fruit punches. 3 Hawaiians "pounding" food. Now you tell me.   Does this place do it like the "locals" miss back home?

X0oa-PQSd8zgYkgXYFHy-w.text: I really love the garlic chicken here.  I'm not sure how it gets its name since there really doesn't seem to be any garlic in it nor is it like any garlic chicken in Hawaii, but it is really tasty.  The breading is cripsy and the gravy is salty.

Sa5s-IjSNxqAwOMfnISsEQ.text: This used to be much better.  Don't get the Poke. It gave me food poisoning.  Gotta go!  Have to hit the toilet...again!

yZZgadyH_zPPsHlxnS7hhA.text: Cheap and good - what more can I say?  Yes it is in downtown Las Vegas hidden in the California Hotel, but the legendary restaurant does exist!  I've been to this place a few times - often going out of my way to eat at this place.  I always order the saiman with wonton and bbq pork - all for less than $8.  A must visit when I  go to vegas!

8St73VgkMkjSV_x3v6A5LQ.text: After having a horrible meal in the Market Street Cafe, we left the food on the table and went to Aloha Specialties to get some better food.  I had the sweet and sour ribs.  Their mac salad was good.  Way better than Market Street.  The sauce didn't have that much sour to it.  It was mostly sweet.  The ribs were pressure cooked tender,so that was good.  I would probably only give this 3 stars, but after a 0 star meal downstairs, I think anything would be a four star meal.

PO4cVMPvoDveumqrkdIgBQ.text: When I'm in Vegas, I often head to Aloha Specialties at the California Hotel. The food here is like real Hawaii comfort food. It's Hawaiian/Asian... sticky rice, kalua pig, haupia, poke, mahimahi, saimin, spam musubi's, mac salad with lots of mayo, tabasco & shoyu on the tables etc... Their "Korean chicken" is delicious, as are most of the dishes here. If you are looking for healthy diet food, this isnt the place. The food is delicious but salty and served with rice and macaroni salad. Yum. Prices are fair and restaurant workers are very nice and friendly. Will be back.

KOzGn975n59-W7Jcyoqn7w.text: only tried a couple of items here short rib & an all meat platter with chicken ,pork chop and beef . all was pretty good and cheap and you get a good amount .also you may get tired of buffets. they sell cookies and t shirts at the counter. if you get a chance go to vegas 808 it is across the way it has all kinds of snacks !

HBUkgB5kYKc9BOzukk1Sew.text: Every time I go to Vegas which seems like every 2 months, I have to have my fix of Aloha Specialties.  I'm just a creature of habit but I like the food here.  The poke is fresh and the portions generous.  I love their Korean Chicken as well as the local plate.  This is how plate lunch tastes in back in Hawaii.  The saimin is good and this place beats anything we have in LA.  Stop there when you get a chance and enjoy the food.  Service is good except you have to wait to order from the counter.

HuEgdhHaSgWazKeAcPChCg.text: A visit to Aloha Specialties has been a tradition on all my trips to Vegas.  The reason is the great food.  I guess you can categorize the place as "fast casual".  You order at the counter, take a number and food is brought out to you.  Service was quick.  This past weekend, my boys and I tried the Kim Chee Saimen, Korean Chicken , and Tripe Stew.  Everything was hot and delicious.  The Saimen had a nice kick from the spicy kim chee and it included large blocks of tofu.   That bowl of soup was huge.  The Korean Chicken was also well flavored, moist and has a nice grilled crust.  We all agreed that the Tripe Stew was amazing.  Tender pieces of tripe in a not-so-thick tomato based sauce.  That was comfort food at it's best.  I would order that again.  Overall, it was a great visit to the hawaiian restaurant.

ByRN_FJi6TpVhcQE3bC1Yw.text: This place is doap. Sm Saimin is big enuf for this tall drink of water, and the aloha special (spam, sausage and more sausage, with two eggs and rice) is 6.50 and is pretty good. I mean, its hard to screw that up. But yeah basically, this little gem is tucked away above the diner that serves oxtail soup, so most miss it. But its nice. Not amazing but better than most.

drQFLwLx-gXPScd-zHACDg.text: Service here could be better but since I really enjoy their food I can't complain much. I've tried pretty much everything, every time I visit my Aunty here in Vegas from Cali. I think it's so funny that people travel from Hawaii only to come and eat here on their vacay. The lines can get pretty long. And customers sometime sit down on a table without a number. I really like their saimin, bento plates and spare ribs. Sometimes the ahi poki can get a pit chewy. I can never go wrong with their spam musubi.

oZp63Yu-icMRRsri0qlqEQ.text: We go here everytime we play at the California. The combination plates are the best and the staff is really friendly.   The Chicken is very tender and I think everyone loves the potatoe salad. The food comes out quick unless they're really overwhelmed.   The lines can get out of hand sometimes but it goes pretty quick. Have your buds save a table if you have to.   If you're tired of all the buffets and you're in the area, get some good cheap food here.

vLeoYgT3FneM7mO6-BqtNA.text: Holy giant musubi!  Too giant, actually.  I carved out most of the rice so that I could at least get a faint taste of seaweed and SPAM, and that's all I got- a faint taste.  The boyfriend got the teri burger and wasn't too impressed.  Perhaps my opinion of the place was tainted by the observed uncleanliness of the staff and cooks.  I'll leave that to your imagination...

yPhKCsNHynoPOAf0PtHKBw.text: Hawaiian Comfort Food...yum.  My best-buddy Rainman (Raymond A.) found this place.  When were at this place, I always think of him since he and my cuz, M. Jun, were stationed in Hawaii when they were in the Navy.  Maybe not the best Hawaiian food on the planet but I appreciate it...  What to order?  I think I've tried everything at this restaurant but here are the items I crave:  + Spam Musubi + Kimchi Saimin  Tasty, affordable, quick & friendly service.  Vices available downstairs in the Cal.  Aloha!

eC01oEKxW6t4o8tkxL_Bkw.text: I'm glad my friends came here to downtown LV to try some authentic Hawaiian food.  This is as close to Hawaii you will get in Vegas and the wait here can be long.  I ordered the Mahi mahi sandwich that was extra delicious and an order of Spam Musubi.  I left with a big smile and a happy stomach while spending less than $10 for food which is hard to come by in Vegas, unless you're away from the Strip.   Also, the Loco Moco is really really GOOD here. =)

y6B7D_Chwfkz6Qb2ppEudQ.text: LOVE THE KOREAN STYLE CHICKEN and CHICKEN TOFU SAIMIN! I also LOVE the LOCO MOCO, SPAM MASUBI, actually EVERYTHING on the menu is pretty good. It's all about what you feel like having at the moment.  Every trip to Vegas incorporates a visit to this place. Check it out.

zbfqkyAnLPdcQ_ivrSOt4w.text: Everytime I come to Vegas I stop by for the Poki. It's not as great as my dad makes it (he uses more Ogo and special stuff,  comes out more salty), but its pretty good, and at [now] $5.99 for what can be deceivingly feels like a lb, you'll only need this for a quick satisfying snack - or pair with a spam musubi and you're good.  Good for eat in, or to go, best way to grab food between the $2 tables at The Cal or the best Crap odds at Mainstreet!

x5UClH6aY-sul4UhUoKLpg.text: I love when you can get local food on the road ! Big servings, Taste good,

Dy-2vWNj4WezTFlwdkyM2g.text: Taste jus like hm but far frm hm... I love it! cheap and gives a lot of food! gotta love it

qfr9qcXjhKQdIz3FCkbj0A.text: This place is a gem for a local food lover... The plate lunches are awesome and the won ton min is huge!  The hotel it's located in is a dive but this is worth visiting.

I60evhlTpPXjMrSBoDjAQg.text: This is the best place in town to get authentic Hawaiian food!! I have never been disappointed with the food and the service is great too. The ladies that work there want to be sure you're happy and comfortable. The kahlua pork & cabbage is by far my favorite dish. If I lived closer to the California Hotel, I'd probably eat here a lot more. I love it!

Y0zjC9j_p9a7xhLXuApyjw.text: After trekking through The Cal.... not having a clue how to get there... we found this little place. Stood in line for 10 mins and ordered.   I had the Loco Moco. This was excellent except for the over cooked my eggs. The hamburger patty was fresh made and so was the gravy. Huge portion for $5.50. Had a side of mac salad. Very good at first but then realized it had way too much mayo. The GF had the chicken and spam masubi plate. She said the chicken was fatty and a little dry. I liked the spam masubi though.   All in all I would come back again if I was in the area but I wouldn't go out of my way.

i-oBQ2I-cfdEbv7msmBYDg.text: Alright so this place is like food to my soul. We always end up coming here when we go to vegas. After loosing all my money getting a beef bowl for less than 5 bucks is amazing. It feels like your in hawaii for a brief moment. If you want solid hawaiian food for a good price, this is a great spot.

8TCr-y4VVs6iyeAo-GHsEw.text: Great place for good plate lunches, saimin, you know...  da kine foods that make you wish you were still back in Hawaii sitting out at da beach and watching all da surfahs comin' out of da water...  ::ahem::  Sorry, flashbacks... This place has good foods for very reasonable prices.  It's just upstairs from the main floor of the California Club Casino...  Check it out if you need a break from loosing...  or if your arm just gets tired from pulling those one-armed bandits...

7yTIr5dJznQdu0QbgnlILg.text: This is a place that I stop at every visit to Las Vegas no matter if I'm staying another place.  My usual order is the garlic chicken w/gravy, spam musubi, and ahi poke.  I'll have this for brunch it will usually hold me over til dinner.  The flavors of the food are delicious and very filling.  The ladies behind the counter seem to never change and they act like they recognize me everytime I visit (I wouldn't doubt if they didn't but that just adds to their personal service).  The food comes arrives at your table in a timely manner and is served with a smile.  This a pleasant little gem hidden in downtown LV.  Tasty food at a reasonable cost has the makings of a successful eatery.

ixW64Ll4G4hCOuz0Btg9wg.text: This place is a staple for my Vegas visits. Ambiance isn't what you come here for, its for the Hawaiian comfort food.  What we ordered: Korean Spicy Chicken:  Skin-on chicken thighs with a sweet/spicy marinade.  Tried to copy this recipe at home, but haven't been successful.  Aloha Breakfast:  Portuguese sausage, rice, and eggs.  What more can you ask for after a long night out?  We always leave this place very satisfied.

Kq-nD1gXUxfsnRejfatHnQ.text: I made a visit early one morning after a long night of gambling.  I was the lone haole in the place.  I was surprised to see Spam as a prevalent item on the menu.  Spam is nasty.  My mom, the child of Norwegian immigrants, used to tell me that her parents brought out Spam on special occasions.  Ugh.  She didn't have indoor plumbing at the time, so there you go.  I've been to the Hormel plant in Austin, MN where Spam is made.  It's comprised mostly of leftovers from the kill floor.  They use everything from the pig except for the squeal.  Trust me on this one.  Everything but the squeal.  Yes, I did try the spam musubi.  Thanks for asking!  I also had the Moco Loco, which looks like a big pile of cow excrement.  It's comprised of white rice, seasoned ground beef, two or three eggs, and brown gravy.  Very tasty with some Tabasco on top!  I'm a fat guy already, but I'd be over three bills if I ate this dish with any regularity.    I'm knocking off a star because the staff was relatively rude.  Perhaps it was because I'm not Polynesian, but I cannot be sure.  Nothing fancy here, but give it a shot if you want to try something different.   It sure helped the old hangover.

GQ9fxuvTEDQMPV4tPa2WTw.text: Awesome. So my friend found this place his last time in Vegas. I was a bit skeptical about the place....I mean it's in the California Hotel on the old strip...not exactly what you think about when you think good eats.But I do remember folks on here talking about a Hawaiian place, so I was hoping this was it.   BINGO!!!!! This place is money!!  My friends ordered the Korean BBQ Chicken and I decided to be different and get the Garlic Chicken with Gravy. So each order comes plate style....meaning it came with rice, macaroni salad and HUGE amounts of chicken.   So there is no waiter service and everything is boxed up like you are getting it to-go. This was cool as they were able to serve lots of people in a short amount of time.  The Korean BBQ was spicy and had great flavor. The Garlic Chicken w/Gravy wasn't as flavorful but was still good. I really liked the kimchi here but unfortunately it was an add on item. I thought the macaroni salad was a bit salty.

0Fp8TH8zSU9z5z_cXx7OOA.text: I've been coming to this restaurant since I was a little kid and nothing has changed. The food is still delicious, and the food gets to your table fast. My favorite dish is the teriyaki chicken plate/bowl and it is so yummy!

1ytrhyx3fPkFfBJnYgpxUA.text: Yelp I'm sorry but you let me down! I don't get how this place has so many good reviews. First the tables block the entrance so you can barely enter the place. Signage is very bad and you can't even see it. The place is beyond gaudy and looks like something from my grandmas living room. The portions are HUGE and the prices are cheap but the food quality was lacking! The sweet and sour ribs weren't even ribs, it was pork butt! The Korean chicken was tender but I didn't care for the skin that was left on it. The place is very old school which may work for some older people but not for me. There's other places that have the same style food and I'll be sure to check them out before ever stepping back into this flashback from the 70's. So please say aloha.... As your driving or walking by!

yAemv7sZJkIm3dBi9AMqmg.text: I always seem to order the Korean chicken and always leave satisfied.  The other dish, beef stew, was demolished by a friend.

wXlanMi34R1panN7IRIR7w.text: I'm going to have to say this is hands down the best restaurant to eat at in all of Las Vegas. Bold statement I know but for the price, quality, quantity, service and consistency this place has it all. We've been going to Vegas for decades now and we've tried hundreds of restaurants from the ultra high end on the strip to the soul food in the hood. While there are absolutely some great eating spots in town we always find ourselves coming to Aloha Specialties every trip, if not multiple times. I get the same thing every time too, the garlic chicken with gravy over rice and a spam musubi. I could probably eat that every day of my life. Lunch hour can get crazy so expect to wait in a long line and for a place to sit. On weekends I've seen the line go out the door and into the casino. The service is pretty quick even when busy. This place is inexpensive and only accepts cash. But if you're rolling around Vegas without any cash it's probably time for you to go home.

hyINrbahdb0iIfj4oBkRJg.text: Solid value. Good food. I recommend it to the budget diner.   It's not Roy's. But for ~$6-8 a plate you can eat some decent themed food and leave satisfied. Cash only! I like it. I will be back. I will recommend it.   I've tried a terryaki combo (beef, chicken, pork), a mahi mahi dish, and a rice bowl (with beef and chicken). All was good.

yweSUCqeoLZGvzK-lNIwSg.text: One of the reasons I love downtown Las Vegas is that they cater to people from Hawaii.  Because of this, there is always an eating establishment serving up local food.  I shared the poke, aloha saimin, and korean chicken plate with my girlfriend.    poke: I don't know that I would get this again.  It's not what I really expected.  The tuna chunks were too big, and they were swimming in sauce.  The taste was still good though, but we didn't finish it.  aloha saimin: I usually don't care for saimin, but it was pretty good.  Lots of wonton, fish cake, and charsiu pork.  Most importantly it was very tasty.  korean chicken plate: this was a special, so it might not always be on the menu.  It didn't taste very korean at all, nor was it spicy (which it advertised).  However, it still tasted great.  Best of all, the prices are very reasonable.  They had a lot of other good looking food, and I wanted to try it all.  The next time I go downtown, I will definitely hit this place up.

ajqkgns5kaRBd_waDctV_g.text: Saturday lunch at Aloha Specialties is a tradition for me whenever I'm in Vegas. I've typically gotten the local plate: beef teriyaki, chicken teriyaki, spam musubi and mac salad, about $8 I think. Solid, generous portions. My last visit I had the loco moco. Again, solid, tough to screw up a loco moco.   Usually a lengthy wait.  Combine Aloha Specialties with a cup of ice cream from Lapperts (right across the hallway) and you're golden.

Pty6bYHxGheSGlQaV8HVPA.text: Pretty good place for local food at a reasonable price. Like the korean chicken plate.

W5IkqM_v0tpbFfpyaxbiAA.text: This place popped my spam masubi cherry...  A group of friends brought us here while in LV years ago.  This place is a diamond in the ROUGH!  Aloha Kitchen is located on the 2nd level of Cal Hotel in Downtown LV.    The food is down home Hawaiian style good. The rice and mac salad alone hits the spot after a weekend of debauchery. The line is usually out the door but it sure is worth the wait.  Note: do not save tables!  You will be scolded.    The food comes out really fast and it is cheap!  So, stash a $20 for lunch here on Sunday afternoon before you head home (and save your change for dinner at In-n-Out in Barstow).

3L4hSn4OKFPOwzD0BQXoXg.text: Whenever we are in Vegas, this place is a must. It's located in the California hotel and casino in Fremont street. They have the best saimin ever. We ordered the local plate as well as the musubis. Yum! Try it and you won't be disappointed.

EGLe0ZFk5Mcs6d1qcInZMg.text: I haven't been here recently but when I was jr high and high school, I'd go to Vegas a lot with my parents because my parents wanted to check out houses and get a house there.   Anyway, we used to come here all the time and it would always be crowded and it would be hard to find a seat. This is the first place that I had a Spam Musubi. My mom would order the Saimin with Wonton and I'd share that with and get 2 Spam Musubis. I've always enjoyed it whenever we went there. I would always pick this place to eat at least once every time we went. ahhh.... memories. After, my parents would play on the slots and I'd wonder around since I wasn't of age yet.   I actually wanted to eat here when I went to Vegas but you know, I mainly stayed on the strip.

6GYBjhfBeMF9nw3yceoNPw.text: The Saimin was really good. Get there early to avoid the long line.

AGCMpWFufQAEyiFyvztF4w.text: This place is cute and makes you feel really homey... I always get their Wonton Saimin, and it is delicious... the broth is perfectly seasoned, the noodles are great along with the meat and wontons!!!  Along with that we ordered the local plate, nothing too special to rave about that, mainly terriyaki chicken and beef, which came with 2 spam misubi's and some macaroni.  The macaroni was kind of bland... The prices are reasonable and the portions are very generous... Gotta try the poki next time I am there or the garlic spare ribs which looked really good too!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The Local Plate: teriyaki chicken, beef &amp; 2 spam misubus
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Large wonton saimin

huDdBMTsV_c-z86u3GXKzw.text: After reading an article about the California Hotel in a local Vegas paper, I was curious to check it out.  I never knew this was the go to hotel for people from Hawaii. I was even more curious to check out the Hawaiian food.    The restaurant is located on the second floor.  It is not a fancy restaurant.  You stand in line, place your order and they give you a number and they bring your food to you.  The prices are cheap considering that it is getting harder to find a good bargin meal in Vegas.    Once again, my eyes were bigger than my stomach, which means I order a bunch of things to try, knowing that I couldn't eat everything.  I had the kahlua pork combo that came with rice, macaroni salad.  I also ordered the saimin soup and nibbled on my mister's aloha bento that that came with fish, teriyaki chicken, bbq short ribs, and portugese sausage.  For dessert we had haupia.    My kahlua pork was tasty, maybe even better than King's, but the rest of the stuff was just all right.  The haupia was just coconut flavored agar-agar, kinda like jello.  Nothing special.    Overall, it was good to try, but it's nothing that I would be dying to try again.  I would rather stick to King's Hawaiian in Torrance.

oUrycnpTQkxm4zX-gLEZhQ.text: Love, love, love the Hamburger Steak here!!  It is a must have every time i stop in Vegas.. A homemade freeform hamburger patty topped with slightly grilled onions and brown gravy.  Mmm... I hate when you order a hamburger steak and it's a processed, machine pressed, hamburger patty that was made for a burger..  Totally not cool.. Wheres the love? Wheres the Aloha? You get the complete opposite here, this piece of meat was made to be a hamburger steak!  whatever spices and flavors they put in there are great!  You can taste the love and the Aloha!  Mmmm aloha... then top it with gravy and a grilled onion?!  I think i could just eat the gravy and rice!  but thats me, I'm known to do that even at thanksgiving!  The mac salad is good too, soft and creamy and goes even better with some of the gravy on top too.  What goes better with fat then MORE fat??  The other thing to get here is the Korean Chicken.  Spicy, but sweet and salty all at the same time..  The best way to describe it is a spicy teriyaki chicken cooked on the grill top..   And for the plane or car ride home don't forget to pick up a few spam musubi's.  No respectable person from Hawaii would leave home with out it.  Pros: one of the best hamburger steaks, even better than most places in Hawaii.. korean chicken, mac salad are good too.  Cons:  they don't take the Vacations Hawaii coupons and some of the items are just okay.  Cash only.  Advice: avoid peak lunch hours.. it can be really crowded.  Located between the bridge between the California Hotel and Mainstreet.

EM-uNNsrYiVttAEDFmZadQ.text: I strolled in here because we were close by. First off, there was a Looooooooong line. We figured the food was good. We were really hungry so we stayed in line. It took forever to get to the front of the line.   It also states that people should not sit until they have paid. Obviously, people do not follow this rule and the business does not enforce it.   The topping to the cake was when I finally got to the front of the line and the cashier ignored me. Did not even bother to acknowledge me. A nice "I will be with you in a moment" would have been appreciated. Finally after refunding someone's money and ignoring me she finally took my order. As I gave her my CREDIT CARD she points to this TINY sign that read "CASH ONLY". I got sooooooooo pissed because it did not have this sign at the entrance.  Waste of my time! If you don't mind poor customer service, long lines, and people to tell you "only cash" once you've waited for a million years, then this is the place for you! Otherwise, go somewhere else. I highly encourage people to go elsewhere!

mZl_BsSeDWfsnCjYC3atsQ.text: Ho yup, dis buggah is winnahs! Out of all the years that I've lived in Vegas, I've never stopped by Aloha Specialties to check out the food or "grinds" as us local peeps affectionately call it. The SO and I were in a chicken mood so I opted for the Korean Chicken on this visit and my wife went for the Chicken Chop. The Korean Chicken was awesome and not overly crispy like some places I've had it at. The Chicken Chop was pretty good but the Korean Chicken was the winner dish IMO. Wanted to try out the famed Teriyaki Chicken but decided to pass on this round. The food was a bit pricey (almost $20 for both of our plates, no soda) but I left happy so I looked past that. Keep in mind that I paid that almost $20 ticket with cash because they are still cash only. Minor set back but I would've liked to have gotten some points on my Hawaiian Miles card so I can get home and taste some real grinds. But, at least I have Aloha Specialties.   Good grinds, will be back for the Teri Chicken next time.

rjstOLacW4lcuHqAY26EWQ.text: I came here expecting this is a 4-yelp star restaurant and I can tell you this is an overrated restaurant.  This place is a mom-and-pop and hole-in-the-wall restaurant in California Hotel. I know a lots of Japanese live in Hawaii but  a place selling Teriyaki should not be named Aloha Specialties and should not be categorized as a Hawaiian cuisine.  I ordered Teriyaki Combo Plate. It comes with three types of meat: beef, chicken, and pork on a big plate of white rice and macaroni salad.  First of all, teriyaki sauce used here is a very generic teriyaki sauce you can find in a grocery. I think Yoshida's Teriyaki sauce from Costco is more fancy than the teriyaki sauce use in this restaurant.  Beef Teriyaki was a thin slide of a cheap steak and it was tough. I spent more time on cutting it and chewing it than enjoying it. Chicken Teriyaki was odd. It definitely has a big slice of chicken breast but it had small pieces and breaded together. The breaded cover was loose and thick. Pork piece was actually descent. It had a big chunk of fat with it. It's bad for the health but it was delicious.   Definitely this place is overrated and someone has to bring down the score to where it belongs to. This restaurant serves in large amount of food but in less quality. Also they are cash only.

6cOSDaMasF8TVME-e4uLpQ.text: Hungover from the night before and wanting to explore the Old Fremont Experience for the nth time, I had the strongest craving for a Loco Moco.  And thankfully, I found this gem.  It's located in the California Hotel & Casino 2nd Floor. It looks like an old-school Hawaiian diner. They have noodles, teriyaki chicken and of course, Loco Moco.    It completely satisfied my craving, I even asked for an extra cup of gravy to douse my rice in.  I'm surprised I didn't gain any weight from this most recent Vegas trip.  But I have Aloha Specialties Restaurant to thank for my cured hangover.

zBcNS1CBxjkd5nZEB9lO5w.text: Better than a 3, not quite a 4.   The place is packed with large Island people mowing on large plates of delicious looking food. How does one NOT eat here?!  Enjoyed chicken, beef, fish combo plate. YUM! Stuffed.   Unless you're a sumo wrestler, share a plate. If you're still hungry get another plate. These are HUGE PORTIONS!

r0qH8_22tg48APof8Sw8Og.text: Seriously, how could anyone ever hate on this place? Especially if you time it right before or after the massive crowds, Aloha indeed!  Bro and I decided to check out the much-heralded food offerings inside the California hotel, and prior to heading over to Main Street Station we accidentally stumbled across the Specialties. Order at the counter, take a number, tiny diner, what is this place???  $6.50 for an Aloha breakfast platter... a generous slice of spam, three slices of sausage, a nice slice of luncheon meat, THREE eggs (!!), a great big bit o' rice (NOTE: this is like Asian/Hawaiian/Filipino/etc. rice, not like pilaf or Spanish or anything) and!!!!!!!!!!!! The ultimate kicker: friggin ginormous piece of Hawaiian toast! SO GOOD!  We added a tripe stew for $7 something and it positively reminded my bro and I of a great Filipino dish that our Mom makes super well. It has a tomato-based sauce that no doubt traditional Hawaiian food connoisseurs will surely appreciate. We rounded out our meal with a musubi roll ($1.75) and it far exceeded our expectations in terms of awesomeness. WHO THOUGHT OF THIS SEAWEED WRAPPED GENIUS!!!  A magical blend of quality, quantity, location and timing brings LOOOOTS of people to this joint, so either come before or after the lunch rush and you'll be okay. Otherwise don't let the sheer amount of patrons scare you! The hordes are on to something!!!

8RRogFvjwalVbOMNWzA3vg.text: What restaurant is empty at noon but packed like crazy at  3 pm?  A Hawaiian restaurant of course!    This is the epitome of good ole fashion Hawaiian food outside of Hawaii.  We ordered:  Fried Saimin--4 Stars Regular Saimin-- 4 Stars Classic Breakfast with eggs, portugese sausage, & rice- 4 Stars SPAM Musubi Haupia  Costs: $ Cheap, real effin cheap, especially for Vegas.  On one of our trips, we ordered a drink, the breakfast, saimin, spam musubi, and Haupia and paid $14.00 total.    Service:  GAZILLION STARS.  Yes, it's slow when it's busy but aside from that, they are very friendly just as you would expect from a Hawaiian establishment.  They are beyond homey.  Altogether, what I like about this place is that it doesn't wreak of refinement if that makes any sense.  The way that it's served, you would think you're at home.  Well, I should say the BF's home since they're Japanese Hawaiian =)  P.S.  THIS IS NOT A FILIPINO RESTAURANT as it says on the info, it's not even close.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Poke
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Fried Saimin
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin

JZS6NXOhKONIX0S4gGdFPw.text: Got the Local plate for lunch. Perfectly portioned and utterly delicious. Good prices, friendly staff, and quick service. The food is an ethnic Hawaiian experience and might be a slight step out of a comfort zone for some people. Give it a shot though. It's absolutely wonderful.

9y6UiefltiRWaF4xnaBOyg.text: Fast service, very tasty food. Aloha breakfast with the Hawaiian sweet bread is so good! The eggs for the loco moco over medium is done very well. Good place to stop when craving local food!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aloha breakfast

WwsT-gExO8go2pV4wAdwnw.text: My son was torn between the garlic chicken and the Korean chicken; the guy at the cash register said Korean chicken, hands down. We ordered that and a locals plate  with two Spam musubi, teriyaki chicken and teriyaki beef, and a scoop of macaroni salad. It was all delicious.
