Even though we were really hungry, we took plenty of leftovers back to the hotel for a midnight snack. We also got a pack of macadamia chocolate chip cookies that had no preservatives, only the ingredients you would use in cookies made at home -- so good.   Remember, cash only and no coupons, but definitely worth a stop!

GBEAnRiFYv1OsGNGlzjC9g.text: Hawaiians, for whatever reason, love Vegas. Hawaiians, for whatever reason, love staying at the Cal Hotel when they go to Vegas. Hawaiians, for whatever reason, will spend their last waking moments in Vegas... literally an hour before they take the early evening flight on Hawaiian Airlines back to the islands... eating local Hawaiian food at Aloha Specialties at the Cal Hotel!  At least this was what was going on when I was here the Sunday after Thanksgiving. We waited in that long-ass line close to HALF AN HOUR. I struck up a conversation with the woman behind me about how the tap water in Vegas tastes terrible. (For those of you who aren't aware, the tap water in Hawaii is magically delicious.)  Alright, now for the actual review. This place is like a Zippy's with a much longer wait but a much smaller menu. However, for a mainland Hawaiian restaurant, the prices are very reasonable and the portions are generous. My dad and I both ordered the fried saimin (which to my dismay was mediocre... should have gone for the $4.95 large regular saimin!). My mom got some special Japanese lunch box (which I forget the name of), and my sister ordered the Korean-style beef and chicken plate lunch combo, which was really good. The mac salad hit the spot too.  There are a number of Hawaiian places around Vegas, but my guess is that this is the place to go if you wanna feel that real spirit of Aloha. Maybe that's just because it's full of Hawaiians in an extra good mood because they're grindin on yummy authentic local food. Just be prepared to WAIT.  Took a spam musubi ($1.50) to go, and ate it while I waited for my flight back to SF. I bet I got a bunch of weird looks by those unaware of the power of something resembling a oversized, angular sushi roll... but I don't care!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

JAK3fZhqZvp2OPvxQNT04w.text: Located on the second floor of the California Hotel, Aloha Specialties is a small resto located across Lappert's Ice cream. I've tasted several dishes here including the garlic chicken, regular saimin, kim chee saimin, chicken and tofu saimin, grilled saba, spam musubi, grilled teriyaki salmon, and chicken katsu. First thing that comes to mind when I eat here is Hawaii comfort food at its best. They all taste very good with an especially generous amount of rice.  I wish they could give other sides instead of just mac salad though. Other than that, Aloha Specialities is a pretty good place if you miss your ono kine grindz.

BDegGLg-SlMQXxjxxonHBg.text: Amazing food and everything on the menu is great! But this place can be pretty crowded but it is well worth it!

Z8ri8xcRsjy-w8Abhut3IQ.text: FOR THE LOVE OF GOD BRING CASH TO THIS PLACE. To get cash in this casino takes longer than booking an airline flight. The food is decent - I had the local combo plate which included spam musubi - but they could use more staff to keep up with the orders. That being said the place is popular (all the tables were full) and it's different than the standard tourist fare on Fremont Street.

qdTtOVMN_FPh53tDPyIYGQ.text: Hawaiian food without going to Hawaii.  If you're anywhere near the Fremont St Experience, then this is by far the best place to get a cheap, filling meal.  I love Hawaiian mix plate and was very happy to have discovered this place.  Delicious comfort food.

uYnQfDDMKKZn8_TZcolmRg.text: This place is amazing! They have a nice variety on the menu. The food is always fresh and delicious.  If you like Hawaiian food, this is one of the best places in town! They only accept cash, so hit up the ATM first.

GCpacs4QvVJ0Wi57TJmwWQ.text: Just ok.   I can't think of anything really good about this place. The line was long, about an hour (luckily my sister was smart to wait for us as my relative got ready) and just ok with the food.   I ordered the garlic chicken but was brought something else, more like chicken cutlet. I mean whatever, I was so hungry I didn't care. I ate it, it was ok. A pretty big portion, I couldn't even finish the whole thing.   One weird thing is the amount of people visiting from Hawaii that eat there. I mean I get it, you're comfortable eating food that you like but there's SOO many places to eat in Vegas, why eat something you can get ANYWHERE at home.

Oepc6I8AC08Xt5txguhnhg.text: I visit this place every time I'm in Vegas. I wanted to try something different so I ordered the chicken with gravy. It was ok. The chicken breading was burnt. That's why only 3 stars. The stews and loco novo are always on point. I will be back for sure..

3S0nNPiAeZwdO3W0urcXSg.text: This place is what it is! Unfortunately the atmosphere is consistent to the hotel they are located in so it's a bit old feeling and since it is a Casino, no windows are available to see the outside or time of day. Perhaps the tables could be smaller to accommodate more people to be able to eat as well. I know, it needs to be big to fit food, but I'm one that orders 3 meals for two people with 3 side dishes. When I say they can have more two people tables, it can be done.  Anyway, the service is direct and I forgot how "as a matter of fact" direct people are in Hawaii and the aloha was reserved for tourists. haha! Know waht you want to order by the time you get to the register and be clear. Other people are waiting and the ordering process is what it is. Even as a local Honolulu boy, I felt a little unwanted but I just relaxed and let things go since the atmosphere was just relaxed and care free.  The food! yes! Thank you for having a place I can eat some Hawaiian food while visiting Las Vegas! The portions are abundant like Hawaiian food should be! Lots of rice!! yes!! get your own water! yes!! Costco sized Tabasco!! yes!! Weird fat Portuguese sausage? weird but that seems to be the standard in Vegas everywhere I had them.  Overall a fan and I visited 3 times in the 5 days I was in the area . . . even though I spent $50 just for a taxi ride to and from the strip to get here! :p yeah, what can I say?

wpL_b2Q_PkJvgsXb-HlgNg.text: My first two visit back since the reopening, and I still got the cheeseburger. Still my favorite. And I like the macaroni salad even more because it is not as lathered in mayo or salty as it used to be. However, the kim chee and spam musubi wasn't like I remembered. The kim chee was a bit too vinegary, and the rice on the musubi was to bland. Fortunately, the hamburger/cheeseburger is my go-to dish there, and that's still great. The portions are still huge and the last time, I had a taste of the teriyaki chicken, and that tasted great. Before, I thought I would try the other dishes, like the saimen, but the portions on many of the items are too big more me, now, and I think that consideration is out for me, unless I can share a dish with someone else.

x-KSHOuFseJdSWt5FUoooQ.text: I was craving beef stew so I drove myself all the way to downtown just for it. Thanks to moocha, for her awesome customer service. She's such a sweetheart. The beef stew def satisfied my cravings. I love coming to California hotel because I can def feel the aloha spirit and vibe.

1JY-ksuTlShtmsKAj8jFCQ.text: Been coming to ALoha Specialties for over a decade. Glad to see that they have remodeled and expanded their restaurant. There is now much more seating and space....  The food here is delicious. The portions are large and decently priced. Definitely get more than what you pay for in comparison to other hawaiian spots. I always leave Aloha Specialties stuffed and satisfied. My favorites are the Garlic Chicken with Gravy and their Loco Moco. Meat is proportioned well with the rice that the meals are served with. Recently tried their Portuguese Sausage with rice and egg, which was appetizing as well. The sausage was a little on the salty side when eaten without rice, but balanced perfectly when scooped and eaten together...  I would give Aloha Specialties five stars, but the line to order is horrible. It has grown in popularity and is always busy, so it takes forever to order your food. They only have one cash register, which is part of the problem. When renovating, they should have added a few more registers (or even at least one more at the minimum) to prevent such delays in ordering. I will say this though...It's evident that all the employees work hard...every worker is always busy and on the go with their duties. While occupied though, they are still always happy to help.  Note: cash only accepted

WSqlAUuwjGn5g-spHYg_Vg.text: Nice place, kind waitresses but you've to wait a lot (something like 45min) ! The poke was super good !

DJ9izmnGCH4QCPn0-C6u6A.text: It's had to been at least 3 years since my last visit here and my opinion of this place has not changed one bit. The menu is basically the same and the prices are still as good as it gets. Comfort food at its finest when you're in DTLV. Aloha's is located in the California Hotel & Casino (2nd level). What to expect...perfect late night dinner, ginormous portions, and great prices. You can get most HI dishes here and the menu is simple. My suggestion...get their Teri anything. One of the guys in our group was excited because Kalua Pig was on the menu. Once we got in line, bam! Kalua Pig is all out. Aloha's must have noticed his disappointment. They immediately took the sign down and it was back on the menu. Yes! Juice! Elite! Tag Team...back again! Juice was happy he got his dish and that made the rest of us as happy as can be. As for me, my favorite is their Loco Moco, but opted for their Local Plate on my most recent visit. This consisted of their Teri Beef, BBQ Chicken, Two Spam Masubi's, and Mac Salad. Again, portions are huge but that really didn't stop me from deMELishing this. Yeah..new word folks. That means no meal is safe around me. My only issue, where's the rice? I ended up stealing a few forkfuls of rice from the girlfriend. Hah...problem solved. She didn't even notice because I got catlike ninja skills. But I did notice that she stole some of my mac salad. Yeah..I noticed. Remember, only a ninja can stop a ninja. PS: If you can't wait for Market Street Cafe's infamous Oxtail Soup that is served later at night, then head up the escalators and find your way here at Aloha Specialties. Local Plate: yelp.com/user_local_phot... Local Fork: yelp.com/user_local_phot...

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mel C. was here!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Local Plate (huge portions)

98WIGlbl6wfmr8gQ_7__nQ.text: YUM! Came here yesterday for lunch and had a great meal here with a few Californians and Hawaiians.  This place can get pretty crowded at lunchtime, so make sure to get here early before everyone wakes up or checks out of their hotel rooms.   I had the local plate, which was 8.95$ before tax.  Definitely a good deal as the portions are big, filling, and tasty.  The local plate comes with two spam musubi, chicken and beef teriyaki, and a side of macaroni salad.  I wasn't too hungry, so I was able to eat all but one spam musubi, which I foiled-up and packed-up for my airplane ride back home.    Take out boxes and foil is located near the front entrance, just below the water dispenser in case you want to take your leftovers.  They also accept credit card now (sorry, no AMEX).  Overall, a great filling meal that won't hurt your wallet. It's great to find some good quality food options that aren't too pricey like most of Vegas.  Aloha!

-TkOJZl4SqSaMXT4X7_GrA.text: This establishment is located inside the California casino on the 2nd floor.  After 2 months of renovating I am finally able to come back after the renovations Cons: ~45 minute wait in line (this maybe due to their outdated POA system and/or person(s) operating the cash register) Health Grade of C (Yes you read that right)  Pros: Food is delish (if your willing to buy food at a place that has a C rating) Consistently good food More seats inside Modern (ambiance, seats, tables, etc.) Spicy Korean Chicken (my personal fav) Loco Moco got better (idk maybe I havent had loco moco in a while) Prices Right across an ice cream eatery  FYI Saimin is now only one size (used to be small or large saimin, not a big deal tho!!)  To be honest, there isn't many cons for this place, but the two I stated can be serious gripes. The food is consistently on par in quality and taste. The place is clean. This place isnt a 50 shades of grey on my tastebuds, but its delicious.  Finally they upgraded their C grade (health code) to an A  If your in need of Hawaiian food to neutralize you appetite try this place out, its been good enough for me to eat at this place for the past couple of years.

Kuh-OYJFs9t7_xfKmMmmgQ.text: Bad Service, terribly cooked food. So bad. Ill never come back even though i love hawaiian food.

2_90zOTd37dHx2otNomWkw.text: Absolutely delicious! Located on the second floor of California hotel. The saimin and teriyaki chicken are my favorite dishes here. The texture of the saimin noodles seems handmade and the broth is the best I've ever had. Teriyaki chicken is different from other places, because the texture has a slight char to it. Sometime there is a line to order, but it's usually no more than 20-30 Min and it's worth it.

9b4o8IM__hygA8JoxG6LEA.text: I'm sure you can find better restaurants in Vegas, but this is certainly one of the better and better value restaurants in Fremont.   I got loco moco, which consisted of a large burger patty, with three eggs on top and gravy all over served on a bed of rice. It was very good and quite filling for a breakfast. And for only 8$, this deal was a steal for Vegas. My friend got he aloha breakfast, which he enjoyed, except for the spam. Maybe avoid the spam if you don't like it here.

R_UdgNkAlQ_LI0GYmSblWQ.text: I come here every time I'm in vegas. The Korean Spicy Chicken and Saimen are some of my favorites. Delish good home cooking. Big portions, really nice people, and very reasonable prices.

u-TyToqgIq-R43pOdfjOmQ.text: This place was really good.  This is obviously a family owned restaurant so I didn't come in expecting anything fancy. A nice change of pace to some of the more upscale(r?) places I have been going to.   It was pretty difficult deciding what to get. We came here for lunch and I decided to get the mixed rice/meat dish, spam musubi and coconut pudding. Everything was good and they give you a generous portion.  You seat yourself here after you order. Water is free and it was so good I came back here for dinner... had the Samin (noodles). Good stuff.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

veyjqhS8Ykotnm1H37RSyQ.text: This place is cash only folks!  I ordered the Korean chicken and a small siamin soup with wonton. The line was long, but moved quick. I was hoping to get the Korean chicken and Korean barbeque special, but it was not offered. The lady at the cash register recommended that I call ahead for the specials, as that one had not  been offered in a very long time. The food was pretty good for the price. I would return, especially given the fact that Leopalds Ice Cream is just across the way. The only other time I get to enjoy macademia nut ice cream is at the Hilton Hawaii Village location in Honolulu.

e9G2YV8LkCozF2EtojH2IQ.text: This place is a must  stop for us when we go to Las Vegas. It feels like home in the islands. I gotta have my tripe stew fix when I'm here. And can't go wrong with their won ton mein for a hangover cure in the morning!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Z3KT47vd5lofLKV8Cnhj6A.text: When I was told we would be getting Hawaiian food.. in Vegas.. I can admit, I was a bit skeptical.  And when we arrived there was this humongous line and I was like.. ugh... I'm so hungry, can we go somewhere else?  It took a little over an hour to get through the line, and I can admit, it was absolutely worth it!  Prices here are soo reasonable, I think we paid about $65 for four people, we all got a main entree plate and got an additional two saiman and an order of ahi poke and a few drinks.  Ahh.. ahi poke.. I only wish one thing:  that I ordered more!  But the sad truth to it all, is that at the end of it, we didn't even finish the saiman, we were THAT full (and this was not without lack of trying).  The only thing I will warn is this.. the local plate comes with spam musubi (in which there is a nice chunk of rice inside the seaweed) it DOES NOT come with additional rice for the teriyaki beef/chicken.  If you order a side order of rice, you will not need it all, you can probably split it with a friend (we ordered two sides after the fact and it was toooo much rice, my sister didn't even finish her spam musubis!).  Bento plate is essentially the same plate except the spam is served next to a giant bed of the rice (and no seaweed) with the teriyaki meats.  I could have probably shared the rice on my plate and no one would have had to order extra.  The last thing ordered was the Aloha plate.. all I can say is, no one had any complaints.  Everything was delicious!  We would have finished the saiman.. if only, we had, more room in our bellies!  Now I can see why this place is so popular.  Definitely worth the hour wait, and the line never ended.  The only thing we were sad about was things slowly started disappearing off the menu (sold out) as we got to the front.. literally, they ran out of garlic chicken right before we reached the order window (darnit!).  To be fair, we did hit the register around 8:30pm and that was close to closing time.    I don't know if this place could go any faster, there is one lady working the orders, one guy expediting orders, and he helps serve along with another girl, and the kitchen seemed to be cranking out orders as quick as they possibly could.  Everything was fresh and tasty (can't complain). The staff was nice, which is always a plus in such a hectic kitchen.  We will definitely will be back if I'm down by the Californian the next time I'm in Vegas!

v2JNvAxfxZGUOdLkZUj0aQ.text: This was the first time I've tried Hawaiian food and let's just say it's left me craving for more! My friends and I came here for breakfast (it was closer to lunch time though, hah) and we decided to share so we can try a little of everything.   Amongst four girls, we ordered:  Ahi Poke - DELICIOUS! If you are a fan of raw fish, this appetizer is an absolute must. It is chunks of tuna perfectly marinated in some wonderful, addicting sauce with raw onions and scallions. It was so good that we ordered 3 more to-go, just so we can eat it later. This is just one of those dishes that you simply cannot share, because you'll want it all to yourself!!!   Kimchee Saimin - Comes in a huge bowl with addicting kimchee broth. It is definitely shareable, unless saimin is the only thing you want to eat. I can't tell if this had MSG in it or not, but my friend said it didn't. This dish is very similar to ramen, but the noodle is different. We were only expecting kimchee in our soup, but to our pleasant surprise, there were also pork slices and tofu cubes!  Side of Chicken Teriyaki  2x Spam Musubi - It was my first time trying musubi and I honestly thought it'll just taste like spam and rice wrapped with seaweed. I'm not a fan of spam so I didn't think I'll like it much. But I have to say, it was pretty good... probably thanks to the sauce that was between the spam and rice.   4x Coconut pudding - For only $1.75, this might be the best coconut pudding I've had in my life. It's hard to describe but the texture and taste of the pudding is very similar to the coconut meat you manage to scrape off the shell after you're done drinking all the juice. It isn't overly sweet nor artificial tasting. I can go on and on trying to describe the taste from memory, or you can go ahead and try it!  We wanted to order more but we were about to go eat again shortly after this meal. (What else do you do besides eat when you're on vacation? ;)) So this "light" breakfast actually turned out to be more filling than we thought! By the last bite of our coconut pudding, we were more than satisfied.  It is cash-only so remember to bring cash! Free parking if you bring your hotel parking lot receipt and food receipt to the casino cashier.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchee saimin, chicken teriyaki, ahi poke, spam musubi, &amp; coconut puddings

QhO2LTj7WXSrbYmnvdTxcQ.text: Four solid stars for this no frills with Aloha friendliness tucked on the second floor of the California Hotel in Downtown Las Vegas. I was craving ramen and did not have a lot of time in between jumping from hotels so yelp reviews led me here.  A good sign was that there were local repair people eating here which was a good sign. In addition, for those that no nothing about the California Hotel  - it primarily caters to the folks from the islands and there were plenty of them here.  For those not familiar with the downtown Vegas hotels, unlike the strip, these hotels will charge for parking. Fortunately, at this hotel, as long as I had the restaurant validate my visit, I got a refund prior to exiting as I had to pay $5.00 upon entering.  AS can best be described as having a simple decor with the menu board posted on the wall as one waits in line to order.I chose the chau siu ramen and ordered for an extra charge won tons with it. The ramen is offered in two sizes ( regaular and a larger bowl). The food will be brought to your table and i got it in no time.  After all, we are talking noodles in a broth right.    The next time you are in Vegas and feel like venturing to the older downtown area, check out Aloha Specialties.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

e9550Neabb8q_toIwFqmgQ.text: The portions are Hawaiian fat boy Big Kanuha style and absolutely delicious. Upon arrival the restaurant was very very clean and the staff extremely courteous. I felt like I could take off my shoes and stay a while. With the look of a couple staff members, my pants too. Boing!!! I always order the loco moco extra sloppy (like my kisses) and it did not disappoint. I recommend this highly if you like Hawaiian/Asian food. These meals always make me super horny, so I try to eat here 15 times a week. Boing!!! Aloha and see you next time.

tnUX9v57xF8czngvtYyhUA.text: I was staying at the Golden Nugget nearby for work and a friend recommended heading here for dinner and told me what to order, the saimin and the spam musubis.  There were signs in the casino pointing the way and I headed up to the second floor. I got there around 7pm and there was no one else in line so I was able to quickly order and it took about 5 minutes to get my food to go so I could eat it in my hotel room.   It was packaged really well with the noodle soup in two containers, one for just the broth and one for the noodles and toppings, and the local plate which has teriyaki beef and chicken as well as 2 musubis and the macaroni salad. I definitely over ordered.   I got back to my room and started with the local plate. It was pretty yummy. The teriyaki chicken was crispy which was nice and the beef was tender. I was a little wary of the spam musubis because I'd never had them before but they were really tasty and huge. I left the saimin for about 45 minutes but it was still really hot when I tucked in. I was only able to finish half of it. The broth was nice with a good flavor of dashi and very clean, there were plenty of noodles, char siu and fish cakes. I should've added the vegetables for something green but I only managed to finish half of it anyway. The macaroni salad was okay but it wasn't really anything special. I could take it or leave it.   My meal was less than $20 bucks and I only managed to eat about half half of it so good value for money. Excellent recommendation and I would recommend it too if you're in the area and want some Hawaiian food.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin packed to-go
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

IMffC70jnpswCJeP_VwKug.text: Mistakenly thought it was the restaurant on the ground floor and nearly cried with disappointment when it was closed for some work they were doing.  While I moped, my mom asked if there was another restaurant at the Cal and we were directed to the second floor.  Was ever so happy to realize my mistake.  As everyone has stated: the portions are huge, the prices are ridiculously low, the food is yummy, and the service is with a smile.  Honestly, even if only three of those were True, it would still warrant a thumbs up from me.  Next time we are in Vegas we will skip the MGM buffet (seriously the worst) and eat here.

wecfisr3xsYaJkpBPJsBaw.text: Never disappoints every time I come here for breakfast food and Saimin! So yummy and service is excellent. It's nice to talk to locals from Hawaii here. Definitely my go to every time I go to Vegas. I brought my boyfriend here for breakfast and we went two days in a row. Buffets are overwhelming and not to mention pricey. I am always down for home style cooking and Aloha Specialties is my go to for comfort food.

s_zr-zIosh6k_5RPxOcqYA.text: This is really my favorite place to get Hawaiian food ever since I was younger. I moved to San Diego in 2009 and still crave this place. It is ran so perfectly that the food doesnt take long to come out at all. They are a cash only place. The bowls are more than enough for one person and the rices are unbeatable. Perfect place for a family to have dinner as they have plenty of room to eat there. The staff are always so nice when we come here.

l61gH8iAKf_-pVs12VvWqw.text: Not bad of a local food place. The rice is medium grain and done well, not like the thin or long grain rice at some of the Vegas buffets. That's the main thing that matters right? Haha.  I also think this is the only place you can get Spam Musubi in downtown Vegas so make sure you stop in during your gambling breaks to refuel! Just make sure to come early and during off-peak times because this place gets packed especially around 9pm when the typical Vegas buffets close.

a7kwWWxfi_sNUrnHOhcljQ.text: I found this jewel in 2006. I've been coming here every year, since then. So just about 13 years now, and the food never gets old. I love this place. I've had nearly everything on the menu, so you can't go wrong with what you choose. It's like a second home to me, with the feel and taste of a home cooked meal. Aloha

v1DU5JkkEo_KGHOX94giUA.text: Yummmm....I love coming here for their Saimin noodles and also their loco moco plates!  It's such a great comfort food!  Good snacks would include their spam musubis and cookies!  Their service is pretty quick and prices are alright, especially considering that it's inside a casino!  If anyone's craving authentic Hawaiian food, I'd definitely recommend making the drive out here!  Prices are good for the portions too.

Q4aIgOsfE0NFCvvXaOmAcA.text: The wait is incredibly long, and the wait for your food is even longer. I was maybe 4th in line, but it took around 20 minutes to get to the counter, and 20-30 min more for the food.  I ordered a bunch of sides of chicken teriyaki, which was overly sauced. Actually, all of the food was overly sauced, I would have to drain the sauce off of the meat for almost everything.   Beef broccoli came with a lot of onion and average broccoli with a little meat.  Aloha bento was good, I asked for no rice or any carbs, but this is NOT the place to do keto, since everything is sweet, as all Hawaiian food is. I wouldn't go out of my way to come here, to be honest unless you're already there. As much as I hate to say it, I think Ono or those other hawaiian BBQ places are better.

ZiXcOtn2-G682aFTI5kHpQ.text: We wanted Lappert's but decided to have dinner first since they're across from each other. They have all of the typical Hawaiian fare.   We ordered the Aloha Combo - Bento, spam musubi, saimin, a side of mac salad, and a side of kimchi.   The Bento Aloha Combo came with furikake rice, grilled teri chicken and beef, a piece of spam, and pickled ginger and radish. The teri chicken was a boneless thigh with the skin on. The skin was nice and crispy and the meat was super juicy. The teri beef was juicy with just a bit of fat left on for flavor. The teri sauce was a nice balance of sweet and salty.  Spam musubi was ok but could've used a slightly thicker slice of spam.  Saimin had a light broth that was a good accompaniment to our combo plate. The noodles were cooked well.  Mac salad was really bland. Wouldn't order again.  Kimchi was pretty good, not sure if it's made in-house but it was tasty.   Service was ok, they all seemed a little burnt out but were still helpful. Overall, a decent meal but nothing spectacular.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Side of Mac salad. Skip it.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kimchi.

taaSwKH9FREVfjjIiSN2oQ.text: Alright guys. This restaurant is a Must for locals from Hawaii. This restaurant is located on the second floor of the California Hotel and has so much island favorites.   Their menu includes bentos and combo plates for such a good price. We ate here twice; once on Monday night for dinner and again on Tuesday morning for breakfast. On Monday night, we ordered the garlic chicken with brown gravy and the mixed plate, which consisted of teri steak, chicken, and mahi.   The garlic chicken with brown gravy was so delicious--so much so that my friend couldn't wait to eat it when it arrived to our table. Unfortunately I wasn't able to snap a picture. The brown gravy though stole the show. Reminded me of a pork cutlet type of gravy; so rich and flavorful.   The mixed plate on the other hand had the three meats: beef, chicken and fish. The teri beef and chicken both had a glaze of teri sauce while the mahi had a spread of tartar sauce. On the side was a scoop of mac salad. The teriyaki glaze tasted so delicious. The mahi was also tasty and with all of the flavors together, it all worked together in perfect unison.   On Tuesday morning we ordered beef stew and the saimin. The beef stew coupled with the mac salad really brought me back to my mom's home cooking. My friend loved his saimin and I did too! The broth definitely made the dish for that's where all the flavor came from.   Whenever I'm in Vegas I'll always visit this restaurant at least once. It reminds me of home and the food is delicious. If you want a taste of the islands definitely give this place a shot.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Beef stew

0EKeq0tYIwNee3YppZSiPg.text: This restaurant is located on the second floor of the hotel. You just ride up the escalator or elevator to the second floor turn right and you'll run into it. This isn't a fine dining experience, it's a Hawaii local food experience. Everything is easy and casual. We stop by this restaurant when we stay at the California. I enjoy the food and the service is always friendly.  You won't go hungry here - large portions....

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Curry chicken with mushrooms and onions
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin noodles

tc9XsD_tz4VYHBOZzInwuw.text: Haven't been here in a while but it's still as good as ever! Woke up craving for Some Hawaiian food and this place is not like The Best, but will definitely satisfy the craving.  Everything we ordered was super delicious! We ordered the Aloha Bento, Omelette with spam and green onions, saimin, and the Spicy Korean Chicken (which was not spicy at all) otherwise everything was very scrumptious!!  I do apologize, we were so hungry I completely forgot to take pictures. Of our "before" pictures  Being from Hawaii and now living here in Vegas, coming to the California Hotel just to eat at Aloha Specialties for a taste of home and the feel of being back home you will definitely get that feeling here!!

BQ2Z9DiS7EZCbSnLMISleQ.text: 5 stars and BEYOND! Their food is tasty and portions are generous. Their haupia is so good that every time I go there, I buy 4 pieces and then get some to go as well. Highly recommend this place.

yyNnlr2AGPvt-eUEX59-Hw.text: Simply put--the absolute best Hawaiian food I've ever had that wasn't home made. I dine there frequently now, after a friend of mine took me there for the first time.

BbNhInsyYWrrk_OOAWf6jQ.text: I thought this place was gonna be amazing, especially after reading all the reviews. But after waiting in line to order for an hour, and then waiting another 30 minutes to get our food, I just did not feel like it was worth it at all.   We were a pretty big group, so we ordered a series of different items. Our orders included the Aloha breakfast, spam musubi, combo special, and the loco moco.   The aloha breakfast consisted of 3 eggs, rice, Portuguese sausage, spam, and ham. To me, this meal was good. It felt very much like something my parents would've whipped up for me when I was younger, but it was nothing to write home about.   The spam musubi was the biggest letdown. The portion of the spam was so small, plus the rice was seriously overfilled, and the seaweed tasted old.   The combo special included the spam musubi, teriyaki beef, and chicken. The beef was okay.  The loco moco was probably the best part of our experience at this restaurant. This included gravy, egg, and a hamburger patty over a bed of rice. I kinda wish I had ordered this instead:   If you end up at this hotel somehow, I'd recommend for you to eat at the Market Street Cafe instead.

uNNqt1N3rD4M7Wgm7QjDOQ.text: First time having Hawaiian food and the experience was okay. The tables weren't as clean as I would like because there's sauces on the table and was sticky. Ordered off the specialties section and the proteins was good. Check my picture!   $20 and there's free ticket validation at California hotel parking. I would recommend you to park there, eat and save your receipt for ticket validation then go to freemont before heading home.  I couldn't really critique the food because I'm new to this type of cuisine.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

N8wqjEQmHBqAi3nFW96p5Q.text: This place is inside the California Hotel in DTLV. This is a family owned business which makes it 10x better since you are supporting a family business. I went back here twice during my trip in Vegas since it was sooo good! I only order the Spicy Chicken. Their servings are huge! My boyfriend and I had to share a plate (which is rare!). Highly recommend this place to everyone!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Korean Chicken

RnpgYR0W0l5U7AjGih95AQ.text: This is the best thing in the California Hotel and Casino hands down.  The portions were very generous and tasted great!  If you are in downtown LV, craving Island eating and can bear walking through the smokey casino then this is the place to go.  I had the island plate with rice, fried eggs, spam, Portuguese sausage, and some other meat and it was awesome but At the same time I was starving from my 5hr drive.  The prices are reasonable.

C7dnakGS66PVVis1rWACsw.text: Always a must stop while visiting Las Vegas and staying at the California hotel or the Main Street Station. My usual order is the mixed plate. Portion is plentiful, tasty like back in Hawaii and price is reasonable. The lines can get long depending what time of the day.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Uw1oaNY-XJWfN-2uIIMtNA.text: This one's a gem because they give you a huge portion for the amount you're paying. The restaurant is in the casino on the second floor I believe. You won't miss it because they have outside seating and the space is pretty open. The line is usually long for this one but they do have plenty of seating inside and outside for groups. I enjoyed my garlic chicken a lot, lots of gravy with a side of mac.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

bd7krna8Hhd5czUVMSnNrw.text: I ordered 4 chicken gravy bowls with extra gravy to go. I get home and look in the bag and there was only 1 container of extra gravy not 4 which I paid to have. Then I open my chicken gravy bowls and there is barely any gravy on them and the rice was not even cooked all the way. The 1 extra have container they gave me should had been water because it was so watered down that it did not even taste good. I am very unhappy with the food and how nasty it tasted.

sTOPjnYpnBaDeQIEtkYe4A.text: After reading the menu online, I looked forward to visiting Aloha Specialties.  The menu offered some items that are near and dear to my heart (i.e. oxtail and tripe soups). But when I finally got around to eating the tripe soup, I found the tripe extremely mushy and the macaroni salad lathered with mayonnaise and flavorless (I really believe the only ingredients used were macaroni, a little minced onion, and mayo!!!) I'll give them another try next time I'm in Vegas. Maybe order something else?

t66WB9R4zr-wNPdua7OyCg.text: I come here everytime I'm in vegas!  I love saimin and this place has a great kimchi saimin bowl!  The portions are awesome.  My hubby and I each get our own bowls.  He also likes the spam masubi.    Better yet, the prices are totally reasonable.

Fa529EU0l4o29qSO5G5XAQ.text: Great food, low-key atmosphere.  Not he place to take a date but the perfect place to hit up with a friend before walking over to Fremont Street to Zip line and people watch!  We had the Wonton Saimin and a side of Teriyaki Chicken.  Very good and very filling.  We avoided the spam. :)

3qRm6X_4PC1cr-DmGFVYug.text: When we first arrived here at The Cal, we were starving!  The line at "Market Street Cafe" was too long, so this was a welcome option, knowing that the food is always good & that the portions are big.  The line was short & so was the wait for them to bring the food to our table.  My husband & I shared the "Bento plate" & a large "Won Ton Min."  As usual, couldn't finish it all, but after eating here, we felt re-charged & ready to begin our vacation.

Gewfk5J3WQT6ytEHMKQDCA.text: The only reason why I'm giving Aloha Specialty a 1 star is because of one waitress that waited on us on April 6 right before closing.  Don't get me wrong, the food is AWESOME, but the lack of service this one waitress didn't give us did not sit well for a party of 6.  Especially when we have 3 first timers that drove 10 hours to get some great tasting food.  I too am in the service industry, but the way this waitress acted was totally unacceptable and if she worked for me, I would TERMINATE her for her lack of customer service skills.  I didn't get her name, but she had long hair and looked Hawaiian.  To management, she's detrimental to your business.

xM4Fo16SrnS6t9Y0L8KbvQ.text: I really enjoyed this little Hawaiian gem, I got their Vienna sausage for breakfast , line goes by fast and affordable prices .  They give you huge portions which is also great so be prepared to save some for later ;)

2fH57HYblAQMzkJTjEJTpA.text: Its like reuniting with that old flame that you can never quite forget.  Before it expanded, it was the typical HOLE in the Muther Effin Wall.  Did a fly by biz trip in the area, so i went to reminisce.  Small Saimen Curry Chicken Platter Large Fruit Punch  So damn cold in vegas last week....but oh so perfect a meal.  Have yet to experience a bad meal.

LI7buzGSTXhQu5lApXX2Ag.text: Hawaiian food is always good here.  A lot of the locals come here.  They have a great menu and there is always something for someone.  Food was good like usual!  It is cash only so don't forget to bring your cash.

W3-yzIWIW1y7e48jAy-e8g.text: Got the kids way outside of box, they groaned and moaned, but they liked it, really good food.

qpJteC2Tc70CbUkxs4EaNw.text: This place is the real deal.  Food here is more authentic Hawaiian than food in Hawaii.  I LOVE this place and we go every time we visit the Premium Outlets.  The spam musubi, saimen, and the local plate are my favorites.  The sweet and sour spare ribs are good too.  On the local plate you get beef, spam musbi, and teriyaki chicken and rice and mac salad. Wish I could substitute the sweet and sour spare ribs for the beef.  The beef is just meh.  The teri chicken is PHENOMENAL.  The skin is crispy and the sauce so perfect.   Not too sweet or salty - just perfection!!!  OMG, I'm craving a local plate now that I'm writing this review.  I could eat at this place 2x a week - not that it's good for you.  The restroom outside of this restaurant seems very well kept and clean compared to other casinos.  Only downside is that this place can get crowded.  Sometimes you have to share a table with someone.  The other downside is that it's in a dive of a casino in downtown that is filled with cigarette smoke.  IDEA FOR MANAGEMENT - Wish they would open a location in HENDERSON - on Eastern perhaps.  Please?  I beg you!  And how about one in TORRANCE, CA?  Pretty Please???  It's urgent.  My craving for local plate is out of control.

77DiSoTBoBz-2v3C0jF0GA.text: OK. I initially wanted to eat at the snack bar downstairs because I love the shrimp tempura there. However, I was coerced to trek the escalator and eat here at Aloha Specialties. Don't get me wrong this place has the heart of Hawaiian food but some of the entrees here did not satisfy my taste buds. This is what we had on a ten point scale.  Beef teri bowl - 6 Chicken teri bowl - 7 Hawaiian poke - 8 Mac Salad - 8  Beef Stew - 3 (very disappointing) Spamusubi - 6   The service was very good. In my opinion the snack bar downstairs is waaaay better.

xvAEVRSRfbwaHf6fC-qJGQ.text: Aloha Specialties probably has some of the best Hawaiian food in town. Other Yelpers had already praised this place to death, so I'll keep it short and sweet.  -absolutely love their teriyaki chicken. possibly the best I've had. -saimin bowls are cheap and gigantic. I often go here just for a bowl. -breakfast is decent. traditional spam & eggs fare.  -this place gets really busy on weekends. Don't be surprised if you have to wait 30 min+ just to place an order. -cash only. keep this in mind before you stand in line! -great ice cream shop right next door for dessert  This place has definitely become my go-to place for Hawaiian food in Vegas.

RBm6-oYqTO4V9uke-cNctA.text: I'm not one to seek out Hawaiian cuisine but my friends insisted we come here.  I ordered spam Masubi and loco moco.  Best spam masubi and loco moco I ever head.  Comfort food at its best.  My friend offered some of his tripe stew to me.  He warned me that I might order one.  After one bite, I was sold on the tripe stew and ordered one of my own.  Texture was executed perfectly.  For those that like tripe, the tripe stew is a MUST ORDER.

xyeiaWk3PG6XgpHAEp6Rsw.text: I brought my parents again to the California because my dad was itchin' to play the quarter poker bandits. Stopped off at Aloha Specialties and ordered the teriyaki ribeye but requested mac salad only...no rice. The meal was so-so...no lumpia on the menu but at least some of the employees cracked a smile today. The place was busy for lunch though. That's enough hawaiian for awhile.

t5x7GLm5nCxUd1jyZ7e3Vg.text: Every time I'm in downtown, I come to this place for some loco moco. U can order it during any time of the day. Super good, but not super good for u. If ur in the mood for some authentic Hawaiian good while in Vegas, this is the place to stop. Has a very mom and pop type of feel. It's located just up the escalator on the second floor of the California club.

Pik1bcSiPZ0DwNVlNMsXpA.text: Your review helps others learn about great local businesses.  Please don't review this business if you received a freebie for writing this review, or if you're connected in any way to the owner or employees.  Just.had a Loco Moco at Aloha Specialties, the eggs over easy was overdone. Hamburger was okay, just what I expected after having the Teri burger the other nite. They're Oyako was good. @ For a  Loco Moco or Hamburger Steak, go to Like Like Drive Inn on Oahu, Hawaii (located on Keeaumoku Street).  Aloha Specialties' Teri Chicken is excellent.  @Prices are very reasonable & employees are friendly & pleasant,

ZV13NmqL_e7gRDQntW9Zzg.text: A little taste of home tucked away in the California Hotel. Good eats for a good price.   I've been here once before a few years ago, and during our recent trip we wanted some good local food. This place definitely reminds me of home...and surprisingly its seems to be always packed with local people :)   Their ahi poke was surprisingly really good! I'm always happy to find a place on the mainland that can make poke as good but never better than Hawaii. Mac salad and teri chicken a must have!   The only complaint and HUGE disappointment was their take on sweet and sour spare ribs. It had a weird sauce, that kinda reminded me Chinese food--it was gooey and it just didn't taste right.

IfvRSgldd43l0nAtvIVSNw.text: If you like Hawaiian grub, this is the place to eat at -   Its in the upper level of the California Hotel & Casino. We used to hit this place up all the time when we came to Vegas. We were in town last weekend and decided to come here for some breakfast. I ordered my usual Loco Moco - a bed a rice, 2 hamburger pattys, 2 eggs over easy and gravy all over.   Good stuff - if you're in downtown go check this place out

7bTugp3NZg1oOI8O1-wGew.text: A tradition and must when we visit Vegas! Our 1st stop.    But, the CA hotel smells of cigarette smoke all over the place. Being an older hotel, must have an extremely poor ventilation system. It seems like there is no air that circulates. Only thing that recycles is cigarette smoke with cigarette smoke.  I feel like I have pure virgin lungs before stepping into the lobby. When I walk out, I feel like I have black lungs.  Ono food though! :)  Then Lappert's afterwards if there's room for more.

ajtytlGRwdvHbsNg5ucC4Q.text: As a born and raised local, I've come here for years with my family to enjoy a quick bite to eat. I've watched the service deteriorate since I was a child, yet the food has stayed the same. Wonderful.   The only reason this is a three star review is because the food is just as phenomenal as it was when I was young. The Sai-Min is incredibly flavorful and soothing. We ordered two bowls of the Chicken Tofu Sai-Min with added vegetables, having ordered the regular as well as the kimchi before.   Usually, service is fine. This time, however, service was horrid. We waited 45 minutes for two bowls of Sai-Min. Usually this wouldn't bother us, we're fairly patient people and all we had planned we're errands. What made the whole experience agitating was the fact that people who ordered after us were receiving their food, and we were just sitting there, very hungry. I understand that some dishes take longer to prepare than others, but it was simply ridiculous. I was prepared to walk out. On top of it, our waitress kept singing loudly and high pitched, and something terrible was going on the hallway beside the kitchen. I have no idea what it was, but it was slightly gear-grinding and loud. Almost like a fork was stuck in a sink's garbage disposal.  The decor hasn't changed since I was small. Frankly, it looks dirty and unmaintained due to age. I love the photos of the owners, though. It puts a smile on your face, honestly. Drinks are pricey and the water station is a serve yourself, open to anyone who'd like to sneeze on the pitchers or in the ice. So many problems...but the food. The food is still great.  Overall, if you're a very patient person with nothing to do but talk and spend time with your company, who also does not mind being disregarded by staff, then this is perfect. The Sai-Min saved the review. It's just that delicious.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken Tofu Sai-Min with added vegetables.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Specials Menu.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Their Sai-Min options.

OJwwZPtpxsg9HQYulidEdQ.text: Feeling like being adventurous took a stroll in search of this popular Hawaiian eatery, located on the second floor of the California Hotel. Lots of locals & Hawaiians.   The ordering process is painfully slow about 5 min for each person in line. Then trying to find seating, is rough, they should add more 2 person tables & a dividing wall where you order so that those tables can be  more private & better utilized. Some background music would be nice. I ordered the Saimin noodle bowl w/ Chicken & Tofu,. It was Huge Huge portion, not salty, delicious. If you have the time try them out , great value, good food.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

y0oUL2HgfjTz0ytIRYq2XA.text: 2nd floor of the California Hotel in Downtown Las Vegas.  Reasonably priced for the portions you get.  Casual and friendly service.  Thing is that ... the food isn't very good.  :c  Combo plates (I had the Teriyaki Chicken/Meat & Masubi) were sooooooo saltyyyyy/sweet!  Did I not order the right thing or what?  The Spam Masubi was so freaken salty it was hard to not eat all the rice that it came with.  The meat that was drenched in the teriyaki sauce was way toooooo sweet.... Everything was a little better after I added some Sriracha... but other than that, way too much salt / sweetness for my liking.  :c  I think I may give this place another try if I had a rental car given how cheap the food was and all the good reviews.  But to walk / cab here from the Strip, nah ... probably not.  :c

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

hrMOV_HUD33Ee9SxEtuyhg.text: Need some Island style home cooking? Well Aloha Specialties is the place to visit for that itch. Located on the second floor of the California Hotel & Casino. I felt I was transported back to Waikiki.   I arrived on a Sunday and made it a point to drive directly here after landing from  So Cal. I had a Hawaiian grub itch that needed fixing quick. After valet parking (self park $3.00) I jumped in the long line to place my order and  opted for the small saimin and Loco Moco since I couldn't decide  on what to choose. Not long after being seated the friendly waitress brought me the two entrees.  I cracked up BC she was looking for another person to give a dish to. Even the customer next to me was shocked what I was going to attempt to do. We laughed about taking leftovers for dinner. Hey at these bargain prices - how could I possibly go wrong? It's cash only so leave your plastic in your purse or wallets people.  The saimin broth was yummy, chau Sui seasoned to perfect flavor - not overcooked or to sweet and just the right amount of fat. the small order was generously sized and hit the spot. The loco moco was also gigantic with a steamed rice base topped with a hamburger patty and drenched with gravy and a medium cooked egg once top . Talk about comfort food - this definitely is the place to find it.   There's seating out front if you''re nto people watching while dinning and many entrees sell out as did that day. I'm looking forward to returning and sampling  additional island style favorites.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Won ton saimin
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Small saimin &amp; loco moco. Huge portions!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. line out the door on a Sunday

hPFVAnzKJWNQcIJlL3WZ0A.text: Though we are staying at our Marriott timeshare at the Grand Chateau, this is a real "find" for me--I seldom get a chance to eat food like this.  Monday we drove to the California Casino for breakfast.  There is even a plug on the 6th level parking for our electric car, tho it is but 110 volts.  Anyway, I had eggs over rice with spam and portuguese sausages!  Nothing fancy, but a big delicious deal for me.  Three more days here in Vegas--must go back for a bowl of Saimin noodles.  And they had Bento boxes too!

k7SyRSQALJdvU5uIwA-00A.text: ***YELP 100 CHALLENGE 96/100***  We have been coming here for years, even when we moved to California and would come to Vegas it's always a must for us to have at least one meal here. Sadly, I've noticed the quality has been steadily going downhill throughout the years. The service even though slow, was always pleasant but lately it seems that everyone is on the edge and very easily irritated by people. Last Saturday I witnessed the cashier snap at someone in the back/kitchen in front of patrons and they weren't even discreet about it. So awkward and unprofessional if you ask me. Also the food isn't what it used to be taste wise, portions are still ginormous but what's the point in that if I don't even want to finish it. The Korean chicken is still flawless, thank God for that! Perfectly crisp skin and tender juicy meat with a kick ass marinade. The teriyaki hamburger steak was awful, the steak was dry and the teriyaki sauce had a cloying sweetness that was undesirable. Kalua pork was ordinary, the one I make at home tastes so much better. No lie. Lol  Their Green Valley location is still my preferred place as not only the staff nicer, but they offer a wider variety of the menu as well. They have Chicken Katsu and Fried rice for example that their California Hotel location doesn't carry.

GIIQK_EQaI7WSKoynpK51w.text: It's just ok. The portions on the mixed plate were small. Thin cuts of mahi, chicken and deli sliced Teri beef. We should have just stuck with the BBQ chicken plate as other customers had it and it looked ono. The "mixed vegetables" are basically stir fried bean sprouts with celery. Mac salad is very "Hawaiian-style" lots of mayo, if you like it that way, it was a reminder of home.   There are hit and miss items on the menu. This one was a miss. The renovations look nice though. Clean, local feel. The line to order food is placed in a better location within the layout as well.

GbpePzXDSnNoew06mE0e5g.text: Quite a good place, but nothing special. Food is ordinary without any excesses. The service was slow and sleepy, and so nothing more. Difficult parking.

YuHt-R_VUI5ZwTfoNHnLpg.text: One of my go-to spots downtown:  Asian food that is superior to other downtown options with fair prices.  Seems very popular with the Hawaii crowd that dominates this casino, and that's good enough for me!

-rYwJf_tDR4lF_8AEc0yYg.text: The food was good. Very different. In Vegas everything is expensive but this restaurant is acceptable. Big portions.

HUqtM6HYCm3ll4fYbD-6nQ.text: Another visit to one of our favorite Hawaiian restaurants in our favorite Hawaiian hotel. Small restaurant 2nd floor of the California hotel. They have remodeled & now take credit cards-was cash only.  They have cut down on the portion size over the years but still a good amount of food for the price. I am always happy with everything I got there & I love the Hawaiian vibe. Do yourself a favor & get some aloha here .

Q46AKzRRDWnb4PX3JISX9g.text: It's an okay place. It doesn't have an elaborate menu and it's hidden within the casino.

eT3Y-HiDkt8PuwaTTdX-Qw.text: Our friends took my husband and I here for breakfast before we hit the outlets.  The food was so good and inexpensive.  They give you big portions can't go wrong with this place.  My friends did good taking us here. Tho my husband was looking for hash browns...  I felt like I was in Hawaii in Vegas.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

PS96NlJ02owaMPN02N1vzg.text: 3.5 stars rounded to 4 stars! Aloha Specialties Restaurant is the popular one-stop shop for local Hawaiian food when you visit Las Vegas. The restaurant is located in the California Hotel and Casino. You need to time your visit here (i.e., go early) because this place gets crowded! I always wondered why Hawaii people would rush to a Hawaii restaurant in Las Vegas. Don't we get enough local food at home? It's all about comfort food. Prices are reasonable, but the food preparation can take a while. Be sure you have some good topics to talk with your table mates about. Employees here work super hard to ensure you have a good experience. Large Saimin Noodles: This dish was just like eating local noodles at home in Hawaii. The portions are quite large. The saimin tasted like S&S saimin. Although the noodles were a bit too soft and smooshy for me, it reminded me of my childhood. Nice. Grade: B yelp.com/biz_photos/aloh... Chicken Curry & Rice: This dish wasn't my favorite. Period. The flavor was right on, but the texture was a bit starchy and thick. Not my style of local chicken curry. Grade: C+ Pork Tofu: This dish was like home cooking! Slices of pork cooked with onions, tofu, and served in a mirin, shoyu, and hondashi sauce! WINNER! Grade: A! yelp.com/biz_photos/aloh... Spicy Korean BBQ Chicken: The highlight of my dish was the grilled Korean BBQ chicken. Three thighs were served with a whole lot of rice and a side of macaroni salad. Well prepared, well cooked, delicious flavor. Grade: A- yelp.com/biz_photos/aloh... Food Grade: B Service Grade: B Worth The Money Grade: B Overall Impression Grade: B

gHKMuJzVUWEoFNBul__Oow.text: When I was hanging out in Downtown Las Vegas and was searching for something delicious and affordable then this place immediately came up. Located in the California Casino on the second floor, this no frills Hawaiian cafe is oh so satisfying. We usually ordered thw combo mix plate, which comes with teriyaki chicken and beef, 2 spam musubis, rice and mac salad. For all this food it was only 10 bucks. The other plate that was amazing was the garlic chicken plate. It comes with a huge portion of crispy fried garlic chicken smothered in gravy and served with rice and mac salad. You will not be disappointed it is definitely a staple and a must get at this spot. Overall, if you are looking for quick, cheap and delicious island food then definitely come to this spot.

zo_asUFx9lYxEK_fwA4SEQ.text: Big portions of local favorites! Had the Loco Moco and it was delicious, but not enough gravy. The garlic chicken is nice chicken thighs, pan fried with brown gravy. Yum!

SHfHyFO1cpq8VgpRjpEsDg.text: I truly love and enjoy this place. Everyone is so friendly and the food is ono. I always get the ochazuke with side Portuguese sausage. It's so onolicious. Great way to end your Vegas trip.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

dZs6PaPnbZWhRqaoyDj5EA.text: Got the baked/fried garlic chicken with gravy on the side. It's not too oil and very crispy.    Since the garlic chicken is crispy, it's better for you to dip the chicken in the gravy instead of the gravy being pour all over the chicken....that's just our take on it when eating it.   Yummy. Yummy. and Yummy.  Highly Recommend this place.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

Et_ph2tb3YH_6IdHT0783Q.text: Hits the spot. First thing I get is loco moco! Rice is great and I always order extra gravy cuz I like plenty! VERY NICE STAFF! Remind me of the people back home :) will hit this place up when I come back to Vegas!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

KQFH1HcRuVeGRcvp0hbVBQ.text: Who would have thought you could find this island gem in the middle of the Vegas desert? Aloha Specialties delivers on so many levels.  We opted for the Aloha Breakfast, Aloha Bento, small saimin and teriyaki salmon...and 4 Spam MUSUBI to go.  To feed a family of 4 was less than $45.  For a person who can eat cups upon cups of rice, Aloha Specialties satisfied my starch hunger and fulfilled my daily intake in one sitting.  The Aloha Bento was a plateful of rice, fish, hot dogs, chicken and beef teriyaki. The Aloha Breakfast contained a variety of meats including Spam and the ever popular luncheon meat. Only those with a taste for meat in a can will distinguish the subtle flavors between Spam and luncheon meat.  The small saimin was actually a medium in some ramen restaurants.  The salmon was probably the smallest of the dishes, but came with white rice and macaroni salad.  The ambiance is great with 98% of the diners from Asia.  In all I give them an A+++.  Mahalo

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3RmQfVosiJdrXRDn6bNnKA.text: It's been about 2 years since I've been back here.  Nothing has changed.  It's still the best place to eat if you want True Hawaiian style food in Las Vegas.  The portions are big and so authentic.    I normally get the Wonton min Saimin.  If you've ever eaten saimin in Hawaii, you can't tell the difference.  I've taken a few of my friends here over the years and they are hooked.  Every time we get close to downtown, we have to make a stop at the Cal and hit Aloha Specialties.   I've had other things on the menu and I can honestly say everything tastes great.  I know some people have reviewed that the service isn't that friendly there and they don't smile.  If you know that going in and know that your food is authentic and tasty that's all that matters.  For me it's the only place that is a must-stop place to eat when in downtown Vegas.

A6ePIB_9MwelZQJkBZEfMg.text: I had the loco moco and the thing was huge !!!  A large hamburger patty (looked like it was a half pound) over a large bed of rice. Two eggs over easy with gravy on top. Eggs were done well. Gravy was ok and patty was ok. I think If the patty was grilled instead of cooked on a flat top I might like it more.   Saimin is pretty good though I would like it better if the noodles had more chew to them. The teriyaki chicken is excellent. The hamburger patty in the sandwich ... I didn't care for. It tasted a little gamey like it was grass fed beef which I don't like.   I gave this place 4 stars instead of 3 because of the generous portion and the service was friendly and efficient.   I'll try something else if I come back which might be the beef stew.

RDcxNOGYWrnQ6uAEvcW-SA.text: Be prepared to stand in line for a long time and to hunt down tables for you to claim on busy days. We came during the Sunday lunch rush and stood in line for about 30 minutes and waited another 15 minutes for the food. There were only two people doing all of taking orders, running orders to tables, and cleaning tables.   Service needs some SERIOUS work. I witnessed the busser kick a group off their table after they had already claimed it and specially gave it to a different group. NOT RIGHT! The cashier also just stands there for a long period of time not taking orders, staring at the long line. I also witnessed the cashier touch money then go straight to touching plates and running food. Hmm...  The portions are big! They can definitely be shared between two people. I ordered the local plate. It was reallllly good! The mac salad tasted fresh. There was a plentiful amount of teriyaki sauce over the chicken and beef, and each meat was cooked just right. The spam musubi was perfect.   Overall, I would definitely come back. Just gotta make sure to time my visit during off times to avoid the larger crowds.
