9WG4QMAuPFs4-oqnqxGV5A.text: Always a full meal for an inexpensive price.  Everything I've ordered here as been outstanding from the Saimin soup,  teriyaki chicken and rice, spam musibi, and loco moco and portions are huge great for sharing.   A great place for lunch or dinner however it can get really crowed during weekends and seating is very limited as a lot of large groups dine here.     I normally grab some macadamia chocolate chip cookies to go.    Don't forget to tip your server. :)

NnHsEFJ80DJ935GWCp_nMg.text: A little hidden gem if you're looking for Hawaii food. This is a good comfort food spot that I always like to stop by when I'm in Vegas. Food is delicious and menu has a wide selection.

KX3TRs5tQ8W2RymOQC1DiA.text: We had a hard time finding this restaurant, which is on the second floor of the California Hotel. We had to stand in line to order at the counter, but the food was delivered to the table and came out pretty quickly. We both had the teriyaki combination plate, which comes with chicken, steak, and pork, white rice, and a small macaroni side salad. The teriyaki sauce was tasty, but the meat portions were small and a little gristly and the chicken thigh was cooked with the skin and fat (which I typically don't eat). The macaroni salad was pretty good.

WiwL6Rr9-m-x4v5ZezzyGA.text: Serving sizes are huge and food is ono. You know its a good place when Hawaiian are the main customers. The hamburger steak and wonton soup were really good.

If1TouYewf8F73B1IJgN2w.text: Let me start off by saying that I love this place! Great local food at an even better price! I can't get enough of it,  everytime I'm in Vegas I go here. They have a really good selection to choose from. They have all the local favorites.   The only draw back is that this place can get supwr busy at peak times and it might take awhile to get your food. But that is because this place has delicious food.  I am definitely a fan of this place and would recommend it to anyone!

sLZmQtIhQw8Qf5XjPviVPA.text: If you go here, be prepared to wait a long time. We came here around 7pm friday night, waited for almost 1 hr to order and get our 1 hamburger steak plate. Which wasn't worth the wait. I tried to call in order, while we stood in line, but no one answered the whole time we waited. I saw the girl at register answer 2 calls, before I tried and saw other ppl walk in to pick up phone orders. When we finally ordered, I asked if I had the right number. She says, we don't answer the phone when it's busy??? Well, she did answer a few calls. It seemed like they have no sense of urgency. Actually had a party of four women, before us all order separately....Really. They stood there and literally ordered one at a time waiting behind the line??? Come on ppl, don't be difficult. How hard is it to order together and figure out the total? SMH...Next time, if we can't order by phone for pick up, forget this place.

lsrTExy2LuorUd9c2ifvzA.text: I love their food the best in my opinion is their moco loco. Now that dish is to die for . Everything that is combined together in the plate is just amazing very appetizing and there is a lot so if you are not starving i say share a plate with someone. It is a very clean place the employees are really great.

5XM2KTwwn_zX_usR0sOQCg.text: My friends and I were staying at The Plaza downtown and ended up eating at Aloha Specialties 3 days in a row. We're all from Hawaii, but currently live in the Pacific Northwest so this restaurant is a little taste of home. I've tried multiple things here over the past several years, but my favorite is the Aloha Bento. The korean chicken and teri beef are super ono! I also get a spam musubi every time I come here, but I save the musubi to eat as a snack at a later time cause the portions here more than enough for me to eat in one sitting. The portions here definitely make the price worth it.  The only reason why I am giving 4 stars instead of 5 is because it always takes a while to place an order and to get your food. There's often a long line, which makes the long wait for the food to come out understandable. However, on my last visit, there were only 3 other people in front of me and the line moved slower than ever. I'm not sure if I went at a time when they didn't have as many workers, but everything took a really long time.  Even if I know the line is gonna take forever and I'm gonna end up waiting for a while to get my food, I can guarantee you that I will eat here every time I stay in downtown Vegas.

BnIcaA2lA2A1NU8D9zTvgg.text: They have a solid saimen soup. The spam and egg sandwich was very good. Portions are large and the staff is friendly. I have never ever had a bad meal here. Great place to dine alone or with a group.

l9AGvJsNEkrD46cDXjBAbQ.text: Stayed at the Downtown Grand Hotel during my business trip in Las Vegas and was looking for something casual/interesting to try.  This Hawaiian joint is located inside the California Hotel, on the 2nd floor. It took me awhile to find the place because all of the signs on the casino level just has arrows pointing to a very general label of "restaurants." Finally, I bumped into an employee who pointed me the right place.   Went on a Wednesday afternoon, around 4pm. Really empty. I find the menu a little confusing, hard to tell what each item actually comes with. After some thinking, I went with the Loco Moco and two spam musubis. The cashiers were all very warm and welcoming, made it a very pleasant experience. I took my order to-go.  Loco Moco was delicious. The hamburger patty was a little dry, but I find that it had flavor even without the gravy. I like that the gravy is not overpowering or overly salty; it complemented the hamburger patty very well. Sadly, the over easy eggs were more over medium/fried. When I broke open the eggs, barely any yolk came out... so disappointed!!! Musubi is good, definitely hit the spot with the teriyaki sauce.  Very happy I got to try this place, highly recommend it!!

SpdS1sGx6dmzHEUIXMGrnw.text: I have been craving Adobo so I thought I would try this Hawaiian place.  I ordered the Sweet and Sour spare ribs and I was not disappointed.  If you are looking for a Hawaiian food fix them this is the place.  The staff is super friendly and it's clean.  It was a little hard to find once in the casino but once you figure out it's upstairs you will see it where all the shops are.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Sweat and Sour Spare Ribs
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3GUg8kydBrk8KEV_hPbnJg.text: Market street is a local favorite for graveyard specials and around the clock cafe/diner fare with a Hawaiian/Island twist. They serve the typical breakfast foods while offering other non-traditional breakfast meats like Tocino, Portuguese sausage, and spam.  They have graveyard specials at 11:00p like oxtail soup, chicken fingers with fries for $5, and other goodies.  I like getting their chili with rice, one of their souls with noodles and meat, or one of the above mentioned breakfast meats with rice and eggs. I also love their oxtail soup the portion is large and the broth is so flavorful.  Service is friendly but the servers are always so busy as the place usually has a line. Be prepared to ask for everything you need as soon as possible. I usually don't see anyone after our food is set down.  The price is right, the non-traditional Asian items are welcome, and the service with a smile are why I frequent this establishment over other cafes and diners.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. A little disappointed with the one won ton in my won ton min lol but it was still good

ErQPp_8q-G_qgA6IqRAVAQ.text: I absolutely love this place!! I've been coming here for the past couple of years now and I can never say no to korean chicken. It's located upstairs in California Hotel. Another great thing about it being in California Hotel, if they're closed, you can always go downstairs to the cafe for some late night oxtail soup! Mmmmm. But anyway about Aloha Specialities, it does suck that they take cash only but I'm always prepared before I come there. And sometimes during lunch, the line is ridiculously long, I hate waiting! Though it's a small little place everyone always fills this place up. So my favorite dish is the Korean Chicken, it has the perfect kick of spicy and the perfect crunch of crunchy!! Melts in your mouth and not only that but some mac salad on the side. I also like getting the Beef Chop Steak, it has lots of veggies when I feel like having a dose of veggies. Boyfriend likes the Chicken Curry, and damn is it good, nice and creamy with some rice mixed in! The portions are so big, I can't finish my whole plate, I end up eating all the chicken and leave out the rice. I only wish they were open a little bit later!! But overall my fav place for hawaiian food. ! : )

HiMleltfg0ZRZxanFo5AwA.text: If u like Authentic hawaiian food, a Must have if your in Las Vegas!! Great Food! It's in the California Hotel & Casino. I live in L.A., and nothing we have out here even comes close.

BM2ewn3WpKn_lgjhKWtGLg.text: Hawaii style food!  Great food! Local Hawaii people all over the place.  It's great that at breakfast  you can order anything on the menu.  To bad the cashier has little if any "aloha spirit".

HY1wrqwcQKQK7z48aiOSBQ.text: dude wtf are they doing to the Mac salad??  for real its like the creamiest mac salad Ive ever had, which coupled with the B health rating kinda makes me nauseous, but in a good "don't tell me, I don't wanna know, this sh*t is bomb" kinda way.  Portions are big.  Best items I tried were the terry chicken and the mac salad!  One of the best terry chickens Ive had, and Ive had a lot TRUST.  Hang loose braddah! I gotta life time ah knowledge

1sBDVvjdVBq_JjwuSIfmGg.text: this spot never gets old. the best saimin in town and i can't not stop by here if i'm in the downtown vegas area. if you want to add a little bite to your dish, ask for some sriracha sauce or add the spicy mustard that they give you. you will want to slurp up every ounce of the broth, the noodles are thicker and better quality than any other saimin wannabe, and the portions are insane when you see their prices. i sometimes forget what good mac salad is until i make my way back here and remember why i like mac salad, when it's made right! then if you can stomach some more after a bunch of good food, head across the hall for some delish ice cream from lappert's. the poifect ending to a fine meal!

LNU1RVkYksJ_4aFcOY-YlQ.text: How come the Hawaii people get off the airplane and run to here??  The food is not bad.

zuKwQbd7eRliIL8U4NZ5fQ.text: This place is a must stop for travelers in downtown vegas craving some plate lunch style foods. It's cheaper than most of the buffets and the portions are pretty good. My favorite is their version of the chicken bowl. Away enough from the smoke so you can enjoy your food -- also the bathroom is nearby too. It's located on the bridge from the Cal(ifornia Hotel) to the Main Street Station.

MkykHNbpgBleTmXxVx0iRw.text: large saimin, hamburger steak gravy all over and poki.....that is what we order everytime we come here.....just to have some hawaiian "comfort" food when you are away from home....gotta have rice & gravy

qk8lq3uHjHfl0lXaeTIj0w.text: one of the hidden gems of vegas.  located in the California.  i didn't get to partake on my last trip to vegas and i've been regretting it ever since.  having a loco moco after the previous night's bender may not be the wisest decision, but its definately worth it.  my fave is the garlic chicken with gravy.  be sure to top your meal off with a side spam musubi and fruit punch.  if you're REALLY hung-over, the saimin hits the spot - basically the hawaiian version of pho.  it's gonna cost about $20-$25 to cab it out there from the strip.

L8k7eTRnBkxLdpOZbdXZPQ.text: Saw the episode where Anthony Bourdain ate here and had to go! Food was great! Best Ahi Poke i've had since visiting Hawaii. HUGE tuna peices in good sauce. Good Poke is hard find...who would have thought it's in Las Vegas? I had to try the Loco Moco and it definitely did not disappoint! Will definitely be back here everytime we are in Vegas!

JjCpvi3KDqV5Z_1AdojJhQ.text: it's not the bestest of spots for hawaiian eats in vegas but it does the trick.  if you're lookin to eat-in be prepared for a wait during the "normal eating hours" cuz the line gets crazy long and service can be a little slow.  a good option is calling the order in and picking up to-go.  i'd suggest the loco moco and/or beef stew.  the saimin is ok but more better when you're hungover.  :P

Q6ToTU3NlqA4aHMnqqkW5g.text: best bang for your buck! located in the california hotel right near fremont street experience, on the second level. the saimin bowl is tasty, but ask for the small because it's huge! teriyaki chicken bowl is good too, simple and only $4 or $5. spam and eggs is great too, around $5 as well. overall you can feed a family of 5 and it will be under $40, now that's a deal!

HUOsynzpev2m_EF3kn1_OA.text: This place brings back memories of college and being able to eat on a student's budget.  Now that I have a job I still eat here though.  With a $10 budget this is the place to go.  Beware because it closes at 9:00 on weekdays and 10:00 on weekends.  I have tried many things on the menu but the one thing that I haven't found at other places is the garlic gravy chicken.  Pan fried chicken with the skin on topped with a bunch of hearty gravy with rice and macaroni salad on the side.  Yummy!  This is my comfort food in Las Vegas.  I spent $46 on cabs to get here from the strip for my garlic gravy chicken $10 dinner.  It was worth it to me.

v6JcCBgqmih6OrdwyQoOUA.text: best hawaiian place in vegas, love it so much. can't go wrong with anything you get there. love their mac salad!!!

AG6qWAOJHOE9AQrZCWJ2pg.text: this place for years has always been well known for their teriyaki bowls.  eh...i dont really care for teriyaki bowls, i like dishes like pork lau-lau, or kalua pork, etc... i really try to only eat the market street cafe downstairs in the california hotel for their awesomely famous oxtail soup.  so, one day my lovely dining companion joined my cousins for a quick bite to eat at aloha specialties.  oh, crap...for $15 a combo plate of pork lau-lau, macaroni salad, ahi-poke, and beef stew, plus a side order of spam musubi and 2 drinks.  first off that pork lau-lau look so sad...it was so dry...that the vegas desert dirt looked more moist.  i bit into that hard, dry, unflavored chunk of meat and yelled...wtf!!!  i didnt dip the meat in shoyu, i had to stick the meat in my mouth and then drink some shoyu to get something out of the dish.  my lovely date and i could not stop laughing at how sad the meal was.  the spam musubi was no better because it was probably sitting out too long.  the seaweed did not break off as you tried to bite through the musubi.  it was one massive chewy thing.  ooh, i hope there are better items to eat here.  it is pretty busy all the time, so there has to be something good to eat.  so i will try again...and let you know

8yrTXW_ppn-cfnUeBtqFVQ.text: No trip to Vegas is complete without  a meal here!  My little girls love getting a bowl of saimin, spam musubi, and 'sprunch' (sprite and fruit punch!) My fave is the Spicy Korean Chicken- not very spicy and doesn't taste very 'Korean', but REALLY good! You can't go wrong with a protugeuse sausage/eggs/rice breakfast here ever!!!  Yes it's in the Cal (gasp!) DOWNTOWN... but we like to eat here before or after our stop @ the outlets on the way! It's a nice, relaxing break from the craziness of the strip, and it's fun sitting at the machines with all the Hawaiian 'aunties' and 'uncles' :)

_0e9DjYK9JUoI1mkx8x6uQ.text: Aloha Specialties is located on the second floor of the California Hotel and Casino on Fremont. This is the place to eat if you're from Hawaii and missing some good local food like we were. Haha. The prices are pretty decent. I think I paid a little over $10 for a kalua pig plate (complete with rice and mac salad) and a musubi. It was super filling and I couldn't even finish half my food. I guess it's good that not everyone ordered food then.   I just didn't understand why the line moved so slowly when all you do in line is order and pay for your food. They give you a number and deliver the food to your table. There's always a long line. There was a line throughout the time we were in line and eating.

F4oC_Pdm8ST9AKB--3lZ6g.text: Visited last night for dinner with the hubby. When we got there the line was out the door and all the seats were filled. I think we could have squeezed in with another family since there was just 2 of us. Hubby found a seat and I ordered as I'm more familiar with this type of food. Line took a while to get through. About 30 minutes to be exact. Got a large saimen with veggies on the side, Kim chee, Mac salad and, musubi. Everything was Delish. Wasn't fond of the Mac salad. It was like a heart attack waiting to happen. Noodles and mayo (lots of mayo). My favorite item was the musubi. The soup was really big enough for 2 almost. There was a self serve water station that was stocked with "to go" boxes too. The staff was working hard to get everyone fed. The kitchen staff seemed to be on the ball. Poor guy in the back (Jordan) put up the wrong soup while I was in line and apologized like they were gonna whip him later. Would have given 5 stars had the line moved faster and there were more places to sit. I would visit again for sure.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kim chee
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spam musubi
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Large siamen

BYu5AhxVlkVzKmH4SvoEng.text: Good place in the California Hotel to come to see all the locals from Hawaii and if you are craving local food while on vacation.  Food is good we usually always get loco moco and saimin. The prices are reasonable and service is ok. This place is usually always busy when we come but they have a big seating area.

MVcUSk8bicJCUx-Zdm97cw.text: Got food poisoning on the first few bites. We didn't even finish our food. That's a complete no, and doesn't compare to other Hawaiian BBQs in the area...

wDXVJnv6qUnMsxL9htlFBQ.text: not 5 stars as they don't take credit cards and the casino ATM fees are high.   Other than that - I take friends and visitors there, have regular meetings with club once a month, and that's the best grindz for our budget.    Casino now BANS motorcycle parking on the property - but I'll rate that separately.   love it.  If you don't know what to order, just ask around to the people eating, most everyone is helpful.

HWH5d0B6vFPeEYeVStkKGw.text: Scratchy throat and watery eyed from all the heavy and poorly ventilated cigarette smoke in this loose-slot/low buy-in casino is worth a stop here for some Ono grindz.  Our most recent visit left me with less to be desired. Surprised since I usually leave pretty pleased with my meal. Granted the prices have gone up a bit since my last stop but in honesty who's hasn't? As for the food this round, the Saimin wasn't that outstanding and was too heavily fishy and salty for my taste. The noodles were great but the musubi more than made up for it. And hey, my husband enjoyed his loco moco and I certainly can't hate a place that serves spam and rice.

mwVuycsK7WZAQBtNqCZ83w.text: Everything is just ok here, nothing to rave about.  I tried the chicken teri, korean chicken, mac salad...it was all just ehh  CASH ONLY

6-1jpnV56yN9Ej3jFWwYoA.text: NO MORE POKE! I'm deeply saddened by the loss of ahi poke on the menu, but this is still my go-to restaurant for Hawaiian comfort food, especially after a night about town. Korean fried chicken and saimin FTW. Go before noon to beat the rush lunch crowd.

aNyerjWnLwCjeArAxwoe0g.text: Okay so I'm biased because I used to live in Hawaii, but coming here felt like HOME!  EVERYONE in the place was speaking pigeon, including the customers.    We got the Aloha Bento, saimin and spam musubi.  Lots of volume, lots of meat smothered in teriyaki...doesn't get betta than dat!  All for less than $20.  They got loco moco, kalua pork, spam & eggs, etc.. you name it!  Come here for a local feel, local food and a chill out time.

kTQ1ZVoNSXpuORf_xC064w.text: Even though we had meal vouchers, I decided to spring for lunch and treat my family after winning a few on the $.25 machines. I kept reading about this place on yelp and wanted to try it on this past trip.  I had the Korean fried chicken plate. It was like BBQ chicken with a Korean twist. They give 3 thighs and it was tasty. The skin was crunchy too. The mac salad, however, wasn't so great. It was too mayonnaise-y and tasted like mayonnaise is all they put in it, no other seasonings. I should have stayed with the Korean theme and ordered a side of kim chee instead.   My parents ordered saimin and I had a taste of the noodles. They tasted freshly made and the portions are huge! It costs extra to add on wonton and vegetables.   I was afraid to, but I went off on a limb and also ordered the ahi poke. I live in Waipahu,HI and compare poke to Tanioka's so, especially on the mainland, I am afraid to try raw fish. I do not like frozen fish and hate getting upset stomachs. To my surprise the ahi was fresh! I do not like limu too much but there wasn't too much of it. The only thing I didn't like about the poke were the huge cubes. They could have cut them a little smaller and it could have soaked up more flavor from the shoyu, onions, etc. The onion slices are large, too. It was pretty good besides that.   While we were eating, I saw an order of musubis come out and could tell they are made to order; the nori was still crunchy looking (just how I like it)  instead of wet from the rice and moisture.   Although it is not advertised, they offer free refills on the beverages. You just have to bring your cup to the counter. Also, they have take out boxes and bowls already out along with complimentary water and foil so you don't have to ask. Overall, everything we had was delicious and I will be back to try other things next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean chicken &amp; ahi poke

x82XCtSyF6BNckTC6S6sig.text: This is a must go for me whenever I stay downtown- simply because of the saimin. It hits your soul, and is quite inexpensive!

Wah-TaRczJXYX2aVmEdh1w.text: After a long vacation and drive from San Fran to LA to Vegas ending up at Aloha Specialties made me feel like I arrived back home on Oahu.  Seeing all the local people, local food, ......home away from home!  The food is ono, the portions are huge, and they have Hawaiian Sun Passion Orange!  Definitely a go to place for Hawaiians!

LeIRGgunYMb3gCMzquksTQ.text: yum! I had such a delicious lunch here today!  I ordered ocha-zuke #2 special (see photo).  It included rice, hot tea, tofu with green onion, ahi poke, mackerel, assorted Japanese pickles, and kamaboko (fish cake).  It also had a some furikake (rice seasoning) that I sprinkled on the rice with shoyu. Served in a bento box!    What made it even more pleasant was a nice little Hawaiian lady asked to join me at my big table.  She sat down with her "small" noodle soup which was massive.  We chatted for awhile and she said I eat Japanese food like a pro!  That always touches me, since I am neither Japanese nor Hawaiian.  I will definitely return.  There was even a line at 2:30 PM when I was there!  Cash Only!!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ocha Zuke #2 includes side of rice and hot tea

zXT8igbm7JugKEB2xuAhKw.text: Located inside the California Hotel in downtown Las Vegas. What a gem. This place has the best Hawaii type food outside of Hawaii. Had the Aloha bento ($8.95), large saimen add wonton ($7.00) and ahi poke ($4.95). All very tasty and portions are huge! The Aloha bento is on their special menu and consist of teri beef, korean chicken, mahi mahi and hot dog on rice with furikaki and some little side stuff like fish cakes and takuan --the highlight was definitely the korean chicken. The ahi poke had huge chunks of fish, super fresh, as good as poke from Hawaii --had a little too much onions and not enough limu but the freshness and quality of the fish more than made up for it. I originally hesitated with the ahi poke just because I thought it might be grey and stinky but it was far from that and definitely exceeded my expectations. Last but not least, the saimen really hit the spot on a cold winter day. Probably would skip the wonton next time, I thought the wrapper was too thick and doughy.  This place is nothing fancy...very casual, friendly staff, tables have cheesy hawaiian print plastic covers. The wait for the cashier to take orders is slow sometimes as she is also pushing food out from the kitchen and making people's drinks. Come here for good food, nothing more, nothing less. Cash only.

xZgtrjGBDU5PzTCAVB6ErQ.text: Went to lunch with the ladies here. Haven't been here in 10 years and it's still one of my favorites. The saimin was perfect for a chilly day and very filling. I also got the Mac salad (YUM!) and took a bento box to go. This place never disappoints, I just never make it down often because I still don't know how to get to the freeway from the hotel to get home they still do parking validation and you get your three bucks back. Love it! It always feel a little like home walking around there listening to everyone talk story.

Sg-dxed-lEUSSIxoiVAGTA.text: This is the spot to go! I had the salmon teriyaki and it was delicious!!!! Big portions and friendly staff!! You could also call in your order and pick up, which is what I usually do. Teriyaki chicken bowl with veggies under $5 is awesome!!

Z2Zy3XPnsBPZQkdhW_mUww.text: Great food! It's a must stop if you live or visiting Vegas. It's a lil pain with parking at California hotel. But it's worth it!

XZwy5MnDrIym7yuN216Umg.text: Always did love eating here... Back when it was just Aloha Cafe to us. Any trip to Vegas would involve a stop at the CAL (California Hotel) and a meal here. Never disappoints. Inexpensive and good. Never mind the wait in line. Everyone has to wait a lil bit to order their food.  I usually order the local plate. This includes beef & chicken teriyaki, 2 spam musubis and some macaroni salad. This order does NOT come with rice but that's okay because in my opinion, the spam musubis they make here come with WAY too much rice action. I usually pair this order with a wonton min (saimin noodle soup that comes with char siu pork & steamed wontons). Very good. This is a large soup order and can be shared... The garlic chicken is also a DELISH order of a meal. Tastes real good.  Don't forget the extra large fruit punch with your meal. You're gonna need it.

eEUyyQeq7tcpUt-vZxYCpw.text: This place is great.  If your planning on having lunch or dinner expect a very long wait. It goes very fast though considering that its a small restaurant. Seating is hard to get so have one person order for you and the other out looking for a place to sit.   This is the place to go for cheap good portioned food.   Haven't tried everything but every time I come I order the teriyaki bowl (that comes with white rice). This is huge and the beef is sooo tender and the teriyaki sauce is sweet but not over powering. I love it! It tastes soooo good. maybe someday I'll take a chance and order something else.  Least favorite thing about this place is that they accept cash only! How inconvenient! Oh well, its def worth it.  I would go more often but its 30 minutes from my house.

auUOtP74MzrkP0xqiadRMw.text: BEST HAWAIIAN FOOD in Las Vegas!!   I first came here 5 years ago when I turned 21.. & has become my favorite Vegas food spot. I average one Vegas trip a month and always find my way here at least once every trip. They have lots of variety on their menu & I don't think i've ever tasted a bad entree.   I usually order one of the meat combos because they load up your plate pretty well. I like the Bento Plate for about $8-$9 which includes: BBQ Beef, Korean Chicken, Mahi-Mahi, with Furakake Rice.. each respectively tasting amazing. The Loco Moco is also a good goto dish which never fails in satisfying a craving, and curing a hangover from a long night of partying.   Awesome food, big portions, good atmosphere, & a whole lot of Aloha!

CeL8bupi2Udyd54twEdy7g.text: First time I came to this place was a few years ago and the prices were CHEAP!! I think the ox tail soup special was $6-7 at the time. About 10 years ago.   The last few times I've been here the portion is extremely small. Before they gave 7-8 decent size chunks but the last few times I got 3. Wtf is going on?? Also it's $9.99 now. The steak is even worse. For $6.99 it came with super oily and soggy fries. Let your fryer heat up before cooking fries!! The veggies are oily as well. The steak have a bunch of gristle and tendon.   Also the service is always bad here. They would literally take your order and drop it off. They never come check up on you or even refill your drinks. I'm sticking to south point from now on for my grave yard specials. Steak is only $4.99 there and the burger special is $3.75

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Ox tail $9.99
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Steak special $6.99

nK6ISiMS3fTV1AwE2Mjsjw.text: Been going to this local spot since I moved here in 2000. They have recently remodeled food is still good but it makes me sad to not have all the old school booths ect. Also the new plates are smaller and not as cool as the old school ones. I bring people here all the time and not one person has been disappointed. Hands down some of the best local Hawaiian food in Vegas!! Korean chicken plate is my shit and a side of extra Mac salad!! ONO

Fchk06aneioG-T6h6ERvWQ.text: Pretty big portions and good quality. It gets pretty busy so it takes longer for the food to come out but that's not their fault. Only didn't give 5 stars because it doesn't blow me away but it's someplace I'd come back to.

TsGq9aHUIF0xP0F8rSpcEw.text: Holy moley where do I start? I absolutely love this place. I have had everything on the menu at least once and have a few choice favorites. Although I reserve  a special place in my heart/tummy for the Kimchi Saimin. Do yourself a favor and order it. Don't forget to get the spicy mustard on the side too. Also... If you are anything like me,  don't wear a scarf while eating it. You'll find random noodles later.

cd3iPzIMoRhnhw7hsmMFcA.text: What can we say, this place is BOMB DOT COM spot for good food! We don't leave Vegas without eating here. Love their Mahi Mahi, Saimen, loco Moco and their Aloha Breakfast! Yum!!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Loco Moco
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. MaHi Mahi plate

PAf8wTtDOWMnVgJ08wNbfQ.text: This place is an awesome establishment. It feels like I am in Hawaii while I'm Las Vegas. I'm from California .The place is really good. I went two time while in Las Vegas for 3 nights. I love there Won-ton min (sorry if spelling is wrong). I also love there Spam Musubi and mac salad. There saimin is also very delicious. They recently updated this restaurant also. It is more modern now. I bought a lot of food for myself and the wife and the total was under $22.00 both times we went. I look forward to my next trip to Vegas to stop by this establishment. Great job!

5XQE9tXms7ZI6pMs4tQvEg.text: I went to get breakfast with my friend on a Sunday morning around 9:30. There was one couple in front of us. By the time we left there were probably twenty in line.   We ordered the saimin, Kim chee, and spam musubi. It only took a few minutes to get our food. It was all good. The char siu with the hot mustard was very nice. The noodles were good too, and plenty long. Kim chee was especially good. The musubi was like I always remembered. Nothing fancy, but a good value of familiar tastes. Cost for two came to $15.00.  The remodel brightened it up a bit. And it was clean. Menu seemed to be pretty much the same as before. Service quick, although  the place had few customers early on. I can't say anything bad about this place. Next time I'll order some boiled peanuts...

ByyVVSN1Kd0LS-oFUQfCiQ.text: Last review from my Vegas trip.  Went here for our last dinner in Vegas before hitting up Marquee.  This restaurant is far off the strip. Heading over here we did pass by the "Pawnstars" shop & the wedding chapel that they used for "The Hangover." Pretty cool! Also the self-proclaimed "World's Biggest Souvenir Shop." Place was HUUUUGE! So I wouldn't doubt the name at all.  Walking into the hotel this restaurant was located in was AWKWARD. Apparently that hotel attracts the OLDER crowd. I didn't see anyone our age at all. What made it eve more AWKWARD was that we were dressed in clubbing clothes so all the older people were staring at us like we were hookers or something. lol. Walking into the restaurant got us lots of stares since we were severely over-dressed & looked out of place. Besides that, here goes my experience.  I ordered the chicken teriyaki, musubi combo. It comes with 2 MUSUBI'S! Yummy! The macaroni salad was sooooo good! The chicken teriyaki, WOW. They were not stingy when it came to portions. I ate as much as I could since we were going to be drinking alot that night & it still looked like I didn't even put a dent into it.  The prices are unbelievably low. I guess going off the strip makes things a little cheaper.  I would go here again, just sayin'

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Teriyaki Chicken &amp; Musubi Combo.

3F9KdWUuskO5jgortCWziA.text: Still one of the best in town!  Newly renovated, prices have gone up a few bucks.  But certainly worth every penny.  Consistency is key!  AS for the win

jUJMFIFqoTkRRpkn1hTPbw.text: Hidden upstairs above the casino, the staff is slammed at a fairly consistent pace and it is evident that they are accustomed to the rush. They wdont seem to be in any particular hurry, but considering the kitchen can only move so fast, I don't blame them. It takes quite some time to get food, but it's worth it. The serving size is more than plentiful, and the flavors are full. Overall, if you're in a rush, skip it, but if you've got time, the flavors worth the wait.

6cI-iCpT9bc2_L_j8ZrTrw.text: Yes! I was happy and will be back again and again!   Starting with very friendly service, the experience was a good one from the beginning.   Located in the California Hotel on the upper level above the Casino, the Aloha Specialties Restaurant will be a place I visit for a comforting meal now and then. Both, my dinner buddy and I had the Teriyaki Salmon with White Rice and macaroni salad. We added a couple of over easy fried eggs and boom.. delicious! :)   Easy ordering at the front counter from the cashier style system.. order, they give you a number, you choose a table, they bring you your food. The delivery was with a smile and was pretty fast. Food was generous in portion and flavors were great. For the two of us with both dinners and 2 bottles of water.. around $25 before tax. Not bad at all.. we were both full. So if you are in the area, and want some delicious grub, drop in to Aloha Specialties Restaurant! Happy Eating!

KxPTNp20_ytTFKzfvdlJ4A.text: Good authentic hawaiian food - awesome price - super generous portion!  This Asian girl is in heaven!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chicken curry and rice with Mac Salad!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $5.25 delicious And cheap! chicken bowl with vegetables!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. In need of an update - but food looks great and portions are generous!

OqSRVaBd3HVp6V9rMt7TSQ.text: Place looks good after the remodel. Sooooo disappointed that they don't make Oyako anymore. It is the best I've tasted and of the things I always look forward to having when we come to the Cal. Also don't have Hawaiian sweet bread toast or Hawaiian Sun drinks anymore. Guess I won't be coming here as much anymore. Most everything else still is on the menu.

mDY1Quc61KYSApkvgxmXwA.text: This place still gets the same amount of stars since my last review, but I feel I need to talk about my last experience there.  Unfortunately, it wasn't that great.  It wasn't the food.  The food was amazing as always.  And the service (once you do order your food) is pretty quick.  Honestly, turnaround here is pretty fast considering how many people they go through.  No, my experience had to deal with customers.  And maybe there's something the restaurant can do about it.  The seating here is basically, seat yourself.  But with such a small seating area, and a line that is usually out the door, sometimes it may get a little hard to find a seat.  But as I said, turnaround is pretty quick at this restaurant, and usually it works out well where there can be a constant flow of customers without too much "I can't find a table to sit at" distress.  However, on this past experience, the line was all the way to the escalator.  A party that had about 20 people decided to save seats when they were clearly at the end of the line, no where near ordering.  By the time we had ordered and gotten our food, we lucked out finding a place to sit, but alas, only 4 seats for 5 people.  We kindly asked these other customers if we could borrow a seat while they waited for the rest of their party to order, but they rudely declined.  Only after my friend asked a second time did they begrudgingly let us "borrow" a chair.  Long story short, we finished our food, and this party that had taken up 3-4 large tables still hadn't even ordered yet!  What was most disheartening was that you could see older people start to look for tables to sit at, and there was no where for them to sit because of this large party.  How to possibly fix this problem?  Possibly make it a courteous rule that you can't "reserve" a spot until you get your number/order your food.  That way, the people who are eating can actually sit down and eat.  And of course, this doesn't happen all the time.  In this instance, it was really the customers who were rude.  But sometimes, it would be nice for the establishment to step in and let them know it's not cool to reserve that many spots when they clearly weren't even close to ordering yet.  Overall, their food is still bomb, and it a Vegas trip really is complete with a trip to this place.  I won't let this one sour experience deter me.

osZIJJfdFtRv072YvCip-Q.text: I love you Yelp. We wouldn't have been able to find this place without you. It's worth the drive to downtown that's for sure. Parking is $5 upfront at the lot of California Hotel. The restaurant is inside of California Hotel. Take your parking recipe and dining receipt to the cashier inside the hotel to get your $5 back. Food was amazing. Never been to Hawaii but hope the food is just as good as here. Spam from a can will never taste the same again. Thanks for the experience and will come back soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Onda zuko special. Not sure if that&#39;s what it&#39;s called but there&#39;s Saba, chicken, tofu, rice, hot tea, and spam!

hg7PtnA1SD_YuZAUlcJIfg.text: Super delicious. Got their beef chicken combo and it was HUGE - enough for two! My hubby ordered their combo fried rice and he got beef, chicken. You can't really beat the yummy food for the price. Highly recommend!

C1MToCyfKZygQ7RfWTwiZw.text: Please get some cash before you are stand in the long line. This is a cash only establishment. I was upset because after waiting in line I find out they didn't have any Kalbi. I settled on Teriyaki beef I thought it was good . The macaroni was also tasty but I thought overall the food was average. I would have rather ate at Rice Trax if I knew the food wasn't going to be great.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

-HZG-HV6k0_qYJ49Gw3FPg.text: WHOA!  The familiar sound of Las Vegas is here!  CLINK CLINK CLINK!  A bunch of quarters hitting the bottom of the Slot Machines!!!!    Now back to the review, we waited in a long line and it took a while for us to get our food because of how busy they were.  No worries, patience for this sought out Hawaiian food.  So I got the loco moco and I must say that I think I liked it more because I was starving.  I now think about it and can say that is was just alright, flavors were there but nothing spectacular.  I've definitely had better.  I guess it's just one of those spots you gotta try at least once and then make your decision to try all the other restaurants in Las Vegas before coming back.    Smell you later.

a00fYtdXc-uUyLuX9dafeg.text: Hawaiian food is a nice change in Vegas. Food is average. The portion size is kinda small and they try to make it up with the rice. I ordered a loco moco with over medium eggs, patty was so dry and the egg were cooked completely through.

nL92EZBeYT1y3JP0Pqu8Tw.text: Good food reasonably priced. They could have wowed me a little more with their service. Cashiers seemed a little absent and more concerned with socializing amongst themselves

XTthcZa_n5PnVDdDpRIgVA.text: My husband said the breakfast loco moco was the best he tasted compared to Hawaii's. The 2 eggs breakfast with spam was delicious too.

k4oh1ZtneTaXrckfvAIv9w.text: i'm pretty surprised at the rating here.  i stopped in for a bite and thought it would be tasty.  not so much.  the line was about 5 deep but it was slower than molasses.  i picked the mixed bowl with veggies on the side, mac salad and musubi.  the mixed bowl was just ok but the veggies were gross.  no flavor and soggy.  the mac also didn't have any flavor to it and was mushy.  the spam could use some teri sauce.  there were so many tables that needed to be cleaned.  won't be back.

67XUKKGdheywdZD2ZUAq1g.text: Used to come here all the time. Just visited on 12/15/16, we like the new spacious renovations.   Service: we came up to the front and there were two women, a kind of brash older Filipino lady and another friendly Hawaiian lady with short hair. The friendly woman made conversation and also brought out the food.   Food: we had the hamburger steak ($9.95), the portion was huge and the gravy was delicious but the hamburger was dry and had way too much pepper in it. Also some of the rice was super hard, like rock hard. It is not as good as we remember it to be. My son had the musubi and liked the Teri sauce on it. Soda is free refills, that was really good.   Prices: it has gone up but the portions are huge and are worth it.   Overall: will probably return and maybe eat Saimin the next time

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $2.75 for one musubi
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $9.75- Hamburger Steak- Super Delicious!!

gNnUq4EGtTvVLnuju8DG6A.text: Waited for over 40 minutes for my meal while my buddy got his ten minutes quicker even though I ordered first. I could see that my side item was made first but it was placed on their kitchen counter for over ten minutes as I watched it get cold. They were so understaffed for being Memorial Day Weekend. I felt sorry for the wave of people that came in shortly after we had ordered. The wait staff weren't attentive at all and had to do multiple duties; server, host, cashier etc. They could not multitask for the life of them. A simple 'sorry for the wait' or 'enjoy' would have been fine but nothing. Not a peep. Food was decent but the overall experience was horrible. 2 stars from me is being a bit generous.

hqv8Z5Ts0-4ij1SxlqRN1A.text: Pretty good food.   Cheap prices.   Large portions.   But probably the worst teriyaki sauce ever, gotta step up the teriyaki sauce game.

hS_Et0NqZtC7JX0OesQmlw.text: Very good try of the Hawaii food, better than I had in Hawaii.   big volume. Liked it.  Gives a mixed platter and other mixed choice so u can try different things.

KeGuUPwFQ_wqf-dEYjxOKQ.text: A hidden gem in downtown Vegas. We found out about this place on a food tour and will always come here every time we are in Vegas. Reminds my husband and I of the Hawaiian cuisine when we were last there. So flavorful and delicious!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

MBRISqtRzo11R8fNTUMh5g.text: Awesome food. Just like being at home. The roast pork loco Moco is to die for. They even have live entertainment

ffWbde7npGdQxFT66R7FsQ.text: Aloha Specialties is my go to spot when we are at Fremont Street. This place is located on the second floor of the California Hotel.   Like many reviews say, be prepared to take your time here. There's only one register, so it takes a while to order food and takes time to get your food as well. The wait is definitely worth it!  I always stick with the local plate, wonton min, and the spicy Korean chicken. SO GOOD!! Most plates come with the usual rice and Mac salad. The local plate comes with teriyaki beef/ chicken 2 musubi and Mac salad.   10/10 would go again and keep going!

liV8JRrcf2Vja2_3vR5O8A.text: Remodel is nice. Lots of space and not so cluttered feeling. They take cards, which is also pretty awesome. Our food was ok. The kids got Bento, Loco Moco & chicken teriyaki. Hunny & I split the local plate. Quality wasn't as great as I remember - the spam musubi didn't have enough sauce and my beef teri was cold. Overall, probably just an off night, and we would give them another try if we were downtown.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

iEqACHDU1KswGu9Q8eSgkA.text: Ordered the mix plate which had BBQ chicken/beef, and fish. Very large portion size (they gave a lot of rice). The mac salad was on the salty side. There is a large amount of seating and it wasn't too busy when I went. Overall, pretty decent meal for cheap.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

RxAiGT_PrqsoIubyHzuiAQ.text: #48 review for 2016 Yelp 100 Challenge  When I read and hear yelpers say this place comes close to island food, I had to check it out.   Despite the undesirable smell of cigarette smoke once you enter the casino to get here, I would say it is worth it to try them out.  Overall rating is a solid 3.5 stars.  I wanted so much to fall in love with their garlic fried chicken.  I loved loved their gravy but I seriously did not taste any garlic on them chicken! =/ Their Portuguese sausage was yum alongside their musubi.  In fact, we ordered extra musubi to take with us.   Definitely you get the ohana feeling seeing how the staff works together.   It's a very laid back feel.  I need to go back and give them another try!
