Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spam musubi

B48H18lSA0N46b9oGQe7KA.text: Food average at best, nothing special! Terrible service! Do you have greens to substitute macaroni salad, response was abrupt, "We don't have greens." How about wheat toast? Another abrupt, "No wheat toast." No smile, just a big frown, no thank you, nothing! No Aloha spirit! Wait... isn't "Aloha" part of the name of this restaurant? Experienced more "Aloha" spirit @ the Vegas hotel restaurants. And what restaurant offers hamburgers, but no fries? Seriously?

yOi9IgEoIfqivCbhX4u07g.text: excellent food, excellent friendly service. Big tasty burgers with awesome macaroni salad for 6 bucks. Can't be beat. Best deal in las vegas.

CiFMksArNqF-luuWjcTjMQ.text: Every time I come to Vegas and stay downtown, I always end up making my way to Aloha Specialties because I miss Hawaii food. I pretty much always order a Saimin which is pretty legit, and as my mom always says, it's not just S&S Saimin like another place in Vegas apparently sells. They include kamaboko, and I got mine with wonton last time, which aren't the best wontons I've ever had, but definitely decent.   They also now take credit card! For the longest time they only did cash, so that's more convenient.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wonton min

Ke7D7tk2nElh-y_MgxcoaQ.text: I had the local plate Great spicy korean chicken and teriyaki red but for some reason the spam musubi was not great...too much rice!. Mac salad was delish, another serving please. So took out most of the rice and continued my great meal.  Til I eat you again.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NJGbp1nTI-E9cVbgtpHT4w.text: This place rocks!  The food is delicious!  Try the spicy Korean chicken or the Saimin noodles.  Oh, their mac salad  is some of the best I've had.  Great food at a very reasonable price. Go here, eat and leave very satisfied!

g8yAxsYSTynn-twyyH_mMQ.text: This place has quickly become a staple on all of our Vegas trips.  Since we frequent this area now cause the vibe is so much nicer than the dooshie strip clientele, this has become a must-go for any meal.  I have noticed that I've catered my selection based on the meal too.    Breakfast: Loco Moco.  Classic favorite and well executed here.   Lunch: Kim Chee Saimin.  Soup soothes the soul.   Dinner: Combo plate or Korean Chicken.   Yes, I can come here for all 3 meals... and yes, I actually have before.    BTW, if they're closed, then you're probably on vegas time and haven't seen the sun in a while.  This just means you need to go downstairs and get the ox tail soup.  You're welcome.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kim Chee saimin!

n9IaZ4QjU47GGsUPLzf6uQ.text: Three things about this place.  1. The food is actually really really good. 2. But the service is super super slow. 3. BUT the portion sizing is huge.  This place is your typical Hawaiian diner.  It's probably the best thing you can have at the Cal and Main without having to leave the hotels.  The food here is really good. But the service is super slow.  The people work like on Hawaiian time, never in a rush. But that doesn't stop the line going out the door.  mac salad - a little on the heavier mayo side but really good spam musubi - too much rice to spam ratio but you can never go wrong with a spam musubi. and it's 2.50. a great snack breakfast spam, eggs, and rice - nothing too fancy but it's fantastic in my opinion mixed vegetables - mix of cabbage, bean sprouts, and celery (just an fyi) teriyaki chicken and gravy bowl - super basic. the gravy is not too thick. i wish they didn't leave the skin on the chicken and that the chicken was a little more crispier.

pqvWfo1eCyID0rMafQ6K_g.text: always loved coming here until i found out that Ross J's in henderson is the same owner and similar menu without the long drive.  Anyhow, the food here is always great with friendly and welcoming service.  Food always comes out exactly as expected and I always leave full.

-cQJUoTlh79c5V95iandMA.text: Great place for local Hawaii people who need a taste of home.  Lots of local dishes to choose from.  Expect a big serving of rice!

rNeq7ohJSIlzAXQH9toR0A.text: Aloha Special - Ocha Zuke! Only $12.95! Very popular eatery at California Hotel. Prompt, friendly service by all. The saimin bowls are huge, too!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

g06nyY2udWAuOfk0xG2jxQ.text: After our visit to the Mob Museum in downtown Vegas we came to the Cal Casino close by for some gambling and a late lunch. The Noodle place was closed so we tried the Aloha Specialties Restaurant upstairs. We had teriyaki burger, saimin and won ton min (same as saimin but with dumplings) and spam musubi. Good to have some island food for a change. Portions are good. Weekend hotel garage parking is expensive!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

y3t9jMePwQScyyJjJi-ItQ.text: Used to be a 5 star restaurant and the definite go-to breakfast or lunch spot when staying at the Cal. When I was here this month the wait was pretty bad. There is typically always a wait here, but before they would get through the line quickly and have the food out in no time. This last trip it took 45 minutes to wait in line to order my food. After that was another 20 minutes until my food was served.  I could have used this time to gamble :) This is not a sit down restaurant where a server comes and takes your order. It's like an L&L where you place your own order at the register and they give you a number, so that was a pretty long wait. Previously the entire process would be no more than 20 minutes.   Besides the wait, the food was still just as good as before. Although they removed some of their options from their menu, their Loco Moco is still to die for. For their low prices, you get great tasting food in large quantities.  I'll probably give them another chance, but if they are just as long as the last time, I probably wouldn't wait.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Scramble
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Hamburger steak with gravey
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Loco moco

--EuGqLBptHsesVUpEkEUg.text: Quantity, quality, and price. This place is definitely cheaper than home for plate lunch, saimin and breakfast. We had bbq mix plate and pork tofu. Was broke Da mouth. Only problem...makes it too tempting to just stay on property your entire stay. Mahalos!!!

DRhMKjVhZnc5AIG3cc0dTg.text: Okay let's talk about being on the ninth island and still getting broke da mouth kine food! It was my fiance's first time in Vegas so I suggested we hung out in downtown LV and check out the casinos and stores. We were hangry so I immediately know where to eat in California hotel but YELP wanted to suggest Aloha Specialties because it was new so we immediately agreed to go here instead. Well it definitely did not disappoint!  I got the saimin, 2 musubis, and haupia while my other half got the aloha bento special and side mac salad. The ladies at the counter took our orders really quick and everyone there was so nice and you can feel as if you're home away from home. They gave us a number and we sat down. They brought us our food right away and we started to eat as if we haven't ate for days. The saimin bowl was huuuuuuge! His aloha bento was stacked with meat, the two musubis were big, and the haupia slice was huge also! Everything was delicious and definitely comfort food. We were so full so we saved the musubis for later when we get hungry from walking all over the place. Prices are reasonable and portions are great! We will be back next time we visit.

0MUkbPaev7hU_SyeDYnHqg.text: Probably top 3 places I love to eat in Las Vegas. I haven't had anything I don't like: Saimin, Chicken Tofu Saimin, Spicy Korean Chicken, Chicken Teriyaki, Spam Musubi, Loco Moco, etc. It's all good.

NJB6M1aZEcteL6aAU3hClw.text: Aloha Specialties!!  Can't say enough about this place. This is the ultimate go to place for local kine grindz.   Everything is good here. Today, I got the Won Ton Min. Humongous bowl of noodles with char siu, fish cake and won tons. Perfect for a cold day in Vegas. Don't forgot the hot mustard!!  Only open until 9PM, so get here early and they take credit cards.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Won Ton Min

rBleUWegJ7LnY5df68KYBA.text: If there's one thing I miss about living in Hawai'i, it's the food!   Somehow, my mom convinced us to dine here this past Sunday during one of the busiest weekends of the year in Downtown Las Vegas. We made our way to The Cal, which by the way is THE hotel to stay in if you're from Hawai'i, in case you didn't know. Vegas isn't nicknamed the 9th Island for no apparent reason, people! We reached the top of the escalator and my god, I've never seen a line so long for a plate lunch!  This was my first time dining at Aloha Specialties, so I wasn't too sure if the line was always this long or if it was just because we were waiting with a third of the festival goers from Life Is Beautiful. We patiently waited for about 45 minutes or so before placing our order, but I didn't mind because it gave my indecisive ass some time to figure out what I was in the mood for.   I was back and forth between the Hamburger Steak with grilled onions or the Spicy-Korean Chicken. My sister ended up ordering the Spicy-Korean Chicken and I figured I could just sample hers and order my Hamburger Steak! Winning!  The portions at Aloha Specialties are more than generous. Let's just say that I couldn't even see my plate because it was completely covered with rice and brown gravy. I love my rice, I'm Filipino for crying out loud! But I personally think that my plate came with way too much rice. Not to mention the size of the Hamburger Steak was about the size of the plate. Talk about overwhelming! The Hamburger Steak was thin and crispy, just how I like it, but it could've used a little salt. There's no way I would be able to finish my meal alone. Can you say kanak attack?  Spicy-Korean Chicken- Not your typical Korean fried chicken! Aloha Specialities nailed it with this one. The chicken is extremely flavorful and moist, but the best part is the crispiness of the skin!   My mom swears by their saimin! I tried some of the broth and it was just okay to me. Not the best, but it wasn't bad either. There was a big variety of vegetables in it too.  As a (now) Vegas local, I appreciate the fact that there are many options to choose from when I'm missing the flavors of the islands and Aloha Specialties is now on my go-to list for when I'm craving a taste of home. I would highly recommend this joint to everyone. Great food and friendly service.   Shoot, even the Hawai'i locals can't stay away from the food when on vacation here in Las Vegas! Needless to say, the line is worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. The line from the inside of the restaurant
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy-Korean Chicken
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin

vHxBTkLirYXLwQQi1f8uxA.text: This restaurant serves island food like saimin, Loco Moco, curry, spam, etc... We had the Korean chicken, musubi, and teri chicken and beef bowls. The chicken was good, but the beef could have been better. The musubi was warm and yummy. The Korean chicken was just spicy enough with rice. Food was good.  The restaurant is located in the second floor off the Cailfornia. It has one register and you get in line to order. The menu is on the wall and clear for you to see and order from. Be prepared to wait since it is cooked when you order it.

NSu3CfI6WTlyjTARXMizcA.text: I would say this is as good as it gets when it comes to Hawaiian food.  I've been to Hawaii many times and this is pretty spot on.  The serving size is great.  Me and my husband shared a Local Plate, that came with two spam masubi's, teriyaki chicken and beef and mac salad.  We also shared a wonton saimin soup.  It was a huge bowl and we didn't even finish it.  I'm not too crazy about the wontons but the saimin broth and noodle was very yummy.  This place is very busy.  You line up and order your food then you grab your seat.  The turn over is very fast lots of people eating here and the wait is worth it.  The price of our bill was only $20 and we were stuffed.   Dont' forget to save your receipt to get your parking validated.

GmZPKcTQN51iWMBFvJoqdg.text: So whenever I'm in Las Vegas, I try and stop here for their Hawaiian food. I usually get the local plate and. Of course extra Spam Masubi. Very friendly staff. If you go during peak times expect a line. A lot of Hawaiians eat here so it seems pretty authentic .

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Local plate, chicken beef, Mac salad and Spam masubi. Very filling .

vxQeqgcbUfLP2mJ9R3F27A.text: AS is a nice option for some simple Japanese Hawaiian grub. The only thing that keeps plaguing me is that the rice is always inconsistently mushy. My friend's spam musubi didn't have mushy rice but 1 of my 2 was. And my combo plate had. Wed that was overlooked and cut in small bits. The Portuguese sausage never disappoints but really can't mess that up too much when cooking it.   The service is always spot on. So I always have mixed feelings. There just isn't an option like it in Vegas and sometimes you want homecooked food.   Renovated interior but food could still use an upgrade.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

NN---2sDqS9rJaiRFoLfKw.text: WOW! Today was my first time here and it was love at first bite. I ordered Korean spicy chicken. It came with a side of macaroni salad and rice. The chicken was so juicy and the right amount of spicy for that little kick. I also tried their spam and eggs (makes a great addition to the Korean spicy chicken plate). I also had a bite of my girlfriends teriyaki combo plate. Which is 3 different meats covered in teriyaki sauce. I should say I had more than 1 bite because that was so good as well. Oh and the plates are huge so you'll have plenty leftovers.  The staff was very fast and friendly. The restaurant itself was pretty big and very clean.  I'm in Vegas a lot and this place has now been added to my list of places I have to eat while I'm here.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spicy Korean chicken with a side of spam and eggs

HcwVyFDTL2CqtZBtJFVBCw.text: This is the place for a little taste of aloha in downtown located in the CAL. The masubi is always a go to grab and go snack. I wish they opened a little earlier and stayed open a little later, but it's well worth a little extra planning to hit this place to satisfy your cravings.  The Aloha Combos, Island Favorites and Noodles make for a perfect meal. If I am in the area just after 9 (opening time) it makes for a great breakfast as well. Service can be a little slow, but that's mostly because the food comes out fresh. All the food is available to go as well. I often find myself picking something up to stash in the room for later when staying at the CAL. They close at 9, except Friday and Saturday when they are open an hour later. The staff is always friendly and the prices are very fair.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

1LQDKBs4eTSLzOo7YN_3ww.text: Great tasting food and great value. Large amount of food for a meal price that's lower than most casino restaurants. This is located on the 2nd floor mezzanine area of The California, so take the escalator up to find it. I ordered the aloha bento and enjoyed it. Portion sizes are huge and I took over half of my food in a to-go box. Two people could certainly split one of these plates. My only complaint is that the mahi mahi was over-cooked and dry, but the taste and cooking of the rest of the meats and sides made up for that.

EhPo2HXfKP3SkEZGaNhLKA.text: Affordable, filling, unique...this is the place to hang out after some late night gambling and strolling on Fremont Street Experience.  The small quaint store is located inside the California Hotel on the top floor. It's not a place to be missed with its bright open French doors and some "outside" seating.  I ordered the local plate consisting of teriyaki beef& chicken, rice, mac salad, and musubi. I also ordered a side of coconut haupia for dessert.  The teriyaki sauce was plentiful, sweet, and savory. It pairs wonderfully with the marinated beef, chicken, and white rice.   Next comes the musubi which is basically nori wrapped around white rice slathered with teriyaki sauce and spam. Despite the simplicity of this food, the sweet teriyaki sauce and the saltiness of the spam with the rice combines wonderfully. Additionally, the crispy nori yields a snappy crunch as you bite into the soft warm rice.  Next comes the mac salad which is macaroni mixed with celery, mayo, and carrot shreds. The mac salad is creamy, sweet, and cold. It's a surprisingly delightful contrast to the main course and provides the warm and salty tongue a rest.  At last comes the coconut haupia (by the way, I'm filled to the brimmed with food at this point). The coconut haupia has an interesting jello/pudding texture and oozes of coco-nutty aroma. The sweet and creamy dessert is extraordinarily light even though it was made with coconut milk.  In conclusion, this place is worth a visit for a taste of simplicity, warmth, and no-frill home cooked Hawaiian meal.

Hwuxr3JXyXjacjdHDhc-cg.text: Service always sucks. If they had competition, I'm pretty sure they'd go down under. Aloha Specialities? More like Aloha Slow ASF! Horrible service, mediocre food? Consider yourself lucky your restaurant is in a casino full of Hawaiians l. Or business would plummet compared to every other Hawaiian restaurant in Vegas.

CoNY0ZldfJDwjOEJe6k_Jg.text: Brought our friends here for lunch and the decor of this place has been upgraded, new menu, bright decor and just more attractive and comfortable plus they take credit cards besides cash now.  We ordered the kalua pork plate, the local plate and the garlic chicken.  The portions were humongous!  Food is tasty but the macaroni salad was alittle on the bland side.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kalua pork
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Local plate
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic chicken

Xko1DdRvQm_6wTZrIzsisQ.text: Omg.. the wait is ridiculous.. my partner and i went there around 2pm and it took almost 20min to order and another 20min for food to be served.. the food was O.K. .. the service is very very slowwwww..

gE4mYlx41X9tFIm4JfvNVw.text: This place is on my top five places to eat in Vegas. Coming from Louisiana, going here was something foreign to me, and if it wasn't for my uncle, I wouldn't have known anything about it! I came hungry, empty stomach, and craving something filling! As I read through fellow yelp reviews, I noticed one thing out of everything, the Loco Moco...  Drizzled in gravy, topped with a fried egg, and what seems to be pork or meat loaf over a bed of rice. This was like HEAVEN. If you're hungry and in the mood for something with an explosion of flavors, do yourself a favor and order it. Loco Moco. Write it down. Memorize it. Love it. Feel it. Eat it.   Other then that, the restaurant is located inside of a casino so sitting outside of the restaurant is optional, but it might be a little intoxicating due to the heavy amounts of tobacco smoke coming from everyone else. So, if you have kids or just can't handle the smell of tobacco (don't worry, I can't either), sit inside and enjoy your meal!

_YvayA36HsQyg-Txgbm9TQ.text: The staff was excellent, but  food was meh- not bad, just bland, nothing special about it. Portions were good, though, so this would be good for big appetites.

lYjq22lVYCjsQ6VMhIFzAw.text: This totally reminds me of being back home in Hawaii!  They even have fruit punch!  Prices are pretty cheap, and the servings are HUGE!!!  They have tons of local favorites.  They even have furikake...you just have to ask.  They give 1 free refill per drink order.    my group has ordered the loco moco, spam eggs rice, garlic chicken with gravy, korean combo (chicken & beef), spam musubi, fruit punch...all DELISH!  The only thing that wasn't all that was the beef in the korean combo.  It was a little on the tough side.  the mac salad is so good!!!  This place is cash only.  Don't forget to tip the servers.  Be prepared to be surrounded by all local folks.  Highchairs are a little on the dirty side.  Take-out supplies are conveniently located near the tables for self-service.  =)  I always come here every time I'm in LV.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wall menu.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic chicken with gravy.
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean chicken &amp; beef combo

tKeczN9kAmSzhhZ9ykLHtA.text: Great little local cafe serving some bomb Hawaiian eats on the 2nd floor of the Cal.  Order from the counter and then grab a seat in the cafe.  Prices are all reasonable and around $10 bucks are so.  Was here for breakfast so had to go with the Loco Moco, very delicious and their gravy was on point.

H-QilluSDyVqTdeu3RmHLg.text: Spam Musubi, Portugese Sausage, Hawaiian Breakfast... A perfect way to start a day in LV. The Saimen is the best cure for hangovers.

_86loC3I_sJAoDbmu58lQg.text: Great place to get some brunch before leaving Vegas after your weekend trip.  My friends and I always try to make a stop here as it reminds us of home.

6_AnhxFqyGqCoawcpo3JWQ.text: Good local food from Hawaii. It's a more cafeteria style service but the food here is great. Btw no credit cards here but only cash is accepted here

9IMspMUnNWQ1cY4ibiZZKg.text: Such simple food but so good!  I had the Saimen and the boy had the Loco Moco. We honestly didn't realize how much food that was because we also had the Spam Musubi. Get everything you want to try on the menu, because its delicious.   Highly recommend the spam musubi!

s5rlPx_XgLcgMPTGUKZwnw.text: Ordered 1 spam musubi.. took 20 minutes to get 1 spam musubi.... store had 5 tables that were already eating.

DL3UiofB7k-GTYhohH4bEA.text: We couldn't wait for the renovations to be done & we were so excited to finally make it down there after they reopened. What a huge DISAPPOINTMENT! They raised the prices and the portion sizes shrank. And of course, the wait time in line remains atrocious. We will definitely not be making the special trip downtown to eat here again.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. This is the Local plate. $11 for this?!? Portions were smaller than a plate from a kids menu.

KG_PgOCh0RSKj0cI_WmFRg.text: If you want authentic Hawaiian food, (which is why people come to Vegas, right?) then this is the place. There's a reason that the Hawaiian's here on vacation eat here...again, not sure why you eat Hawaiian food when you're in Vegas...but there are always friendly, happy, and hungry islanders here so you know the food is good! Food is all cooked fresh and the portions are huge. Never order extra rice because rice plates come with huge scoops. Our favorites are the garlic chicken plate ($8.95) which comes with rice and macaroni salad. The saimin is also yummy. Small is big, large is huge! Teri chicken is generous and beef is tender. Teri chicken is okay too. Go for breakfast )but they don't open until 9am), lunch or dinner (close at 9pm). You won't be disappointed!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Casual, friendly place!

4ag0x2YgbH8jENAL4wcZBA.text: Saw the high Yelp reviews for this place, and we were staying in the adjoining Main Street Station, so we ended up in here for dinner one night.  We got there around 7, and there was a line of maybe a dozen folks ahead of us.  I had the saimin (good, but nothing special), as well as the garlic chicken.  GF got the combo plate that had Korean beef and chicken, along with the obligatory rice and macaroni salad.  This isn't fine dining by any stretch - presentation isn't really a concern, and we're not talking about any crazy complimentary flavors or subtle undertones or anything.  Portions are large - GF and I could easily have just split the combo plate and been more than full.  Solid, stick-to-your-ribs, Hawaiian style food.  The beef and chicken were solid, maybe a bit fatty, but that's to be expected.  Cash only was a bit of a surprise, but fortunately I hadn't handed over all my money on the blackjack tables.  This is one of those places that looks like a hole in the wall, but looks like it's always packed.  Large portions and great bang for the buck.  Not amazing food, but a great value, especially if you're craving Hawaiian style.

WfMPq7QmnZvU_FVpMjzgXQ.text: I didn't REALLY want to go, but I'm a convert on the 1st try!  F'ing AWESOME food.   Kalua Pig and Cabbage...delicious! Side Macaroni salad - MMGOOD!  Spam and Egg Sandwich - Canned sodium goodness!  Chicken Tofu Siamen - Tofu sooo soft and tasty! The broth was good (a bit too salty).  Quick service, excellent food and great prices!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Kaula pork....mmgood
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

3skRTBsedRNQf6ng5FYSdw.text: If you want some tasty reasonably priced hawaiian food this is the place to go. Its inside of the California hotel and casino on the second floor. This past time I ordered the aloha breakfast which came with eggs, rice, spam, Portuguese sausage and what they call luncheon meat. Very filling meal and if youre in the mood for breakfast it hits the spot. The spam was  not too soft had a slight crisp to it (just the way I like it) and the Portuguese sausage had goof flavor. The luncheon meat was interesting. I would compare it to a thick piece of bologna.   You seat yourself here and order at the cashier. There's only one cashier so when it gets busy you may have to wait. They only accept cash here so dont be coming in with a credit card. But then again you're at a casino so getting money shouldn't be an issue.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aloha brrakfast

rlu2x-qHgkiidUVeBiKBVA.text: Probably the coziest little diner I've ever been to. Aloha specialties reminded me very much like an Asian styled Denny's.   My girlfriend and I ordered the loco moco and the aloha breakfast. The loco moco came with 2 eggs over a beef looking Patty on a bed of rice surrounded in some curry sauce. I somewhat enjoyed the dish, but the patty was not to flavorful to satiate my taste buds. I'd honestly rate the loco moco 3/5. The aloha breakfast came with a medley of meats. The Portuguese sausage was very very flavorful. I thought the luncheon meat was spam, but it was something different. Very sweet and delicious. Then the last piece of meat spam. My honest rate on the aloha breakfast would be a hard 5/5.   Very delicious indeed. Only reason I went 4/5 stars was the taste factor. I usually eat a bit salty so could be the reason why.

rJF6JDeU7WcBdknax-v6Jw.text: This place was okay. Most of the reviews rave about the Korean chicken and as a first timer that's also what one of the employees recommended. I mean Korean chicken at a Hawaiian restaurant? I guess! It literally tasted like my mom's (Vietnamese) chicken but sweeter. Which of course isn't bad but I was really expecting something amazing, especially with all of the reviews. The portions are very generous, however. You will have to share or have lots of leftovers ! (Which is always nice). I wish this place had katsu but it doesn't. Their spam masubi was meh; seaweed was too hard to bite through. Also their Mac salad. MAC SALAD. Super generous portions but super bland. You're just eating mayo !

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean chicken

FQ63hgLYVo-08x1ePt1gPA.text: This place offers amazing and affordable food! They are located on the second floor of the the California hotel/casino...  The food is really fresh and authentic! They have anything from soups to rice bowls... we ordered the Wonton Saimin, which has eggs, char sui pork and veggies with ramen noodles. Their spam masubi's a great appetizers and their garlic chicken is a must! If you are in downtown Las Vegas and are looking for a quick, cheap and delicious meal, I would definitely check this place out! You walk up and order at the counter and the seats are first come first serve.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Spam Masubi
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Garlic Chicken Plate
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Wonton Saimin

J4HRTpeRPk2aO42WfjfYgw.text: Been coming here for years and the place never disappoints.  Whether you want breakfast, lunch or dinner the food is consistently good.  I recommend the Loco Moco, Garlic Chicken, Saimin, Spam Musubi, BBQ Plates and you pretty much can't go wrong with whatever you order.  Reasonable prices, portions are good too, so you shouldn't leave hungry.

CA2V2wb099fTR-MbWuzXAw.text: The food here is as close to Hawaii anywhere I have found here on the main land. Prices are okay food is better but the service is slow but maybe because they're on Hawaii time. Mahalo!

iL6WxxWwgpqmlBDQHCIivg.text: You wouldn't expect this Hawaiian restaurant on the 2nd floor of a casino to have amazing food..... But it's amazing! The cheeseburger was so savory and juicy! I wanted to get more. I was originally upset I couldn't get fries with my burger but the macaroni salad is a perfect palette pleaser to accompany the burger. My friends orders the Flash Bowl, with chicken and beef (teriyaki on rice) and is was also sweet and delicious! The place is spacious and a nice calm getaway from the Vegas Fremont, just a block away. They only thing is that they only take cash!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. $4 awesome cheeseburger!!
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Flash Bowl, chicken and beef teriyaki

JigFLMgQIte65rGON45yuw.text: This spot is where the crew goes for bfast but more like lunch because its vegas! Its a homestyle spot with all of Hawaii's best. The prices are a deal considering ppl would pay more in vegas and the portions are big. The loco moco is a hangover bfast definately hits the spot. Masubi is a great side. The best thing on the menu is the korean chicken! I can eat only korean chicken everyday for the rest of my life .. Game over!

TQeF5H3Qde5sOQq9iSxqXw.text: I would eat here every day if I could.  Prices have gone up since i started going but it has been a few years.  This place is awesome, and I am not hawaiian.  I can only speak about the chicken rice bowl cause thats all I ever get.

b-ya8-kwLeksTFNGYwU5VQ.text: I'm going on a whim and give this place 5 stars. Why? There's just no place to describe "comfort food" than this place for me. Their prices hasn't gone up also so that was another plus. Their saimen I like better than ...Hamura's in Lihue. There's really nothing out of the ordinary here (they have the usual spam musubi, saimen, beef and chicken teri, etc) Here's a pic of the menu board: static.px.yelp.com/bphot... I would give them 3 stars but then I realized that I had this place on speed dial from my previous phone, I knew either I had a eating problem or this place has really been good to me. Well....some of you know I have an eating problem, but that's another story. Came this past weeknd and got: Chicken over rice bowl: $2.95 Way better than Yoshinoya! static.px.yelp.com/bphot... Saimen with Wonton: $3.50+ $1.50 Their wonton is all meat, no veggies and no shrimp. However, it goes great with their saimen and stock. static.px.yelp.com/bphot... Garlic chicken with Gravy: $7.00 Same chrispy skinned chicken but with gravy. Heart attack on a plate! static.px.yelp.com/bphot... Haupia: $1.25. I thought it was a bit chaulky but I'm glad to finish a meal with something semi sweet and tasty. I am going to add them to my speed dial list cuz I no like waiting 20 minutes in line.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

h44VcZycsKqLWdoBdR5cFA.text: We ordered a mixed plate and saimin. Portions are pretty generous.  Will come back again.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Mixed plate was pretty good.

m6grF9tQut94HZhj-TDKuA.text: Although I've been here many times, I've finally found my number one dish!  Listen, I can overlook the smokey casino outside and the outdated carpet and tables.  It's that good!  I got the Aloha Bento for $8.75!  Man this plate is AH-MAZE-ING!  Let's start with a bed of rice, seasoned with furikake, a seaweed seasoning.  Then you have Teriyaki beef, Korean chicken, Redondo red hot dog and mahi mahi.  My gosh!  Worth every penny.  Let's start with the tender and nicely grilled Teriyaki beef.  The sauce really makes it taste like home.  Then you have the hotdog, sliced in half and grilled.  This hot dog is only embraced in Hawaii.  I grew up on this and love it!  It's red, which is weird to some, but awesome to others!  Then the Korean chicken was super flavorful.  Grilled chicken thigh.  The sauce seemed to stick well and such a nice tangy taste to it!  Last but not least, the mahi mahi was breaded with egg and topped with a light tartar sauce. Probably the best part of the dish.  I've grown to love all types of fish and breaded mahi mahi has to be one of my top 5 favorites.  The tartar sauce really pulls the taste together and brings a very light element to the overall dish.    Man, I'm so glad I chose this meal.  Now I know what I'm getting from now on and will definitely be back next week.  Gosh, I hope you have the opportunity to try it!  So delicious :)

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aloha Bento for $8.75
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Aloha Bento to go for $8.95

PTJR4MJNV15paTPAxsFAuQ.text: I visit this restaurant every September when I'm in town for the LVI basketball tournament.  I've been coming here since 2007 - either my taste buds have changed or the food quality has  dropped.  The place is always crowded this time of the year and prices are very reasonable. I will continue to eat here regardless of a single good or bad experience  Highly recommended for those staying at Main Street Station or The Californian - I wouldn't go out of my way to eat here though.  *September 2013

uODgMvcJlG_Iz_1z_YRN1g.text: My saimen fix always good ;) every time when family comes to the mainland we usually hit up the cal :)

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. &#34;Wonton saimen yummmmy good hangover fooooodddddie&#34;
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Huge Teri chicken bowl

5dlFa-_PGJbsVBntI8ddlw.text: My family and I had to eat at this little restaurant while visiting because a) were from Hawaii b) so badly craving a loco moco and some spam!   Its a small restaurant up stairs, and really inexpensive food.   If you are missing loco grindz (food) and need you portuguese sausage, saimen, loco moco, beef stew, etc fix- this is your place.   Its inexpensive, away from the smokey casino and you're bound to run into other Hawaii locals.

pEqzx7srzcVjb9lFSr8q4Q.text: This place is phenomenal! Randomly located in the Cali casino, you know it's going to be good when it's packed. Staff was pleasant and efficient, and the food...oh the food! We got the aloha bento which is a combo platter of mahi-mahi, teriyaki chicken and beef, and a red hot dog over rice. Also, we got a bowl of Saimin, (noodles and pork in broth), a side of spam and kimchi. It was all amazing, we housed all of it like we hadn't eaten in days! Cheap for what you get. Oh yeah, CASH ONLY!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States

f-9AgEbs4jEfeFqQSNbBOQ.text: Not going to pretend I'm from Hawaii or anything and say that this place is authentic. However, after visiting Hawaii and eating plenty of the local food, I can say that it comes somewhat close.   I love me some hamburger steak so that's what I ordered. There wasn't enough gravy but the taste, rice and mac salad made up for that. I enjoyed it very much.   My family and I shared the large saimin noodle. The soup wasn't very tasty (I think I'm just used to ramen broth) but everything in it was good. It just wasn't like "OMG THIS IS DELICIOUS."  We also had some korean chicken, which was pretty good. I would have preferred it to be crispy all over just not on one side though :p   Overall, it was a great meal and the portions are a good size. I think it's a tad pricy, but it IS in a casino (California Hotel and Casino). The line is long, so expect to wait. Also, seating is limited. I would come back if I had some extra time during my next Vegas trip and was seeking some comfort food.

futytI87U_td2sS6XiNNAA.text: Mahalo's I love your locomoco and macaroni salad

XMbpjmF4cvWNt_kF2t9fTQ.text: I've been going to this place since the days of the first Street Fighter II and before they expanded the restaurant. 11:00am  misses the lunch rush. There is barely a line, but steady.  I pretty much still get the same order. You cannot go wrong with the teri chicken bowl, kim chi, and fruit punch. Their poke is fantastic and they give you a lot of it. The orders come to the table quick style. HIGH FIVE!!!  I always leave this place with the itus. Thank you Aloha Specialties for ALWAYS coming through.

ToLTVJjjF0PM6v21Rh1IeQ.text: Been coming here since I was a kid and the food has gone down a little in taste but I still love this place for the nostalgia.  I highly recommend the saimin (don't forget to get the hot mustard) and any of the teriyaki plates.    Of an important note, this place only takes cash and the lines can be long and seats are sometimes limited.  However, if you're looking for some good Hawaiian comfort food, you gotta come here.

indZug7c99heAZZjo009UQ.text: We had the flash, loco moco, garlic chicken, spicy korean chicken everything was good! They also have a great customer service! My friend didnt like her first order and they immediately replaced it according to her liking! no questions asked!

anN8b9jnCsMG98kl6i2B3w.text: Ninth Hawaiian Island indeed.  The prices here are reasonable, but the line was long.  In terms of Hawaiian food, this place is a little disappointing.  I felt like there was way more rice on my plate than I needed, while lacking in the chicken department.

f4JRXhlYs6PBpMIWybpQKA.text: If you enjoy hawaiian food or need to fuel up before hitting the table, this place is great for big portions of tasty grub. The only drawback is they can take awhile to complete your order.

v8AKtUGQMMSTHuIiJiGeCQ.text: Customer service here is pretty bad... Guess they ran out of the boiled peanuts and while waiting one of the girls come by and said "we are returning your money we ran out of boiled peanuts" she didn't even offer to ask "can we get you something else"?? She was just really RUDE!  I am not going back here!  Food was just okay.

2YM_rxaaPlA9X3xxujg-rg.text: The BF and I take his mom and grandma for lunch.   The BF got teriyaki ribeye- the meat was thin sliced and pretty soft. It's thick style teriyaki sauce which I'm not sure if I'm fond of, but its True Hawaiian style.   I got the garlic chicken with gravy- this was decent, but it was stingy with the gravy and my 3rd piece was a bit burnt on the bottom....burnt garlic flavor is no bueno. I was debating between this or the ocha zuke bento. The family all ordered a plate, but we shared so I picked the more "family friendly" dish since the inlaws dont like fish.    BF and I shared a ahi poke- It was okay. The cut of the fish isn't very uniform with small pieces being really marinated and some pieces being 4x it's size. They give you a good amount for the $4.95, but it's better to go to a poke deli if what you're wanting is good poke and thinking of coming here for it.  Mom got korean chicken- the BF and I loved this dish at Ross J's and hearing the two are associated by owners, we thought this would be a way to let her try it. It was good, but not nearly as good as Ross J's. They make the skin there crispy a bit so it's not nearly as fatty feeling with the skin.   Grandma got chopped beef steak- this was pretty good stir fry with beef, bean sprouts, bell peppers, onions. She enjoyed it, but she took a piece of the korean chicken and liked it better.   Each plate was about $8 so 4 plates, poke, and 4 drinks came up to $45ish so it was okay pricing, but I've had cheaper for better.   Now, parking at the California is a plain fucking bitch. There's always a lack of space for the amount of people going here. We had to find parking elsewhere and wheelchair his grandma over on the street. They are pretty good about taking orders at a good pace so if you see a long line, it'll probably be about 10-15 minutes.   Being a place with a line, a positive rating and a place associated to Ross J's (which we do really like), I was expecting a lot of ono. Not that it's a no-no, but it's just good food, not great food. It's not what I would say is worth the trouble and the wait . In the time it took us to find parking we could've gone to Henderson and took the family on a lil mini trip. Next time, we're gonna make the drive to Ross J's for the craving and skip this place.   The Aloha I was looking for isn't this.

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Chopped beef steak

gpUHoqhMDDcNdtI-t16Urg.text: Aloha Specialties makes some of the best Hawaiian type food outside of Hawaii.  It could be because most of the customers come from Hawaii so they want to make it as authentic as possible.  First off, when you go here, order the Korean Chicken.  It's a bit spicy but if you like the heat like I do then "you will love this.". The more people the merrier...so you can try some of your friends dishes as well, like their Local Plate that comes with Spam Musubi.  What is Spam Musubi?  Well, it's spam sushi-style.  It's CASH ONLY here so bring some greenbacks with you.  It's located inside the California Hotel & Casino.  Parking is free for 4 hours after validation near the cashier cage.  Aloha Specialties is a great place to try out some Hawaiian cuisine if you've never had it before.  Enjoy!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Saimin
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Local Plate
Photo of Aloha Specialties - Las Vegas, NV, United States. Korean Chicken

cU08i4yk2lWahipJPm23wA.text: For a Local Hawaiian place this is pretty good.  The food tastes good, cheap prices and its as close as it gets to a plate lunch place in Hawaii. If you are feeling like Local food, go here. Chicken Teri / Garlic chicken is good....Teri Burger, Mahi mahi, Fried Saimin, Saimin and Loco Moco are good too. The specials are always good, Local plate, Mix plate, Teri plate. Almost everything they have is good or what Ive tried so far, even their musubi's are good, top with fruit punch and whoooaaa....Overall good place to grind but may be busy since this is a favorite to many people....

6cCuleQac7laBfyxGI-eRA.text: Delicious authentic Hawaiian food. I had the shoyu chicken and it came with all the fixens. Sticky rice and macaroni salad. It was da bomb! I couldn't eat very much of it though as I didn't want to get full before eating at Alex for dinner. We also ordered some poke which was as good as you can get it in Hawaii. Will definitely be coming back here for a tasty lunch whenever in Vegas. The only problem is we have to go down to Fremont. :(

zpShWUCZz6txx2eebNvCpw.text: My friend took me to this restaurant on a recent Vegas trip since I love Hawaiian food. The restaurant is inside the California hotel. It's a perfect give-a-way that it is a good one when there are a lot of Hawaiians roaming around the casino and hotel. I ordered one of my all time fave, loco moco. Boy was it good!!! My friend ordered saimin and the soup just reminded me of Shige's. I would definitely come here again and try one of their lunch plates. There's also a Lappert's Ice Cream right across that sells malasadas but you need to go get the malasadas early cause they sell out pretty fast.

h6LwmCA511dadD8lFd-OSA.text: Mahalo! Best Hawaiian cafe in town. Prices are reasonable, food is mighty tasty and done right. Best Loco Moco and Spam Musubi around, the gravy is flavorful and the Spam was cripy. Been coming here for at least 10+ years. Sometimes there are long line esp. on weekends when the Hawaiian tours are in so expect to wait 20 minutes to place your order. Its fast food so don't expect to much for service once you get your food but the staff is always friendly and helpful. And remember its cash only so find an ATM first.

J9xc3DZ8vYu7VOvVNle1dg.text: Whenever you are in vegas and craving hawaiian food, this is the place to go. My favorite is the saimin with a spam musubi.

6MGXMvocsWSNt2tOiSjtwg.text: Never had a complaint about this place. Service is good, people are nice, and food is good. I mean you can't mess up spam, eggs, and rice. I mean someone probably could, but that person would deserve to get beaten with a stick immediately.. Other meals are also good. And for some weird reason, it doesn't take 5 years to get your meal. We sat down and received our order in less then 10 minutes! Closer to 5 probably! Nice..

PfN2mdl7KSoIC74T9CGJVw.text: My vegas vacations would not be complete with out stopping here for my lau lau plate,saimin and teri sticks...This is the place where people from the hawaiian islands come to eat to get their taste of home....everything here is onolishes(very good).Authentic local food,plates big enough to take some back to your room for later.Don't be surprised if there is a long line.It's worth the wait...Come here and enjoy.(p.s. the sports book is on the same floor around the corner.So can run and go place your parlay card while you are eating)..heehee..Enjoy aloha specialties in one of my favorite towns.....Vegas baby!!!!!!!!!!!

T9k4fd9ntqRf81ZTKglQHw.text: I have been eating at this restaurant for twenty years.  I usually get a teri chicken bowl with extra teri and split a small wonton saimin with my wife. I also enjoy their mac salad.  The prices are reasonable, but the location takes time to get to.  There is often a long line when I get there (a good sign for quality), so I now call ahead and bypass the line to pick up my order.  Highly recommended.

YXziXcK5z85Z2B-ZhzYhOQ.text: Had the Korean BBQ combo plate and large saimin bowl... boooomb. This is a regular spot for me and my bf when we go to vegas. And the last time we went, we saw that Hawaiian guy from "Forgetting Sarah Marshall" :) If you're a fan of Hawaiian food, you have to try it out.

6oo02MfR6nMTR8S6S3irHQ.text: many years ago, in one of my many trips to vegas, i was brought here from a then co-worker at one of our 'business' trips.  i remember it being so good, so comforting, and at normal prices.  i hadnt returned until now, about 8-9 years later.  man.. ooooooh man!  quickly: we went here TWICE in a 2 day vegas trip.  this is how good it is.  I ordered the chicken plate the first time and was just blown away at the taste.  I mean, i looked at the plate and could probably count up the ingredients for all the items on my plate in 2 hands.  super simple, super good.  the chicken was skin-on, thigh meat.  3 big pieces on a bed of fresh sticky rice and a big scoop of mac salad.  good to the last scrape of the plate...   2nd time around this trip, i had the ribeye plate.  2 thin cut slices, on the bed of rice and mac salad.  My brother got the local plate, which should be renamed to the LOVE plate, cuz it had love all over it.  it was Chicken and  Beef teri, and 1 spam musubi + rice & mac salad.    great grub at normal prices (not vegas prices), but the only downer part is that this place is downtown and not on the strip (~$20 cab ride each way).. i was tripping, so im still giving this place full blast Yelp kudos.  5 bangers

OOJuMBQcUvZLCfLW54HIfw.text: I like the pork chops and the saimin.  Great Hawaiian food at great prices.

H4ln_INbqkrLiMLgLT1ELQ.text: Cutie cafe on 2nd floor of Calif Hotel.  You get in line, order your food and wait at your table to be served.  Got the local plate w/ teri beef and chicken, mac and 2 spam musubi's.  Pretty good. Took the musubi on the road for later.  The best part of the experience was hearing one of the employees talk 'bout his "cuzin" won 80 grand at Keno downstairs. It's always someone's cuzin in Hawaii!  Love it~

yNM0PpUY_T6RZTtEufVIsg.text: If you are on a low-carb diet you can order the saiman without noodles and with veggies instead. I think I was charged around ~$4. They gave me bean sprouts and napa. Also still had the roast pork with it. Still a decent serving size and was pretty filling.

coE_lTEWnQ8-xhMq7iy12w.text: If you want some good Hawaiian grub at the Fremont, this is the place to go. I would recommend sticking with the rice dishes such as the loco moco since the ramen (saimin) were just ok. Keep in mind, this is cash only. Aloha!

7Q02DBpUcoxycpfd0tISCw.text: Two of my roommates in college were from Hawaii, so I had some beta and ordered the Kahlua pig. Mmmm....soooo good. Very juicy and tender, but not too salty. Even better, I asked them for some gravy on the side to pour on my rice and they gave me a small cup and later a soup bowl of it to share with the table. I picked out the cabbage though...not a big fan and didn't seem to go well with the pork and gravy. You must add their gravy to your rice, it makes it like 10x better. Not kidding.

lRmGIbGdW0hfiGMs_mTHOg.text: Yeah, food looks to be ok.  But I didn't fly 2500 miles to eat loco moco and saimin.  Don't get me started on the oxtail soup at the Cal.

nP-xuWa_J7Qvwbg7pb1YEw.text: Local food....spam musubi and teri chicken bowls are grubbin!  I got the beef stew this past weekend....it was good...just the right portion not tooooo much!  if you go on tourney weekend the lines are hella long....so be prepared!   like j said you have to know the trick! :)

3Snm93mrBEkg6EXYHhRNVA.text: I love Aloha Specialties.  Not necessarily for the quality of food, though it is good.  I love Specialties for what it implies:  when I'm eating at Specialties, it means that I'm in Vegas!  I always get the Portuguese sausage, scrambled eggs, and rice with a side order of chicken teri.  Maybe a spam musubi to go.

mM9Y5LWNNqzCw0-TfbfmMw.text: ugggh , i can't even bare to read aLL the good feedback this restaurant got . 2 stars is being EXTREMELY generous . when i Lived in Vegas years ago , my famiLy & i used to ALWAYS go here & it was thee Biz . i recentLy went here the first week of january when i was visiting & it was pathetic . food was bLand , service was whomp whomp , they have NO chicken katsu , & they ONLY accept cash . Like seriousLy , it's 2011 ... get with the program . as much as i LOVED this pLace when i was younger , i don't think i couLd ever bring myseLf to go here again . if you guys want good hawaiian/isLand food in the mainLand , come to the REAL state of CaLifornia & i'LL be gLad to recommend a handfuL of great pLaces . i was Looking forward to going to this pLace when we got to vegas , & it was such a bummer that it was faiL .

VS8c4Rc5b2GSPdK93j9Fdg.text: Some really great, real food in a casino. I have been going here for years. It is located in the California Casino on the second floor in a small food court. Get anything, it's good, that's it. The prices are very good, and bring CASH because that's all they take.
